content.demo: <NavigationToast>Back to settings</NavigationToast>
do: Provide a clear action that's explicit and guides user to the intended destination, e.g., "Go to Settings" or "Scroll back to top".
Only use the toast to direct users to environments or actions that are immediately relevant to their current context.
Use short, actionable text for the title and description.
dont: Don't use it as a notification, use <StatusToast/> instead.
Use the navigation toast as a supplementary guide, not the primary navigation element of your application.
Don’t leave the toast displayed indefinitely if it’s no longer relevant or actionable.
Refrain from adding unrelated or out-of-context actions within the toast.

content.description: Input shell is an atomic input component, it can replace the regular <Input /> or <Dropdown /> components in cases where you need a value which is not a string. i.e. Font dropdown.
do: Use <InputShell /> to preview non-string values.
dont: Don't use it to show simple string values, use <Input /> or <Dropdown /> instead.

commonUseCaseExamples.title: Border style

featureExamples.title: Size
featureExamples.description:

  • To emphasize specific inputs in onboarding flows, use large.
  • Use small for more dense and compact layouts.

  <InputShell size="medium" placeholder="Medium" />
  <InputShell size="small" placeholder="Small" />
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

do: Use it to build Dropdown, Multiselect, Search dropbox values or custom lists.
dont: Don't use it as standalone component for general layouts. Use SectionHeader instead.

featureExamples.title: Disabled
featureExamples.description:
Component can be disabled, it automatically changes color of all areas if used as text or icon.

Tooltip can be added to explain why the component is disabled with disabledDescription

featureExamples.title: Text cropping
featureExamples.description:
By default component wraps the text. If needed it can be configured to show ellipsis and display full value on hover.

Tooltips on truncated text will be overridden if the component is disabled. In that case, it will show disabledDescription first.
featureExamples.example:
<Layout cols={1}>
 <ListItemSelect
    ellipsis
    titleMaxLines={2}
    subtitleMaxLines={2}
    title="This is a very very very very very very very very long text that will wrap to 2 lines"
    suffix="Nice long long long long long Suffix"
  />
  <ListItemSelect
    ellipsis
    title="This is a very very very very long text that will be cropped by ellipsis at some point"
    suffix="Nice long long long long long Suffix"
  />
  <ListItemSelect
        disabled
        ellipsis
        title="This is a very very very very long text that will be cropped by ellipsis at some point"
        suffix="Nice long long long long long Suffix"
        disabledDescription="This is disabled"
      />
  
</Layout>;

        title: 'Carmel Lloyd',
        subtitle: 'Kaplan 41',
        suffix: '31 Dec 2017',

      listItemSelectBuilder({

Control the position of a toggle button labels with `labelPlacement` prop. It supports 2 values:
 - `end` (default) - use it if there are many (5 or more) items to show. Button width depends on a label length but has a max width of 270 px. Label will be truncated if the limit is reached.
 - `bottom` - use it with few items to show. Component's width is fixed to 90 px.
 - `tooltip` - use it only for professional tools that users are good at and use side actions repeatedly. For example, image editing tools like color fill, text, shape, etc. Configure tooltip's placement and size with `labelTooltipProps`.

content.description: A status toast notifies users about a status change in an application.
do: Use it to provide contextual feedback on the outcome of user action.
Use clear language and provide an actionable next step when applicable.
Provide one main action only (e.g., "Dismiss" or "Retry") to avoid complexity.
Use it to communicate status changes even when the user is inside a modal.
dont: Don’t add more than one action.
Don't use it for application-level messages. Use <SectionHelper/> instead.
Don't display identical toasts repeatedly. If an error persists, try a single persistent notification.
Don't use it as a navigation control between pages. Use <NavigationToast/> instead.

commonUseCaseExamples.title: In modals
commonUseCaseExamples.description: Status toasts should be used inside of modals as well. Toasts in modals have the same logic as in pages. They appear at the same location, with an offset of 26px from the bottom of the page and have the same stacking behavior.

featureExamples.title: Status
featureExamples.description:
Control the toast type with the status prop:

  • success is for a toast displayed after a successful action.
  • error is used for error messages and information about critical issues that prevent users from continuing.
  • warning is meant to draw the user's attention to unresolved issues that might affect the application but doesn't block the process.
  • info is for informational updates that aren't urgent.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column" gap="24px">
  <StatusToast
    status="success"
    dismissible
    action={<StatusToast.Action>Action</StatusToast.Action>}>
    Success
  </StatusToast>
  <StatusToast
    status="error"
    dismissible
    action={<StatusToast.Action>Action</StatusToast.Action>}>
    Error
  </StatusToast>
  <StatusToast
    status="warning"
    dismissible
    action={<StatusToast.Action>Action</StatusToast.Action>}>
    Warning
  </StatusToast>
  <StatusToast
    status="info"
    dismissible
    action={<StatusToast.Action>Action</StatusToast.Action>}>
    Info
  </StatusToast>
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Close button
featureExamples.description:
Control whether the user can dismiss a status toast with thedismissible prop.

NOTE: If this is not enabled, error, warning and info toasts will remain visible on the screen until an action is taken or the issue is resolved.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column" gap="24px">
  <StatusToast
    status="error"
    dismissible
    action={<StatusToast.Action>Action</StatusToast.Action>}
  >
    Dismissable
  </StatusToast>
  <StatusToast
    status="error"
    action={<StatusToast.Action>Action</StatusToast.Action>}
  >
    Non-dismissable
  </StatusToast>
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Action
featureExamples.description: Add a button to a notification with the action prop. Offer one action only to avoid complexity.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column" gap="24px">
  <StatusToast
    status="success"
    dismissible
    action={<StatusToast.Action>Action</StatusToast.Action>}>
    With action
  </StatusToast>
  <StatusToast
    status="success"
    dismissible>
    Without action
  </StatusToast>
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Width
featureExamples.description: Component width is fixed to 600px. If the context exceeds the length, it will wrap to the next line.
featureExamples.example:
<StatusToast
    status="warning"
    dismissible
    action={<StatusToast.Action>Action</StatusToast.Action>}
  >
    Width is 680px
  </StatusToast>

featureExamples.title: Height
featureExamples.description: Minimum component height is 42px. The component height will grow together with the content. Height is not limited, so be cautious about using very long texts, as a long message will cover any content behind it.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column" gap="24px">
  <StatusToast
    status="warning"
    dismissible
    action={<StatusToast.Action>Action</StatusToast.Action>}>
This is a one-line content example  </StatusToast>
  <StatusToast
    status="warning"
    dismissible
  action={<StatusToast.Action>Action</StatusToast.Action>}>
This is a much longer content example that wraps automatically to a second line while the status toast height grows with it   </StatusToast>
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Positioning
featureExamples.description: The position of a status toast is not customizable. <ToastContainer/> position is attached to the viewport with 26px gap from the bottom and not to the parent container or content within the page.

featureExamples.title: Timeout
featureExamples.description:
Whether notification disappears automatically or not can be controlled with duration prop.

Recommended delay until toast disappears is at least 7 seconds.

When possible, it is recommended to make error toasts persistent, giving the user a chance to resolve the error or dismiss it at their own pace.

featureExamples.title: Stacking
featureExamples.description:
By default, only one toast is visible at a time and the rest will be hidden under the first one.

However, you can control how many toast are visible at the same time. Up to thee toast can be visible at the same time. If more than given number is shown, they will be stacked with 6px gap between each other.

If three toasts are already visible, the newest one will be shown instead of the oldest one, until a slot is freed up by closing a toast, solving an issue, or it times out.

featureExamples.title: Shape
featureExamples.description:
Control the form of the avatar with a shape prop. It supports 2 shapes:
 - `circle` (default) - use it to represent a user.
 - `square` - use it to represent an entity such as a company or organization.

featureExamples.title: Content states
featureExamples.description:
Component has 3 states:
 - Loads image when image URL is provided.
 - Falls back to the placeholder when provided image URL is broken or not given.
 - Display initials when image URL is broken or not given, but avatar name is defined.

Adjust the avatar size using size prop. It supports 8 sizes:
 - `size90`
 - `size72`
 - `size60`
 - `size48` (default)
 - `size36`
 - `size30`

  <Avatar size="size24" name="Anne Rikki" />

featureExamples.title: Presence
featureExamples.description:
Use the presence prop to indicate the status of a user. It supports 3 statuses:
 - `online` - indicates that user is online.
 - `offline` - indicates that user is not available.

developerExamples.title: Custom HTML tag
developerExamples.description:
Use as prop to render close button as any given HTML tag.

For example, they can be rendered as:

  • <a> when attributes like href, target, etc., are needed.
  • <Link> when props like to, replace, etc. are needed.

    • All attributes will be passed to the rendered HTML tag.
developerExamples.example:
() => {
  const ReactRouterLink = (props) => <div {...props} />;
  return (
    <StorybookComponents.Stack gap="60px">
      <Box direction="vertical">
        <CloseButton
          as="a"
          href="https://www.wix.com"
          target="_blank"
          size="large"
        />
        <Text size="small">An <a/> tag</Text>
      </Box>
      <Box direction="vertical">
        <CloseButton
          as={ReactRouterLink}
          href="https://www.wix.com"
          target="_blank"
          size="large"
        />
        <Text size="small">A react router <Link/> tag</Text>
      </Box>
      <Box direction="vertical">
        <CloseButton
          as="button"
          href="https://www.wix.com"
          target="_blank"
          size="large"
        />
        <Text size="small">A native <button/> tag</Text>
      </Box>
    </StorybookComponents.Stack>
  );
};

content.description: Close button is an interactive element that allows users to exit an event.
do: Use it to close pages, notifications, helpers, cards or menus.
Use one close button at a time.
dont: Don’t use it to trigger any action other than close. Use <Button/> or <IconButton/> instead.

commonUseCaseExamples.title: Custom icon
commonUseCaseExamples.description:
To add a help icon next to the close button, pass the help icon as a child element to <CloseButton/>.

This is valid only when the help icon is next to the close button. For all other cases use <IconButton/> instead.

While it is possible to override the x icon with any other icon, it is not recommended to ensure the component's consistency.
commonUseCaseExamples.example:
<Card
  controls={
    <Box>
      <CloseButton skin="dark" size="medium">

  }
>
  <Card.Content>

  </Card.Content>

featureExamples.title: Size
featureExamples.description:
Use size prop to choose the size of the close button:

  • Use large in larger size layouts, such as <SidePanel/> or modals.
  • Use medium in medium size layouts, such as <FloatingNotification/>.
  • Use small (default) for common use cases.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack>
  <CloseButton size="large" />
  <CloseButton size="medium" />
  <CloseButton />
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Skin
featureExamples.description:
Use skin prop to control the appearance of the close button.

  • Use standard on white backgrounds.
  • Use standardFilled on white backgrounds when action needs to be emphasised.
  • Use transparent on colour or image backgrounds.
  • Use light on dark backgrounds.
  • Use dark on white or light color backgrounds.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack>
  <Box align="center"  padding="8px" backgroundColor="D80">
    <CloseButton skin="standard" />
  </Box>
  <Box align="center"  padding="8px" backgroundColor="D80">
    <CloseButton skin="standardFilled" />
  </Box>
  <Box align="center"  padding="8px" backgroundColor="B20">
    <CloseButton skin="transparent" />
  </Box>
  <Box align="center"  padding="8px" backgroundColor="D10">
    <CloseButton skin="light" />
  </Box>
  <Box align="center"  padding="8px" backgroundColor="D80">
    <CloseButton skin="dark" />
  </Box>
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Disabled
featureExamples.description: Use disabled prop to disable all close button interactions and to highlight unavailable functions.

content.description: A clickable preview for colors, gradients, images and vector graphics. Mainly used as a building part for <Swatches/> component, but can be used as a standalone item too.
do: Use it to create a swatch of selectable colors, gradients or images.
Use it to list available style options for the fill.
dont: Don’t use it to make large swatches. When a big preview is required, use <Thumbnail/> instead.

commonUseCaseExamples.title: Fill type
commonUseCaseExamples.description: Use fill preview to show the options of gradient fill types in forms.

commonUseCaseExamples.title: Color selection
commonUseCaseExamples.description: Use <FillPreview/> to let users select a color for different items.

featureExamples.title: Fill
featureExamples.description:
Render preview content with fill prop. It accepts:

  • colors
  • gradients
  • colors with opacity
  • images
  • SVGs
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack width="24px">
  <FillPreview size="medium" fill="#3399ff" />
  <FillPreview
    size="medium"
    fill="linear-gradient(to right top, #3399ff, #ffffff)"
  />
  <FillPreview size="medium" fill={['rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.2)', 'rgba(0, 0, 0, 1)']} />

    size="medium"

  />
  <FillPreview size="medium" fill={<Icons.HomeSmall />} />
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Multiple colors
featureExamples.description:
Display up to four selected colors in the fill preview. Use the fill prop to pass definitions for up to four colors, including those with opacity. This feature is useful for visualizing selections that involve semi-transparent colors.

Note: Each color segment is not individually interactive, the entire element is a single clickable area to ensure a sufficient hit target.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack width="24px">
  <FillPreview aspectRatio={1} fill="#3399ff" size="medium" />
  <FillPreview
    aspectRatio={1}
    fill={['rgba(51, 153, 255, 0.4)', '#3399ff']}
    size="medium"
  />
  <FillPreview
    aspectRatio={1}
    fill={['rgb(0, 0, 0, 0.3)', 'rgb(0, 0, 0, 1)', '#59A96A']}
    size="medium"
  />
  <FillPreview
    aspectRatio={1}
    fill={['#E1F0C4', '#9BDEAC', '#636940', '#59A96A']}
    size="medium"
  />
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Size
featureExamples.description:
Control the component size with the size prop. The component supports five sizes:

  • extraTiny – use in very dense layouts for display purposes only. Keep in mind that this size does not provide a sufficient clickable area, so use it sparingly.
  • tiny – use in tight layouts where space is limited.
  • small – use to display rows of color selections. This size is also used in other components, such as <ColorPicker/>.
  • medium – use in design settings panels.
  • large – use in spacious layouts, especially when only a few <FillPreview/> components are present.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack width="24px">
  <FillPreview size="extraTiny" fill="#3399ff" />
  <FillPreview size="tiny" fill="#3399ff" />
  <FillPreview size="small" fill="#3399ff" />
  <FillPreview size="medium" fill="#3399ff" />
  <FillPreview size="large" fill="#3399ff" />
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Preview ratio
featureExamples.description: Control preview ratio with the aspectRatio prop. By default, the component maintains a 1:1 ratio when the width of parent container is defined.

  <FillPreview aspectRatio={1 / 2} fill="#3399ff" />
  <FillPreview aspectRatio={1} fill="#3399ff" />
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: States

Control the component state with:

  • selected - use to highlight active selection.
  • disabled - use to highlight unavailable option.

accessibilityExamples.title: Screen reader support
accessibilityExamples.description:
Assign each input of the control with an ariaLabel value to specify which corner it represents, for example:

  • ariaLabel = "Top left corner"
  • ariaLabel = "Top right corner"
  • ariaLabel = "Bottom left corner"
  • ariaLabel = "Bottom right corner"

    • When the user is applying changes to all corners, use linkedValuesChangedMessage to pass a message indicating that all corners have been updated.

commonUseCaseExamples.title: Change units
commonUseCaseExamples.description: Allow users to change units of corner radius by adding dropdown selection to the suffix area.
commonUseCaseExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column" width="300px">
  <FieldSet legend="Corner radius">
    <CornerRadiusInput
      linkingButtonLabels={{
        pressed: 'Edit individually',
        unpressed: 'Apply to all corners',
      }}
      topLeft={{
        ariaLabel: 'Top left corner',
        value: 0,
        suffix: (
          <DropdownBase
            selectedId={1}
            focusOnSelectedOption
            dynamicWidth
            options={[
              { id: 0, value: 'px' },
              { id: 1, value: '%' },
            ]}
          >
            {({ toggle, selectedOption = {} }) => (
              <TextButton onClick={toggle}>{selectedOption.value}</TextButton>
            )}
          </DropdownBase>
        ),
      }}
      topRight={{
        ariaLabel: 'Top right corner',
        value: 0,
        suffix: (
          <DropdownBase
            selectedId={1}
            focusOnSelectedOption
            dynamicWidth
            options={[
              { id: 0, value: 'px' },
              { id: 1, value: '%' },
            ]}
          >
            {({ toggle, selectedOption = {} }) => (
              <TextButton onClick={toggle}>{selectedOption.value}</TextButton>
            )}
          </DropdownBase>
        ),
      }}
      bottomLeft={{
        ariaLabel: 'Bottom left corner',
        value: 0,
        suffix: (
          <DropdownBase
            selectedId={1}
            focusOnSelectedOption
            dynamicWidth
            options={[
              { id: 0, value: 'px' },
              { id: 1, value: '%' },
            ]}
          >
            {({ toggle, selectedOption = {} }) => (
              <TextButton onClick={toggle}>{selectedOption.value}</TextButton>
            )}
          </DropdownBase>
        ),
      }}
      bottomRight={{
        ariaLabel: 'Bottom right corner',
        value: 0,
        suffix: (
          <DropdownBase
            selectedId={1}
            focusOnSelectedOption
            dynamicWidth
            options={[
              { id: 0, value: 'px' },
              { id: 1, value: '%' },
            ]}
          >
            {({ toggle, selectedOption = {} }) => (
              <TextButton onClick={toggle}>{selectedOption.value}</TextButton>

    />

</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Size

content.description: A vertical tabs item is a single row of content in <VerticalTabs/>.
do: Use this as a part of the <VerticalTabs/> component.
dont: Don't use a vertical tabs item as a stand-alone component.
content.title: Usage

featureExamples.title: Types
featureExamples.description:
Use the type prop to change the behavior of the tab item:

  • tab can be used to organize settings into logical categories.
  • action can be used as a button.
  • title can be used to maintain structure between tab elements.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <VerticalTabsItem type="tab">Vertical Tab</VerticalTabsItem>
  <VerticalTabsItem type="action"> Vertical Tab Action </VerticalTabsItem>
  <VerticalTabsItem type="title">Vertical Tab Title</VerticalTabsItem>
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Affix
featureExamples.description:
Add more context to actions with affix icons:

  • Emphasize the tab action with a prefixIcon.
  • Indicate that the tab will open a popover or navigate users to another page with a suffixIcon.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <VerticalTabsItem prefixIcon={<Icons.Add />}>Prefix icon</VerticalTabsItem>
  <VerticalTabsItem suffixIcon={<Icons.ChevronRight />}>
    Suffix icon
  </VerticalTabsItem>
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Disabled
featureExamples.description: Use the disabled prop to indicate that a tab can't be selected.
featureExamples.example: <VerticalTabsItem disabled>Disabled tab</VerticalTabsItem>

content.description: Vertical tabs let users vertically navigate between different content sections within a page, card, or panel.
do: Use it to organize multiple content sections within the same context.
Use short and descriptive tab titles.
dont: Don’t use it to show the path users need to follow to complete a process. Use <Stepper/> instead.
Don't place critical navigation elements within tabs.
Don't make the user click back and forth on the different tabs to complete a single task.

commonUseCaseExamples.title: Sidebar in a custom modal
commonUseCaseExamples.description: Place tabs inside a </CustomModalLayout> to create a sidebar with structured content.
commonUseCaseExamples.example:
<CustomModalLayout
  showFooterDivider
  showHeaderDivider
  primaryButtonText="Save"
  secondaryButtonText="Cancel"
  onCloseButtonClick={() => {}}
  title="Account settings"

  content={

  }
/>;

content.description: A circular progress bar indicates the percentage of completion for a task or process with a visual indication that fills a circular track.
do: Use to indicate progress of a task that require a long time to complete (10 seconds and more).
Use to show users that their action is being processed.
dont: Don't use circular progress bar if processing user action takes less than 10 seconds. Use <Loader/> instead.

commonUseCaseExamples.title: Setup progress
commonUseCaseExamples.description: Use circular progress bar to indicate users where they are in the feature or tool setup process.
commonUseCaseExamples.example:
<Layout>
  <Cell span={5}>
    <Card>
      <Card.Header title="SEO assistant" />
      <Card.Divider />
      <Card.Content>
        <Box direction="vertical" gap="SP2" paddingBottom="SP4">
          <CircularProgressBar
            size="medium"
            value="20"
            label="1/5"
            labelPlacement="center"
          />
          <Text weight="normal">SEO setup checklist</Text>
          <Text size="small" secondary>
            Fix current issues and follow recommendations to improve this site’s
            performance in search results.
          </Text>
        </Box>
        <Button priority="secondary" size="small">
          Continue Setup
        </Button>
      </Card.Content>
    </Card>
  </Cell>
</Layout>;

featureExamples.title: Size
featureExamples.description:
Control progress bar size with size prop:

  • large is best for places where progress bar is the only element present.
  • medium is for common use cases.
  • small fits into smaller UI elements like cards and widgets.
  • tiny is used for dense layouts.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack>
  <CircularProgressBar size="large" label="Large" value={20} />
  <CircularProgressBar size="medium" label="Medium" value={20} />
  <CircularProgressBar size="small" label="Small" value={20} />
  <CircularProgressBar size="tiny" label="Tiny" value={20} />
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Skin
featureExamples.description:
Control the appearance with skin prop. It supports 3 styles:

  • standard is for common cases.
  • success is best for highligthing the positive effect of the process.
  • premium is to prompt users to upgrade their plans to premium subscription.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Background skin="light">
  <StorybookComponents.Stack padding="24px">
    <CircularProgressBar skin="standard" label="Standard" value="20" />
    <CircularProgressBar skin="success" label="Success" value="20" />
    <CircularProgressBar skin="premium" label="Premium" value="20" />
  </StorybookComponents.Stack>
</StorybookComponents.Background>;

featureExamples.title: Light
featureExamples.description: Invert the skin of a progress bar with the light prop. Use this skin on backgrounds with colors or images.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <StorybookComponents.Background skin="light">
    <StorybookComponents.Stack padding="24px">
      <CircularProgressBar value={20} skin="stanard" label="20%" />
      <CircularProgressBar value={20} skin="success" label="20%" />
      <CircularProgressBar value={20} skin="premium" label="20%" />
    </StorybookComponents.Stack>
  </StorybookComponents.Background>
  <StorybookComponents.Background skin="dark">
    <StorybookComponents.Stack padding="24px">
      <CircularProgressBar value={20} skin="stanard" light label="20%" />
      <CircularProgressBar value={20} skin="success" light label="20%" />
      <CircularProgressBar value={20} skin="premium" light label="20%" />
    </StorybookComponents.Stack>
  </StorybookComponents.Background>
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Progress indication
featureExamples.description: Add a label that indicates current progress in percentage with showProgressIndication prop.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack>
  <CircularProgressBar value={20} />
  <CircularProgressBar showProgressIndication value={20} />
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Error status
featureExamples.description:
Let users now if process failed using error property.

Add text that explains what went wrong or what action the user should take with the errorMessage prop. Message will be revealed on hover over.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <StorybookComponents.Background skin="light">
    <StorybookComponents.Stack padding="24px">
      <CircularProgressBar value="0" label="0%" />
      <CircularProgressBar value="20" label="20%" />
      <CircularProgressBar value="100" label="100%" />
      <CircularProgressBar
        value="20"
        label="Error"
        error
        errorMessage="This is the message that explains what went wrong."
      />
    </StorybookComponents.Stack>
  </StorybookComponents.Background>
  <StorybookComponents.Background skin="light">
    <StorybookComponents.Stack padding="24px">
      <CircularProgressBar value="0" skin="success" label="0%" />
      <CircularProgressBar value="20" skin="success" label="20%" />
      <CircularProgressBar value="100" skin="success" label="100%" />
      <CircularProgressBar
        value="20"
        skin="success"
        label="Error"
        error
        errorMessage="This is the message that explains what went wrong."
      />
    </StorybookComponents.Stack>
  </StorybookComponents.Background>
  <StorybookComponents.Background skin="light">
    <StorybookComponents.Stack padding="24px">
      <CircularProgressBar value="0" skin="premium" label="0%" />
      <CircularProgressBar value="20" skin="premium" label="20%" />
      <CircularProgressBar value="100" skin="premium" label="100%" />
      <CircularProgressBar
        value="20"
        skin="premium"
        label="Error"
        error
        errorMessage="This is the message that explains what went wrong."
      />
    </StorybookComponents.Stack>
  </StorybookComponents.Background>
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Label
featureExamples.description: Add custom label for the progress bar using label prop.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack>
  <CircularProgressBar value={20} />
  <CircularProgressBar label="1/5" value={20} />
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Label placement
featureExamples.description:
Control custom label position using labelPlacement prop:

  • bottom (default)
  • center
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <StorybookComponents.Background skin="light">
    <StorybookComponents.Stack padding="24px">
      <CircularProgressBar value="20" label="1/5" />
      <CircularProgressBar value="20" skin="success" label="1/5" />
      <CircularProgressBar value="20" skin="premium" label="1/5" />
    </StorybookComponents.Stack>
  </StorybookComponents.Background>
  <StorybookComponents.Background skin="light">
    <StorybookComponents.Stack padding="24px">
      <CircularProgressBar value="20" label="1/5" labelPlacement="center" />
      <CircularProgressBar
        value="20"
        skin="success"
        label="1/5"
        labelPlacement="center"
      />
      <CircularProgressBar
        value="20"
        skin="premium"
        label="1/5"
        labelPlacement="center"
      />
    </StorybookComponents.Stack>
  </StorybookComponents.Background>
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

content.description:
Presets are pre-configured building blocks made up of WDS components. They simplify the process of constructing app panels and cover a wide range of use cases.

If a specific scenario is not covered by the presets, you can still build them using WDS components yourself.

featureExamples.title: Back button
featureExamples.description: Use <Button/> in secondary priority to display back navigation to the main menu of the selected tab.
featureExamples.example:
<SidePanel width="288px">
  <SidePanel.Field>
    <Button priority="secondary" size="tiny" prefixIcon={<Icons.ChevronLeft />}>
      Back
    </Button>
  </SidePanel.Field>
</SidePanel>

featureExamples.title: Button
featureExamples.description: Prompt users to perform a main action, such as saving changes or creating a new item, with the primary <Button/> skin. Use <FieldSet/> to provide a label to items that will appear after the user completes the action.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <SidePanel width="288px">
<SidePanel.Field>
<Box align="center">
<Button size="small">Confirm</Button>
</Box>
</SidePanel.Field>
</SidePanel>
<SidePanel width="288px">
  <SidePanel.Field>
    <FormField label="Filters" labelSize="small" labelPlacement="top">
      <Box align="center">
        <Button size="small" prefixIcon={<Icons.AddSmall />}>Create New Filter</Button>
      </Box>
    </FormField>
  </SidePanel.Field>
</SidePanel>
</StorybookComponents.Stack>

featureExamples.title: Button set
featureExamples.description: Group related actions together using one of two components. Use <FieldSet/> when a label for related actions is needed.
featureExamples.example:
<SidePanel width="288px">
  <SidePanel.Field>
    <FieldSet legend="Manage selection" direction="vertical" alignment="center">
      <Button size="small">Add Choice</Button>
      <TextButton size="small">Add Multiple Choices</TextButton>
    </FieldSet>
  </SidePanel.Field>
</SidePanel>

featureExamples.title: Checkboxes
featureExamples.description: Use checkboxes to display all available options. For example, in display settings, use checkboxes to allow users to select what to show or hide.

featureExamples.title: Color and opacity
featureExamples.description: Use a <Slider/> to control the selected object color and opacity.

featureExamples.title: Corner radius input
featureExamples.description: Use <CornerRadiusInput/> to let users control the corner radius of an element such as a card, button or input field.

featureExamples.title: Date picker
featureExamples.description: Use <DatePicker/> to select or enter a specific date.
featureExamples.example:
<SidePanel width="288px">
  <SidePanel.Field>
    <FormField label="Start date">
      <DatePicker value={new Date()} size="small" width="100%" />
    </FormField>
  </SidePanel.Field>
</SidePanel>

featureExamples.title: Date range
featureExamples.description: Use <FieldSet/> to group multiple <DatePicker/> components to allow users to select a range of dates.
featureExamples.example:
<SidePanel width="288px">
  <SidePanel.Field>
    <FieldSet legendPlacement="none" gap="small">
      <FormField label="From">
        <DatePicker width="100%" size="small" value={new Date()} />
      </FormField>
      <FormField label="To">
        <DatePicker width="100%" size="small" value={new Date()} />
      </FormField>
    </FieldSet>
  </SidePanel.Field>
</SidePanel>;

featureExamples.title: Dropdown
featureExamples.description: Use <Dropdown/> to let users select a single item from a predefined list of options.

featureExamples.title: Dropdown and fill preview
featureExamples.description: Group <Dropdown/> and <FillPreview/> to allow users select an option from the dropdown and choose its color.

featureExamples.title: Empty state
featureExamples.description: Use an <EmptyState/> in the main tab of the app settings panel to give a brief introduction to the app and help users get started.
featureExamples.example:
<SidePanel width="288px">
  <SidePanel.Field>
    <EmptyState
      image={<Image width="120px" height="120px" />}
      title="Event page"
      subtitle="This is where guests see your event's schedule. Customize text, color & more."
    >
      <Box direction="vertical" gap="small">
        <Button size="small">Customize Page</Button>
        <Button priority="secondary" size="small">
         Manage Event
        </Button>
      </Box>
    </EmptyState>
  </SidePanel.Field>
</SidePanel>;

featureExamples.title: Fill preview
featureExamples.description: Use <FillPreview/> to let users select a color or to show a color applied to an element.
featureExamples.example:
<SidePanel width="288px">
  <SidePanel.Field>
    <FormField
      label="Border color"
      labelSize="small"
      labelPlacement="left"
      labelWidth="1fr"
    >
      <Box width="30px" height="30px">
        <FillPreview fill="#B7FFBA" aspectRatio={1} />
      </Box>
    </FormField>
  </SidePanel.Field>
</SidePanel>

featureExamples.title: Google preview
featureExamples.description: Google preview allows users to preview how the website appears in Google search results. It is frequently used in SEO settings’ panels.
featureExamples.example:
<SidePanel width="360px">
  <SidePanel.Field>
    <FormField label="Google preview">
      <GooglePreview
        siteName="Wix"
        title="Wix.com: Website Builder - Create a Free Website Today"
        previewUrl="https://www.wix.com"
        description="How to create a website for free. Sign up for a free website builder. Choose what kind of website you want to create."
        titleMaxLines={2}
      />
    </FormField>
  </SidePanel.Field>
</SidePanel>

featureExamples.title: Image
featureExamples.description: Use <Image/> and <IconButton/> to prompt users to add images for backgrounds and covers or for logo uploads.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">

        </IconButton>
        <IconButton size="small" skin="standard" priority="secondary">
          <Icons.DeleteSmall />
        </IconButton>
      </FieldSet>
    </SidePanel.Field>
  </SidePanel>
  <SidePanel width="288px">
    <SidePanel.Field>
      <FieldSet
        legend="Business logo"
        legendSize="small"
        legendPlacement="top"
        alignment="center"
        columns="142px auto auto"
      >
        <Image
          height="90px"
          width="130px"

        <IconButton size="tiny" skin="standard" priority="primary">
          <Icons.RefreshSmall />
        </IconButton>
        <Button size="tiny">Update</Button>
      </FieldSet>
    </SidePanel.Field>
  </SidePanel>
</StorybookComponents.Stack>

featureExamples.title: Input with actions
featureExamples.description: Use input area to let users add text and perform actions with the text. For example, add <Input/> with <IconButton/> to let users add links or use it as a form submission field.
featureExamples.example:
<SidePanel width="288px">
  <SidePanel.Field>

>

featureExamples.title: Number input
featureExamples.description: Allow users to edit numeric values, like defining maximum order amount, by adding a <NumberInput/> component.
featureExamples.example:

featureExamples.title: Radio group
featureExamples.description: Use <Radiogroup/> to allow users to make a single choice from a predefined list of options.
featureExamples.example:
<SidePanel width="288px">

    <FieldSet legend="When button is clicked">

featureExamples.title: Section header
featureExamples.description: Use <SidePanel.Section/> to group several related sections together.

featureExamples.title: Segmented toggle
featureExamples.description: Use <SegmentedToggle/> to let users switch between different layouts, such as between a grid or a list view, or to control an item’s status.
featureExamples.example:
<SidePanel width="288px">
  <SidePanel.Field>
    <FormField label="Registration for this event">
      <SegmentedToggle size="small" defaultSelected="Open">
        <SegmentedToggle.Button
          value="Open">
          Open
        </SegmentedToggle.Button>
        <SegmentedToggle.Button
          value="Closed">
          Closed
        </SegmentedToggle.Button>
      </SegmentedToggle>
    </FormField>
  </SidePanel.Field>
</SidePanel>;

featureExamples.title: Slider and number input
featureExamples.description: Let users control border radius, color opacity or padding with a <Slider/>, and and let them enter an exact value by wrapping it together with an <Input/> in a <FieldSet/>.

featureExamples.title: Text area
featureExamples.description: Let users customize longer texts like descriptions or informational banners by adding an <InputArea/> component.
featureExamples.example:
<SidePanel width="288px">
  <SidePanel.Field>
    <FormField label="Product description">
      <InputArea
        value="I'm a product description. I'm a great place to add more details about product such."
        size="small"
        minHeight="70px"
        resizable
      />
    </FormField>
  </SidePanel.Field>
</SidePanel>

featureExamples.title: Text button
featureExamples.description: <TextButton/> communicates low-emphasis actions that users can take. Use it for optional actions on a page or a widget.
featureExamples.example:
<SidePanel width="288px">
  <SidePanel.Field>
    <FormField>
    <TextButton size="small" prefixIcon={<Icons.Add />}>
      Add more
    </TextButton>  
    </FormField>
  </SidePanel.Field>
</SidePanel>;

featureExamples.title: Text formatting
featureExamples.description: Allow users to format text by providing several style options by wrapping <ToggleButton/> inside a <FieldSet/>.

featureExamples.title: Text input
featureExamples.description: Allow users to customize short texts, like button texts, placeholder texts, labels by adding a <Input/> component.
featureExamples.example:
<SidePanel width="288px">
  <SidePanel.Field>
    <FormField label="Button text">
      <Input value="Add to Cart" size="small" />
    </FormField>
  </SidePanel.Field>
</SidePanel>

featureExamples.title: Text paragraph
featureExamples.description: Text is a typography component used to create a wide variety of content including guidance, information, descriptions, labels and more.
featureExamples.example:
<SidePanel width="288px">
  <SidePanel.Field>
    <Box direction="vertical" gap="6px">
      <Text weight="normal">Fun facts about Skype</Text>
      <Text weight="thin" size="small">
        Keep your header fixed at the top of the browser when visitors scroll in
        your website. Click Preview in order to see your header fixed.
      </Text>
      <TextButton size="small">Read More</TextButton>
    </Box>
  </SidePanel.Field>
</SidePanel>

featureExamples.title: Text style
featureExamples.description: Allow users to select fonts style and color with <Button/> and <FillPreview/> components.
featureExamples.example:
<SidePanel width="288px">
  <SidePanel.Field>
    <FieldSet legend="Title" columns="auto 30px">
      <SelectorButton 
        fullWidth
        size="small"
        suffixIcon={<Icons.TextSmall/>}
        > Heading 1
      </SelectorButton>
      <FillPreview fill="#B7FFBA" aspectRatio={1} />
    </FieldSet>
  </SidePanel.Field>
</SidePanel>

featureExamples.title: Thumbnails
featureExamples.description: Use <Thumbnail/> when select items need to be emphasized with graphics or images, such as for alignment options or placement. It can have a title or be in a horizontal layout.

featureExamples.title: Time input (range)
featureExamples.description: <TimeInput/> allows users to enter or select a specific time value.
featureExamples.example:
<SidePanel width="288px">
  <SidePanel.Field>
    <FieldSet
      gap="small"
      alignment="end"
      columns="auto auto 30px"
      legendPlacement="none"
    >
      <FormField label="Start">
        <TimeInput size="small" />
      </FormField>
      <FormField label="End">
        <TimeInput size="small" />
      </FormField>

        <Icons.EditSmall />

  </SidePanel.Field>
</SidePanel>

featureExamples.title: Toggle switch
featureExamples.description: For settings that can be turned off or on, use <ToggleSwitch/> in a <FormField/> wrapper.
featureExamples.example:
<SidePanel width="288px">
  <SidePanel.Field>
    <FormField label="Apply shadow" labelPlacement="left" labelWidth="1fr">
      <ToggleSwitch size="medium" checked />
    </FormField>
  </SidePanel.Field>
</SidePanel>;

featureExamples.title: Upload button
featureExamples.description: Allow users to upload files to the system. Use this preset with a <StatusIndicator/> to show if the action was successful or not.
featureExamples.example:
<SidePanel width="288px">
  <SidePanel.Field>
    <FormField
      label="Add a file"

    </FormField>
  </SidePanel.Field>
</SidePanel>

featureExamples.title: URL
featureExamples.description: Let users add links to elements by providing a <SelectorButton/> to link to the editing flow.

<SidePanel width="288px">
  <SidePanel.Field>

  <SelectorButton 
  fullWidth
  size="small"
  suffixIcon={<Icons.LinkSmall />}

<GooglePreview
  siteName="Wix Logo Maker"

content.description: Google preview allows users to preview how the website appears in Google search results. It is frequently used in SEO settings’ panels.
do: Use it to illustrate how a website appears on Google search results.
Use it to visualize changes in SEO settings.
dont: Don’t use it to visualise how information is displayed when the URL address is shared on social media platforms (use <SocialPreview/> instead).

commonUseCaseExamples.title: SEO settings panel
commonUseCaseExamples.description: Use Google preview to visualise SEO settings impact on user website appearance in Google search results.

featureExamples.title: Structure
featureExamples.description:
Component consists of 4 content areas:

  • siteName - shows the title of a page at the top of the widget.
  • previewUrl - shows the URL preview at the top of the widget.
  • title - shows the title of the page and its keywords, as set in the SEO settings.
  • description - shows a short description for the page, as set in the SEO settings (optional).
featureExamples.example:
<GooglePreview
  siteName="Site name"
  title="Title"
  previewUrl="Preview URL"
  description="Description"
/>;

featureExamples.title: Skin
featureExamples.description:
Change the background of the widget with skin prop:

  • light (default) sets the background to white with gray 1 px border.
  • transparent removes the background color and border.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <GooglePreview
    siteName="Site Name"
    title="Title | <GooglePreview/> in light (default) background"
    previewUrl="www.site-name.com"
    description="A short description for a site"
    skin="light"
  />
  <GooglePreview
    siteName="Site Name"
    title="Title | <GooglePreview/> in transparent background"
    previewUrl="www.site-name.com"
    description="A short description for a site"
    skin="transparent"
  />
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Title
featureExamples.description:
Limit the number of lines the title can take with titleMaxLines prop.

The default titleMaxLines value is 1.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <GooglePreview
    siteName="Site Name"
    title="Site Name | This is a single line title"
    previewUrl="www.site-name.com"
    description="A short description for a site"
  />
  <GooglePreview
    siteName="Site Name"
    title="Site Name | This is an especially long website title that does not fit in one line and gets truncated"
    previewUrl="www.site-name.com"
    description="A short description for a site"
  />
  <GooglePreview
    siteName="Site Name"
    title="Site Name | This is an especially long website title that does not fit in one line. However, titleMaxlines prop is set to 2, so the title wraps into two lines"
    previewUrl="www.site-name.com"
    description="A short description for a site"
    titleMaxLines={2}
  />
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Description
featureExamples.description:
Use description to provide more context about a site.

Truncate the description after a certain number of lines with descriptionMaxLines prop.

The default descriptionMaxLines value is 2.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <GooglePreview
    siteName="Site Name"
    title="Site Name | a title of your site"
    previewUrl="www.site-name.com"
    description="A short description for a site containing all the relevant keywords that get your website great results in search engines."
  />
  <GooglePreview
    siteName="Site Name"
    title="Site Name | a title of your site"
    previewUrl="www.site-name.com"
    description="This is a long description for a site containing all the relevant keywords that get your website great results in search engines. If the description is longer than 2 lines, by default it gets truncated by ellipses at the end of the second line. This is an example how the end of this sentence will not be visible, since it will get truncated by ellipses."
  />
  <GooglePreview
    siteName="Site Name"
    title="Site Name | Preview without description"
    previewUrl="www.site-name.com"
  />
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

content.description: Card gallery item is an interactive component that allows users to display media content and actions related to it in a grid layout.
do: Use it to represent a content entity, such a blog post, product or event.
Use it to display content that users can interact with.
Use it to display content for grid layout.
dont: Don’t use it to display static media. Use <Image/> or <Preview/> instead.
Don’t use it to display content in a custom layout. Use <Card/> instead.

commonUseCaseExamples.title: Product list
commonUseCaseExamples.description:
Use `<CardGalleryItem/>` to list down visual items, such as dishes, blog posts, products or their collections.
        These lists are commonly accompanied by an `<AddItem/>` component at the end of the list which allows users to add a new item to the grid.

featureExamples.title: Background
featureExamples.description:
Define a gallery item's background using one of the following:
 - `backgroundImageUrl` - use it to pass a link to the background image source file.
 - `backgroundImageNode` - use it to pass a custom component as a background.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack>
  <CardGalleryItem
    backgroundImageUrl="example.jpg"
    primaryActionProps={{
      label: 'Button',
    }}
  />
  <CardGalleryItem
    backgroundImageNode=<Image height="100%" />
    primaryActionProps={{
      label: 'Button',
    }}
  />
  <CardGalleryItem
    backgroundImageNode=<FillPreview fill="linear-gradient(45deg, rgba(14,0,255,1) 0%, rgba(0,212,255,1) 80%)" />
    primaryActionProps={{
      label: 'Button',
    }}
  />
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Image placement
featureExamples.description:
Specify the placement of the background image using one of the following:

- top (default) - Places the background image on top of the footer, as a <MediaOverlay/>.

- side - Places the image in the footer, to the left of the title/subtitle.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack>
  <CardGalleryItem
    backgroundImageUrl="example.jpg"
    primaryActionProps={{
      label: 'Button',
    }}
    title="Title"
    imagePlacement="top"
  />
  <CardGalleryItem
    backgroundImageUrl="example.jpg"
    primaryActionProps={{}}
    title="Title"
    imagePlacement="side"
  />
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Title
featureExamples.description:
Give more context to a card with following props:
 - `title` - use it for a short and descriptive card title.
 - `subtitle` - use it for a short caption to provide more narrative.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack width="200px">
  <CardGalleryItem 
    backgroundImageUrl="example.jpg"
    primaryActionProps={{
      label: 'Button',
    }}
    title="Title"
    subtitle="Subtitle"
  />
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Badge
featureExamples.description: Emphasise item status with a `badge`. Use it to promote new items or highlight ones that require attention.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack width="200px">
  <CardGalleryItem
    backgroundImageUrl="example.jpg"
    primaryActionProps={{
      label: 'Button',
    }}
    badge={<Badge skin="standard">Badge</Badge>}
  />
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Actions
featureExamples.description:
Define primary and secondary actions for an item with `primaryActionProps` and `secondaryActionProps`. 
        This component is an interactive element so primary action is mandatory, while the secondary button is optional.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack width="400px">
  <CardGalleryItem
    backgroundImageUrl="example.jpg"
    primaryActionProps={{
      label: 'Button',
    }}
    secondaryActionProps={{
      label: 'Text Button',
    }}
  />
  <CardGalleryItem
    backgroundImageUrl="example.jpg"
    primaryActionProps={{
      label: 'Button',
      disabled: true,
      disabledMessage: 'Message explaining the status',
    }}
    secondaryActionProps={{
      label: 'Text Button',
    }}
  />
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Settings menu
featureExamples.description:
Allow users to act on a specific item by providing a settings menu.
        Popover menu can contain any required number of actions inside of it.

featureExamples.title: Size
featureExamples.description:
Control the size of the card. It supports 2 sizes:

- small. Use this size if the card is stretched to less than 200px.

- medium (default). This size is supposed to be used if the card is stretched to more than or equal 200px in the container.

Note that if imagePlacement="side" is enabled, the size prop will change the size of the image.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <Box width="198px">
    <CardGalleryItem
      backgroundImageUrl="example.jpg"
      size="small"
      primaryActionProps={{
        label: 'Edit',
      }}
      title="Title"
      subtitle="Subtitle"
    />
  </Box>
  <Box width="300px">
    <CardGalleryItem
      backgroundImageUrl="example.jpg"
      size="medium"
      primaryActionProps={{
        label: 'Edit',
      }}
      title="Title"
      subtitle="Subtitle"
    />
  </Box>
  <Box width="300px">
 <CardGalleryItem
    backgroundImageUrl="example.jpg"
    primaryActionProps={{}}
    title="Title"
   size="small"
    imagePlacement="side"
  />
</Box>
  <Box width="300px">
 <CardGalleryItem
    backgroundImageUrl="example.jpg"
    primaryActionProps={{}}
    title="Title"
   size="medium"
    imagePlacement="side"
  />
</Box>
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Suffix
featureExamples.description: Define a component (commonly icon) to be added to the footer. Use showSuffixOnHover to make it appear only when hovering over the card.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack>
  <CardGalleryItem
    backgroundImageUrl="example.jpg"
    size="medium"
    primaryActionProps={{
      label: 'Edit',
    }}
    title="Title"
    subtitle="Subtitle"
    suffix={<Icons.Home />}
  />
  <CardGalleryItem
    backgroundImageUrl="example.jpg"
    size="medium"
    primaryActionProps={{
      label: 'Edit',
    }}
    title="Title"
    subtitle="Subtitle"
    suffix={<Icons.Home />}
    showSuffixOnHover
  />
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Skin
featureExamples.description:
Control the look of the card border with skin prop.

- standard (default) shows a shadow around the card

- outlined gives a one pixel border around the card
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack width="400px" flexDirection="column">
  <CardGalleryItem
    backgroundImageUrl="example.jpg"
    primaryActionProps={{
      label: 'Button',
    }}
    title="Title"
    skin="standard"
    imagePlacement="top"
  />
  <CardGalleryItem
    backgroundImageUrl="example.jpg"
    primaryActionProps={{}}
    title="Title"
    skin="standard"
    imagePlacement="side"
  />
    <CardGalleryItem
    backgroundImageUrl="example.jpg"
    primaryActionProps={{
      label: 'Button',
    }}
    title="Title"
    skin="outlined"
    imagePlacement="top"
  />
  <CardGalleryItem
    backgroundImageUrl="example.jpg"
    primaryActionProps={{}}
    title="Title"
    skin="outlined"
    imagePlacement="side"
  />
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Skin visibility
featureExamples.description: Control if the skin should be visible at all times or only on hover with skinVisibility prop.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack width="400px" flexDirection="column">
  <CardGalleryItem
    backgroundImageUrl="example.jpg"
    primaryActionProps={{
      label: 'Button',
    }}
    title="Title"
    skinVisibility
    skin="standard"
    imagePlacement="top"
  />
  <CardGalleryItem
    backgroundImageUrl="example.jpg"
    primaryActionProps={{}}
    title="Title"
    skinVisibility
    skin="standard"
    imagePlacement="side"
  />

</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

content.demo: <ListItemSection title="Section" />
content.description: List item section allows you to group or divide list options or actions.
do: Use it to build Dropdown, Multiselect, Search dropbox values or custom lists.
dont: Don't use it as standalone component for general layouts. Use SectionHeader instead.

commonUseCaseExamples.title: Grouping
commonUseCaseExamples.description: Use it to group options into categories.
commonUseCaseExamples.example:
<Box direction="vertical">
  <ListItemSection type="subheader" title="Most popular" />
  <ListItemSelect title="Wix Stores" />
  <ListItemSelect title="Wix Bookings" />
  <ListItemSelect title="Wix Blog" />
  <ListItemSection type="subheader" title="Other" />
  <ListItemSection title="Wix Events" />
  <ListItemSelect title="Wix Forum" />
  <ListItemSelect title="Wix Restaurants" />
</Box>

featureExamples.title: Structure
featureExamples.description: A list item section consists of title and suffix areas.
featureExamples.example:
<ListItemSection
  title="title"
  suffix={
    <StorybookComponents.Placeholder height="24px">
      suffix
    </StorybookComponents.Placeholder>
  }
/>;

featureExamples.title: Types
featureExamples.description:
Component divides lists by 4 types:

  • title - acts as a title for list items.
  • subheader - acts as separator between list items for differentiation
  • whitespace - adds some padding between list items.
  • divider - same as whitespace, but with a line.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <ListItemSection title="Section title" />
  <ListItemSection type="subheader" title="Subheader title" />
  <ListItemSection type="divider" />
  <ListItemSection type="whitespace" />
</StorybookComponents.Stack>

featureExamples.title: Suffix
featureExamples.description: Add text, icons or a button at the end using suffix.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <ListItemSection suffix="Suffix Action" />
  <ListItemSection suffix={<InfoIcon content="Tooltip content!" />} />
</StorybookComponents.Stack>

featureExamples.title: Text overflow
featureExamples.description: By default, text wraps into any number of lines. With ellipsis enabled, it will truncate to fit the width of the parent container.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <ListItemSection
    ellipsis
    title="This is a very very very very long text that will be cropped by ellipsis at some point. This is a very very very very long text that will be cropped by ellipsis at some point."
  />
  <ListItemSection title="This is a very very very very long text that will *not* be cropped by ellipsis at some point" />
</StorybookComponents.Stack>

content.description: Tabs enable users to navigate between different content sections on the same page, card, or a panel.
do: Use it to organize multiple content sections within the same context.
Use it to enhance usability by grouping information or forms into smaller, easily digestible parts.
Use short and descriptive tab titles.
dont: Don’t use it to group unrelated content.
Don’t use it to navigate to other pages. Use <Sidebar/>, <Breadcrumbs/> or links instead.
Don’t use it to show the path users need to follow to complete a process. Use <Stepper/> instead.

commonUseCaseExamples.title: In a page

commonUseCaseExamples.title: In a panel
commonUseCaseExamples.description:
Let users switch between parts of content in the same context of a <SidePanel/>.

Select to show either panel divider or a default tabs’ divider to separate panel header from its main content.

featureExamples.title: Size
featureExamples.description:
Control tabs size with size prop:

  • Use small in dense layouts, like narrow panels.
  • Use medium (default) in all other layouts, like below <Page.Header/>.

featureExamples.title: Min width
featureExamples.description:
By default, tabs fill in the entire width of their parent container and have a minimum width of 628 px.

Set custom min width of tabs using the minWidth prop.

featureExamples.title: Type
featureExamples.description:
Control how tabs are positioned with type prop:

  • By default, each tab grows with its title. Side paddings are inside tabs.
  • compact - each tab grows with its title. Side paddings are outside tabs.
  • compactSide - each tab grows with its title. Side paddings are outside tabs. The first and the last tab has no left and right paddings respectively.
  • uniformSide - each tab grows to the size defined in width prop. If tab content is longer than the width, it gets truncated by ellipsis. Side paddings are inside tabs.
  • uniformFull - all tabs grow equally to fill in the whole container. Side paddings are inside tabs.

featureExamples.title: Alignment
featureExamples.description:
Control text alignment inside tabs with alignment prop. It supports 3 options:

  • Use start (default) to align tab titles to to the left.
  • Use center to align them to the middle.
  • Use end to align them to the right.

featureExamples.title: Bottom divider
featureExamples.description: Control if the default bottom divider is shown with hasDivider prop.

featureExamples.title: Side content
featureExamples.description:
Add any component to the end of tabs with sideContent prop.

For example, use it to store a filter or form actions like Save and Cancel.

do: Use it to show how a user's site or other content will appear in a web browser.

Don’t use it to show how a website's URL appears on social media (use <SocialPreview/> or <SocialPostPreview/> instead).
Don’t use it to show how a site appears on Google search results (use <GooglePreview/> instead).

Change the background style with skin prop:

featureExamples.title: Browser bar size
featureExamples.description:
Control the height of the browser bar with browserBarSize prop, depending on the preview area width:

  • Use size9 when preview's width is <312 px.
  • Use size12 (default) when width is 312–443 px.
  • Use size18 when width is 444–660 px.
  • Use size24 when width is >660 px.

content.description: Section headers are used to group together content or items under a unifying title. They help users understand what the following section is about.
do: Use it in a <SidePanel/> to introduce a new section of related content.
Use it in an <Accordion/> or a <Card/> to group together related items.
dont: Don't use it inside of a <Page/>. Use <Page.Section/> instead.

accessibilityExamples.title: Title as a heading
accessibilityExamples.description:
By default, a section header title is a text element (<span>).

For better accessibility, use the as prop to render the section header title as a heading element.
accessibilityExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <SectionHeader title="Default" />
  <SectionHeader title="Title as <h3> heading" as="h3" />
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

commonUseCaseExamples.title: Group content in cards
commonUseCaseExamples.description:
Use section headers to organize card info into separate categories.

This makes the whole card easier to scan.

featureExamples.title: Size
featureExamples.description:
Control the size of a section header with the size prop:

  • medium (default) is the standard used in common cases.
  • small is used in dense layouts and panels.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <SectionHeader title="Medium" size="medium" />
  <SectionHeader title="Small" size="small" />
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Horizontal padding
featureExamples.description:
Adjust the horizontalPadding of a section header according to the content padding inside the following section:

  • large (default)
  • medium
  • small
  • tiny
  • xTiny
  • xxTiny
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <SectionHeader title="Large" horizontalPadding="large" />
  <SectionHeader title="Medium" horizontalPadding="medium" />
  <SectionHeader title="Small" horizontalPadding="small" />
  <SectionHeader title="Tiny" horizontalPadding="tiny" />
  <SectionHeader title="Extra tiny" horizontalPadding="xTiny" />
  <SectionHeader title="Extra-extra tiny" horizontalPadding="xxTiny" />
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Skin
featureExamples.description:
Control the style of a section header using the skin prop:

  • standard is the default and is used in most cases.
  • neutral is used to minimize the component’s visual weight.
  • light is used as a completely minimal header that blends in with rest of the content.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <SectionHeader title="Standard" skin="standard" />
  <SectionHeader title="Neutral" skin="neutral" />
 <SectionHeader title="Light" skin="light" />
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Dividers
featureExamples.description:
Control which dividers are visible with the divider prop:

  • By default, a section header has both top and bottom dividers.
  • Use top when there is already a divider at the bottom of a component.
  • Use bottom when there is already a divider at the top of a component.
  • Use none when there are already dividers at the top and bottom of a component.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <SectionHeader title="Default" />
  <SectionHeader title="Top" divider="top" />
  <SectionHeader title="Bottom" divider="bottom" />
  <SectionHeader title="No dividers" divider="none" />
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Suffix
featureExamples.description:
Use a suffix container to add info or actions that relate to the content below a section header.

A variety of components can be used in the suffix:

  • <InfoIcon/>
  • <TextButton/>
  • <Button/>
  • <IconButton/>
  • <Text/> or others
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <SectionHeader
    suffix={
      <InfoIcon
        size="small"
        content="Info icon gives more information about a section."
      />
    }
  />
  <SectionHeader
    suffix={
      <TextButton
        size="tiny"
        priority="secondary"
        prefixIcon=<Icons.AddSmall />
      >
        Suffix
      </TextButton>
    }
  />
  <SectionHeader
    suffix={
      <Button size="tiny" priority="secondary">
        Suffix
      </Button>
    }
  />
  <SectionHeader
    suffix={
      <IconButton size="tiny" priority="secondary">
        <Icons.MoreSmall />
      </IconButton>
    }
  />
  <SectionHeader suffix={<Text size="tiny">Suffix</Text>} />
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Title
featureExamples.description:
Use the title prop to describe the content that appears below the section header.

The default is a text value, but the container can accept any component.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <SectionHeader title="Default" />
  <SectionHeader
    title={
      <Text weight="bold" size="small">
        Custom title
      </Text>
    }
  />
  <SectionHeader title=<StorybookComponents.Placeholder height="24px" /> />
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Title alignment
featureExamples.description:
Control the title's position with the align prop:

  • Use start (default) for left-aligned lists.
  • Use center in settings panels.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <SectionHeader title="Start" align="start" />
  <SectionHeader title="Center" align="center" />
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Title overflow
featureExamples.description:
Title text that does not fit in one line gets truncated with an ellipsis.

The full text appears in a tooltip when hovering over the truncated text.
featureExamples.example: <SectionHeader title="A very long section title goes into a title container in this case. It even has multiple sentences inside. It will be truncated by ellipses once it reaches the second line" />;

developerExamples.title: Custom content width
developerExamples.description:
Set the width of each child component using columns.

  • Use min-content to make the child component as narrow as possible.
  • Use auto to make the child component fill in all available space.
  • Use px to set the component's width.
  • Use fr to set the column proportions. For example, use 1fr 1fr for equal width child components and 1fr 3fr to make the first child fill 25% and second to fill 75% of available width.
  • Use a combination of all 4 values to create custom content layouts.

    • Note: Do not use percentage values as they will cause child components to exceed the field set width.
developerExamples.example:

    legend="Assign color to a team"
    columns="auto min-content"
    alignment="center"
  >
    <Dropdown placeholder="Select a team" />
    <FillButton fill="purple" tooltipContent="Pick a color" />
  </FieldSet>
  <FieldSet
    legend="Select a time range"
    alignment="end"
    columns="1fr 1fr min-content"
  >
    <FormField label="From">
      <TimeInput value={new Date()} />
    </FormField>
    <FormField label="To">

    </FormField>

      <Icons.Edit />
    </IconButton>
  </FieldSet>
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

content.description: A field set wraps a group of related components in a form, has a title (legend), and can include a tooltip for extra information.
do: Use it to provide a short title for a group of related form components.
Use it to give a group title for screen reader users.
Provide additional information about the group in a tooltip.
dont: Don't use it to add a label for an individual form component. Use <FormField/> instead.

accessibilityExamples.title: Using hidden legends
accessibilityExamples.description:
Provide extra information within the legend for screen reader users.

To hide this information on screen, set the legendPlacement to none.
accessibilityExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <FieldSet legend="Select a date range" columns="1fr 1fr">
    <FormField label="From">
      <DatePicker width="100%" value={new Date()} />
    </FormField>
    <FormField label="To">
      <DatePicker width="100%" value={new Date()} />
    </FormField>
  </FieldSet>
  <FieldSet
    legend="Select a date range"
    columns="1fr 1fr"
    legendPlacement="none"
  >
    <FormField label="Start date">
      <DatePicker width="100%" value={new Date()} />
    </FormField>
    <FormField label="End date">
      <DatePicker width="100%" value={new Date()} />
    </FormField>
  </FieldSet>
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

accessibilityExamples.title: Status messages
accessibilityExamples.description:
When using FieldSet with FormField, the status message is connected to Input element automatically. If it's a FieldSet message without status, it applies to all Inputs under that FieldSet and if message has a status, it only applies the message to the FormField of matching status.

If more control is required over status message linking, set FieldSet statusId and Input aria-describedby to the same value. This disables the automatic linking.
accessibilityExamples.example:
() => {
  return (
    <StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
      <FieldSet
        legend="User contacts (Auto linked status message)"
        status="error"
        columns="1fr 1fr"
        statusMessage="Insert your phone number starting with +3706."
      >
        <FormField label="Phone number" status="error">
          <Input value="00000" />
        </FormField>
        <FormField label="Email">
          <Input value="user@email.com" />
        </FormField>
      </FieldSet>
      
      {/* Manually linked status message */}
      <FieldSet
        legend="User contacts (Manually linked status message)"
        status="error"
        columns="1fr 1fr"
        statusMessage="Insert your phone number starting with +3706."
        statusId="number-status"
      >
        <FormField label="Phone number" status="error">
          <Input value="00000" ariaDescribedby="number-status" />
        </FormField>
        <FormField label="Email">
          <Input value="user@email.com" />
        </FormField>
      </FieldSet>
    </StorybookComponents.Stack>
  )
}

commonUseCaseExamples.title: In setting panels
commonUseCaseExamples.description:
Use field sets to group related form components together and give them a title.

When individual component labels are descriptive enough, set field set legendPlacement to none.
commonUseCaseExamples.example:
