              legend="Background color"
              columns="30px auto 72px"
              alignment="center"
            >
              <Box>
                <FillPreview fill="#B7EEFF" />
              </Box>
              <Box marginRight="12px">
                <Slider
                  displayMarks={false}
                  gradientColor="#B7EEFF"
                  min={0}
                  max={100}
                  value={backgroundOpacity}
                  onChange={changeBackgroundOpacity}
                />
              </Box>
              <Input
                value={backgroundOpacity}
                suffix={<Input.Affix>%</Input.Affix>}
                size="small"
                onChange={(e) => changeBackgroundOpacity(e.target.value)}
              />
            </FieldSet>
          </SidePanel.Field>
          <SidePanel.Field>
            <FieldSet
              legend="Text color"
              columns="30px auto 72px"
              alignment="center"
            >
              <Box>
                <FillPreview fill="#454B46" />
              </Box>
              <Box marginRight="12px">
                <Slider
                  displayMarks={false}
                  gradientColor="#454B46"
                  min={0}
                  max={100}
                  value={textOpacity}
                  onChange={changeTextOpacity}
                />
              </Box>
              <Input
                value={textOpacity}
                suffix={<Input.Affix>%</Input.Affix>}
                size="small"
                onChange={(e) => changeTextOpacity(e.target.value)}
              />
            </FieldSet>
          </SidePanel.Field>
          <SidePanel.Field>
            <FieldSet
              legend="Background photo"
              columns="auto min-content min-content"
              alignment="center"
            >
              <Box marginRight="12px">
                <Image src="running_man.png" />
              </Box>
              <Button priority="secondary" size="small">
                Replace
              </Button>
              <Tooltip content="Delete image">
                <IconButton priority="secondary" size="small">
                  <Icons.DeleteSmall />
                </IconButton>
              </Tooltip>
            </FieldSet>
          </SidePanel.Field>
          <SidePanel.Section title="Publish period">
            <SidePanel.Field divider={false}>
              <FormField labelPlacement="left" label="Set publish period">
                <ToggleSwitch
                  checked={hasPublishPeriod}
                  onChange={() => setHasPublishPeriod(!hasPublishPeriod)}
                  size="small"
                />
              </FormField>
            </SidePanel.Field>
            <SidePanel.Field>
              {hasPublishPeriod && (
                <FieldSet
                  legend="Publish period"
                  legendPlacement="none"
                  columns="1fr 1fr"
                >
                  <FormField label="From">
                    <DatePicker
                      width="100%"
                      value={new Date()}
                      size="small"
                      popoverProps={{ appendTo: 'window' }}
                    />
                  </FormField>
                  <FormField label="To">
                    <DatePicker
                      width="100%"
                      value={new Date()}
                      size="small"
                      popoverProps={{ appendTo: 'window' }}
                    />
                  </FormField>
                </FieldSet>
              )}
            </SidePanel.Field>
          </SidePanel.Section>
        </SidePanel.Content>
      </SidePanel>
    )
  }

  const renderCreateStep = () => (
    <>
      <ComposerSidebar labelPlacement="bottom" items={items} selectedId={2} />
      {renderBackgroundSidePanel()}

      <Box backgroundColor="D70" width="100%">
        <Box width="100%" padding={4}>
          <StorybookComponents.Placeholder>
            <Box verticalAlign="middle" align="center" height="100%">
              <Text>Composer content area</Text>
            </Box>
          </StorybookComponents.Placeholder>
        </Box>
      </Box>
    </>
  )

  return (
    <Layout gap={0}>
      <Cell>
        <ComposerHeader backButtonValue="Manage Album">
          <ComposerHeader.Actions justifyContent="end">
            <Button priority="secondary">Preview</Button>
            <Button>Publish</Button>
          </ComposerHeader.Actions>
        </ComposerHeader>
      </Cell>
      <Cell>
        <Box direction="vertical">
          <Box gap="0" height="800px">
            {renderCreateStep()}
          </Box>
        </Box>
      </Cell>
    </Layout>
  )
}

featureExamples.title: Structure
featureExamples.description:
A field set consists of legend, suffix and children areas.

Children and suffix areas can include any actions or form components.
featureExamples.example:
<FieldSet
  legend="Legend"
  suffix={
    <StorybookComponents.Placeholder>Suffix</StorybookComponents.Placeholder>
  }
>
  <StorybookComponents.Placeholder height="36px">
    Children
  </StorybookComponents.Placeholder>
</FieldSet>;

featureExamples.title: Legend placement
featureExamples.description:
Control the legend position with the legendPlacement. It supports 4 options:

  • For all common cases use top (default).
  • Use left or right to save vertical space in less spacious layouts. This only works well with short legends. When using, be mindful of localization.
  • Use none to visually hide the legend. It will still be available for screen readers.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <FieldSet legend="Top (default)">
    <StorybookComponents.Placeholder height="36px" />
    <StorybookComponents.Placeholder />
  </FieldSet>
  <FieldSet legend="Left" legendPlacement="left">
    <StorybookComponents.Placeholder height="36px" />
    <StorybookComponents.Placeholder />
  </FieldSet>
  <FieldSet legend="Right" legendPlacement="right">
    <StorybookComponents.Placeholder height="36px" />
    <StorybookComponents.Placeholder />
  </FieldSet>
  <FieldSet legend="Hidden legend" legendPlacement="none">
    <StorybookComponents.Placeholder height="36px" />
    <StorybookComponents.Placeholder />
  </FieldSet>
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Legend alignment
featureExamples.description:
When legend is placed on the side, its vertical position can be controlled with legendAlignment. It supports 2 options:

  • For all common cases use top (default).
  • Use middle for single line inputs.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <FieldSet legend="Top" legendAlignment="top" legendPlacement="left">
    <StorybookComponents.Placeholder height="60px" />
    <StorybookComponents.Placeholder />
  </FieldSet>
  <FieldSet legend="Middle" legendAlignment="middle" legendPlacement="left">
    <StorybookComponents.Placeholder height="60px" />
    <StorybookComponents.Placeholder />
  </FieldSet>
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Required
featureExamples.description: Mark mandatory field sets with an asterisk by using required.
featureExamples.example:
<FieldSet legend="Required" required>
  <StorybookComponents.Placeholder height="36px" />
  <StorybookComponents.Placeholder />
</FieldSet>;

featureExamples.title: Status and message
featureExamples.description:
To change the status and display a message below the field set, use status and statusMessage.

  • For an error message, set the status to error.
  • For a warning message, set the status to warning.
  • To show helper text, use the statusMessage with no status.

    • Note: to set the status and message for individual child components, use the same props within that component's FormField.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <FieldSet
    legend="Field set in error state"
    status="error"
    statusMessage="This is an error message."
  >
    <StorybookComponents.Placeholder height="36px" />
    <StorybookComponents.Placeholder />
  </FieldSet>

  <FieldSet
    legend="Field set in warning state"
    status="warning"
    statusMessage="This is a warning message."
  >
    <StorybookComponents.Placeholder height="36px" />
    <StorybookComponents.Placeholder />
  </FieldSet>

  <FieldSet
    legend="Field set in default state"
    statusMessage="This is helper text."
  >
    <StorybookComponents.Placeholder height="36px" />
    <StorybookComponents.Placeholder />
  </FieldSet>
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Additional info
featureExamples.description:
Use a tooltip to provide users with more information about the field set and what they need to input.

To add info icon content use infoContent.
featureExamples.example:
<FieldSet
  legend="Hover over info icon"
  infoContent="This tooltip provides additional info about what the user needs to put in the field set elements."
>
  <StorybookComponents.Placeholder height="36px" />
  <StorybookComponents.Placeholder />
</FieldSet>;

featureExamples.title: Suffix
featureExamples.description:
Add a custom element in the top-right corner of the field set to add extra actions or information. Any component can be used in this area.

Or use charCount to show how many characters are left in a text input.

Note: Choose either charCount or a custom element inside suffix; using both together is not possible.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <FieldSet
    legend="Custom suffix"
    suffix={
      <TextButton size="small" suffixIcon={<Icons.ExternalLinkSmall />}>
        Go to External Site
      </TextButton>
    }
  >
    <StorybookComponents.Placeholder height="36px" />
    <StorybookComponents.Placeholder />
  </FieldSet>
  <FieldSet legend="Character count in suffix" charCount={20}>
    <StorybookComponents.Placeholder height="36px" />
    <StorybookComponents.Placeholder />
  </FieldSet>
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Content direction
featureExamples.description:
Choose how child components are arranged in the field set:

  • horizontal (default) arranges them in a row.
  • vertical arranges them in a column.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">

    <StorybookComponents.Placeholder height="36px" width="120px" />

</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Content alignment
featureExamples.description:
Choose how child components are aligned using alignment.

In horizontal:

  • start (default) aligns to the top.
  • center aligns to the middle.
  • end to aligns to the bottom.

    • In vertical:

  • start (default) aligns to the left.
  • center aligns to the center.
  • end to aligns to the right.

    </FieldSet>

    <FieldSet legend="Center" columns="auto 120px" alignment="center">

      <StorybookComponents.Placeholder height="18px" />
    </FieldSet>
  </Cell>
  <Cell span={6}>
    <FieldSet legend="Center" direction="vertical" alignment="center">

      <StorybookComponents.Placeholder height="18px" width="120px" />
    </FieldSet>
  </Cell>{' '}
  <Cell span={6}>
    <FieldSet legend="End" columns="auto 120px" alignment="end">

developerExamples.title: Programatically controlled item
developerExamples.description: Control the selectable accordion items programatically using open prop.

content.description: Selectable accordion is a list of interactive items, which show and collapse additional content when they are selected and deselected.
do: Use it to organize complex settings by grouping them into collapsible sections.
Use it to show additional information or settings only when an item is selected.
dont: Don’t use it to display a single item. Use <Collapse/> mechanism instead.
Don’t use it for items that have no additional information to expand. Use <Checkbox/> or <ToggleSwitch/> instead.

commonUseCaseExamples.title: In long settings pages
commonUseCaseExamples.description:
A selectable accordion on a settings page helps save space and reduces mental load for the user.

This is because the UI displays only the settings that are relevant at a time.

featureExamples.title: Structure
featureExamples.description:
Selectable accordion consists of clickable items and their inner content, which is expanded when an item is selected.

Inner content areas accept any components inside.
featureExamples.example:
<SelectableAccordion
  type="toggle"
  items={[
    {
      title: 'First item',
      initiallyOpen: true,
      content: (
        <StorybookComponents.Placeholder>
          First item content
        </StorybookComponents.Placeholder>
      ),
    },
    {
      title: 'Second item',
      content: (
        <StorybookComponents.Placeholder>
          Second item content
        </StorybookComponents.Placeholder>
      ),
    },
  ]}
/>;

featureExamples.title: Type
featureExamples.description:
Change the type of items' controller with type prop. It supports 2 options:

  • checkbox - use when multiple items can be selected at once.
  • toggle - use when items (or features) are enabled / disabled.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <SelectableAccordion
    type="checkbox"
    items={[
      {
        title: 'Checkbox',
        content: (
          <StorybookComponents.Placeholder>
            Item content
          </StorybookComponents.Placeholder>
        ),
      },
      {
        title: 'Checkbox',
        content: (
          <StorybookComponents.Placeholder>
            Item content
          </StorybookComponents.Placeholder>
        ),
      },
    ]}
  />
  <SelectableAccordion
    type="toggle"
    items={[
      {
        title: 'Toggle',
        content: (
          <StorybookComponents.Placeholder>
            Item content
          </StorybookComponents.Placeholder>
        ),
      },
      {
        title: 'Toggle',
        content: (
          <StorybookComponents.Placeholder>
            Item content
          </StorybookComponents.Placeholder>
        ),
      },
    ]}
  />
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Vertical padding
featureExamples.description:
Control vertical padding of selectable accordion items with verticalPadding prop:

  • medium is a larger padding that emphasizes a few items.
  • small (default) is a standard padding for common cases.
  • tiny is a compact padding that displays more items in a smaller space.

    • Note that verticalPadding prop only controls the padding of selectable accordion items (and not their inner content).

        content: (
          <StorybookComponents.Placeholder>
            Item content
          </StorybookComponents.Placeholder>

  <SelectableAccordion
    verticalPadding="small"
    type="toggle"
    items={[
      {
        title: 'Small',

          </StorybookComponents.Placeholder>

  <SelectableAccordion
    verticalPadding="tiny"
    type="toggle"
    items={[

        title: 'Tiny',
        content: (
          <StorybookComponents.Placeholder>
            Item content
          </StorybookComponents.Placeholder>
        ),

      {
        title: 'Tiny',
        content: (
          <StorybookComponents.Placeholder>

          </StorybookComponents.Placeholder>

content.demo:
<Box align="center">
  <EditableTitle
    defaultValue="Write your own title"
    initialValue="Write your own title"
  />
</Box>;
content.description: Editable title allows users to change a page title on the spot. It is used as a title inside of a <Page.Header/> component.
do: Use it to let users give a title for a page (e.g., for a product, category or event detail page).
Use it as a part of a <PageHeader/>.
dont: Don’t use it for static page titles that cannot be edited (e.g., Inventory, Settings, Subscriptions).
Don’t use it outside of a <PageHeader/> component.
Don’t use it as an editable cell or title inside forms or tables. Use <Input/> with a 'bottomBorder' border type instead.

commonUseCaseExamples.title: Giving a name for a newly created item
commonUseCaseExamples.description:
Use Editable title in the <Page.Header/> when users create a new item with no default name (e.g., a product for the Store).

Editable title can work in sync with Form components (e.g., writing 'Green Shoes' in the 'Name' field will automatically change the page title, too).
commonUseCaseExamples.example:
() => {
  const [productName, setProductName] = React.useState('');

  return (
    <Page height="60vh">
      <Page.Header
        title=<EditableTitle
          defaultValue="Untitled Product"
          value={productName}
        />
        actionsBar={
          <Box gap="SP2">
            <Button skin="inverted">Cancel</Button>
            <Button>Save</Button>
          </Box>
        }
        breadcrumbs={
          <Breadcrumbs
            activeId="2"
            items={[
              { id: '1', value: 'Products' },
              { id: '2', value: 'Untitled Product' },
            ]}
          />
        }
      />
      <Page.Content>
        <Layout>
          <Cell span={8}>
            <Card>
              <Card.Header title="Product info" />
              <Card.Divider />
              <Card.Content>
                <Layout>
                  <Cell span={6}>
                    <FormField label="Name">
                      <Input
                        value={productName}
                        onChange={(e) => setProductName(e.target.value)}
                        placeholder="Add a product name"
                      />
                    </FormField>
                  </Cell>
                  <Cell span={6}>
                    <FormField label="Price">
                      <Input prefix={<Input.Affix>$</Input.Affix>} />
                    </FormField>
                  </Cell>
                  <Cell span={12}>
                    <FormField label="Description">
                      <RichTextInputArea minHeight="114px" maxHeight="114px" />
                    </FormField>
                  </Cell>
                </Layout>
              </Card.Content>
            </Card>
          </Cell>
        </Layout>
      </Page.Content>
    </Page>
  );
};

featureExamples.title: Max length
featureExamples.description:
Define a max number of characters that users can write in the title with maxLength prop.

maxLength includes spaces and has no default value.
featureExamples.example: <EditableTitle initialValue="I can only write 24 char" maxLength={24} />;

featureExamples.title: Auto focus
featureExamples.description: Make the component ready to type in as soon as it is rendered (on mount) with autoFocus prop.
featureExamples.example: <EditableTitle initialValue="Start writing now" autoFocus />;

featureExamples.title: Value
featureExamples.description:
Control title text value with these props:

  • defaultValue - use it to display a placeholder text. It will become a title if users do not change it.
  • initialValue - use it to suggest a fitting opening title for users. They can delete and change it themselves.
  • value - use it to specify the current value of the title.

    • Note that when users delete the initialValue, defaultValue is still shown.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <EditableTitle defaultValue="Default Value" />
  <EditableTitle initialValue="Initial Value" />
  <EditableTitle value="value" />
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

content.demo:
<Box align="center">
  <Stepper
    activeStep={1}
    steps={[
      { text: 'Set Title', type: 'completed' },
      { text: 'Add Description' },
      { text: 'Update Image', type: 'disabled' },
    ]}
  />

content.description: Stepper displays the path a user needs to follow to complete a process.
do: Use it to divide a complex form or a process into a sequence of steps.
Use it to let users navigate across different steps.
dont: Don’t use it to display users’ location on a website. Use <Breadcrumbs/> instead.
Don’t use it to split up large amounts of data into multiple pages. Use <Pagination/> instead.
Don’t use it for static progress indication. Use <LinearProgressBar/> instead.

commonUseCaseExamples.title: Multi-step flow
commonUseCaseExamples.description:
Split a long form into steps and demonstrate the user’s progress.

Use linear or nonlinear Stepper logic for navigation based on your form content:

  • In linear logic, users cannot go back to previous steps or check future steps. Disable steps that they cannot navigate to.
  • In nonlinear logic, users can freely move across all steps.
commonUseCaseExamples.example:
() => {
  const [activeStep, setActiveStep] = React.useState(0);

  return (
    <CustomModalLayout
      title="Create your loyalty program"
      showFooterDivider
      showHeaderDivider
      primaryButtonText="Next"
      secondaryButtonText="Cancel"
    >
      <Layout>
        <Cell span={12}>
          <Stepper
            activeStep={0}
            onClick={(step) => setActiveStep(step)}
            steps={[
              { text: 'Brand your program' },
              { text: 'Set points' },
              { text: 'Set rewards', type: 'disabled' },
              { text: 'Add description', type: 'disabled' },
            ]}
          />
        </Cell>
        <Cell span={12}>
          <Divider />
        </Cell>
        <Cell span={6}>
          <FormField labelSize="small" label="Program name">
            <Input placeholder="" />
          </FormField>
        </Cell>
        <Cell span={6}>
          <FormField labelSize="small" label="Points name">
            <Input placeholder="" />
          </FormField>
        </Cell>
        <Cell span={6}>
          <FormField labelSize="small" label="Short description">
            <InputArea
              placeholder="Add more details about your program"
              rows={3}
              hasCounter
              resizable
            />
          </FormField>
        </Cell>
        <Cell span={6}>
          <Box width="72px">
            <FormField labelSize="small" label="Points icon">
              <AddItem theme="image" tooltipContent="Pick points icon">
                Add Item
              </AddItem>
            </FormField>
          </Box>
        </Cell>
      </Layout>
    </CustomModalLayout>
  );
};

commonUseCaseExamples.title: Composers
commonUseCaseExamples.description: Use stepper in composer header to split a complex flow into smaller steps.

featureExamples.title: Type
featureExamples.description:
Control stepper appearance with type prop:

  • Use circle (default) in all common cases.
  • Use text in dense layouts.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <Stepper
    type="circle"
    steps={[{ text: 'Circle' }, { text: 'Circle' }, { text: 'Circle' }]}
  />
  <Stepper
    type="text"
    steps={[{ text: 'Text' }, { text: 'Text' }, { text: 'Text' }]}
  />
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Fit mode
featureExamples.description:
Control how component fits in the parent container with fit prop:

  • Use compact (default) to set the stepper width based on its content.
  • Use stretched to fill in all available space.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <Stepper
    fit="compact"
    steps={[{ text: 'Compact' }, { text: 'Compact' }, { text: 'Compact' }]}
  />
  <Stepper
    fit="stretched"
    steps={[
      { text: 'Stretched' },
      { text: 'Stretched' },
      { text: 'Stretched' },
    ]}
  />
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: States
featureExamples.description:
Control the state of each step individually with type prop:

  • Use normal (default) for non completed steps.
  • Use completed for previously completed steps.
  • Use error for steps with incomplete information or other issues.
  • Use disabled to indicate that step cannot be interacted with at a given moment.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <Stepper
    steps={[
      { text: 'Normal', type: 'normal' },
      { text: 'Completed', type: 'completed' },
      { text: 'Error', type: 'error' },
      { text: 'Disabled', type: 'disabled' },
    ]}
  />
  <Stepper
    type="text"
    steps={[
      { text: 'Normal', type: 'normal' },
      { text: 'Completed', type: 'completed' },
      { text: 'Error', type: 'error' },
      { text: 'Disabled', type: 'disabled' },
    ]}
  />
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

content.description: A status indicator highlights the status of UI elements with an explanatory message that’s displayed in a tooltip. It’s an internal component of various form inputs.
do: Use it to provide information about component status in compact layouts, where providing it below the component is not possible.
dont: Don't use it as a standalone item to indicate loading for lists or layouts. Use <Loader/> instead.

commonUseCaseExamples.title: Built-in part of form elements
commonUseCaseExamples.description:
A status indicator is used as a building block for a variety of form components that require validation or data processing. Avoid using these indicators for status messages unless absolutely necessary, like for very compact layouts.

Showing the status message directly below the component is preferred in all default cases. For this, use <FormField/> prop statusMessage.
commonUseCaseExamples.example:
<Layout gap="48px">
  <Cell span={4}>
    <Box direction="vertical" gap="12px">
      <Heading size="tiny">For narrow layouts only:</Heading>
      <Box direction="vertical" gap="40px">
        <FormField label="Product name">
          <Input status="error" statusMessage="This field is mandatory" />
        </FormField>
        <FormField label="Select color">
          <AutoComplete
            status="warning"
            value="Green"
            statusMessage="This color already exists"
          />
        </FormField>
      </Box>
    </Box>
  </Cell>
  <Cell span={8}>
    <Box direction="vertical" gap="12px">
      <Heading size="tiny">For all default cases:</Heading>
      <FormField
        label="Product name"
        status="error"
        statusMessage="This field is mandatory"
      >
        <Input />
      </FormField>
      <FormField
        label="Select color"
        status="warning"
        statusMessage="This color already exists"
      >
        <AutoComplete value="Green" />
      </FormField>
    </Box>
  </Cell>
</Layout>;

featureExamples.title: Status
featureExamples.description:
Control the indication type with the status prop:

  • error - use it to highlight invalid values, failed actions and processes.
  • warning - use it to highlight areas that require extra attention, like if a password has been compromised.
  • success - use it to highlight valid values, successful actions or processes.
  • loading - use it to show that an input value is being loaded.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <StorybookComponents.Stack alignItems="center">
    <StatusIndicator status="error" />
    <Text>Error</Text>
  </StorybookComponents.Stack>
  <StorybookComponents.Stack alignItems="center">
    <StatusIndicator status="warning" />
    <Text>Warning</Text>
  </StorybookComponents.Stack>
    <StorybookComponents.Stack>
    <StatusIndicator status="success" />
    <Text>Success</Text>
  </StorybookComponents.Stack>
  <StorybookComponents.Stack>
    <StatusIndicator status="loading" />
    <Text>Loading</Text>
  </StorybookComponents.Stack>
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Message
featureExamples.description:
Explain the status with a message prop.

The message is revealed in a tooltip when the users’ mouse hovers over the status icon.
featureExamples.example: <StatusIndicator message="Message in a tooltip explains the status" />;

featureExamples.title: Tooltip placement
featureExamples.description:
Position the tooltip with the tooltipPlacement prop:

  • top (default)
  • right
  • bottom
  • left
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack alignItems="center">
  <Text>Top:</Text>
  <StatusIndicator message="Top" tooltipPlacement="top" />
  <Text>Left:</Text>
  <StatusIndicator message="Left" tooltipPlacement="left" />
  <Text>Bottom:</Text>
  <StatusIndicator message="Bottom" tooltipPlacement="bottom" />
  <Text>Right:</Text>
  <StatusIndicator message="Right" tooltipPlacement="right" />
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Size
featureExamples.description:
Control the size of a component with size prop:

  • large - use when item height is >212 px.
  • medium - use when item height is between 162 px and 212 px.
  • small - use when item height is between 120 px and 162 px.
  • tiny (default) - use when item height is between 48 px and 120 px.

    • size prop affects component's padding and icon size. Its height and width also depend on a parent container.

    Minimum height of a component is:

  • 48 px for dashes,
  • 42 px for plain, and
  • 81×81 px for image themes.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <AddItem size="large">Large</AddItem>
  <AddItem size="medium">Medium</AddItem>
  <AddItem size="small">Small</AddItem>
  <AddItem size="tiny">Tiny</AddItem>
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Theme
featureExamples.description:
Control the style of a component with theme prop:

  • dashes (default) - use it outside of a card, in a table or a list that contains images.
  • plain - use for in-card lists and tables that mainly consist of text.
  • filled - use for small in-card items, when a prominent call to action is needed.
  • image - use to add images inside a card.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <AddItem theme="dashes">Dashes</AddItem>
  <AddItem theme="plain">Plain</AddItem>
  <AddItem theme="filled">Filled</AddItem>
  <AddItem theme="image">Image</AddItem>
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Alignment
featureExamples.description:
Control content alignment with alignItems prop:

  • left
  • center (default)
  • right

    • Use left alignment with a plain component theme to maintain visual consistency with a remaining list inside a card.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <AddItem theme="plain" alignItems="left">
    Left
  </AddItem>
  <AddItem theme="plain" alignItems="center">
    Center
  </AddItem>
  <AddItem theme="plain" alignItems="right">
    Right
  </AddItem>
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Padding
featureExamples.description:
Control whether a component has padding with removePadding prop.

Use it in special cases only, when component is used in dense and narrow layouts.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <AddItem>Default</AddItem>
  <AddItem removePadding>No padding</AddItem>
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Border radius
featureExamples.description:
Control the border radius of a component with borderRadius prop.

By default, component has a corner radius of 8 px. Change it in custom scenarios, for example, when user needs to add a round avatar photo.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack width="min-content" height="100px">
  <AddItem borderRadius="8px" />
  <AddItem borderRadius="100%" />
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Title
featureExamples.description:
Emphasize action with a title.

If no title is shown, display it in a tooltip on item hover with tooltipContent prop.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <AddItem>Title</AddItem>
  <AddItem tooltipContent="Title"></AddItem>
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Subtitle
featureExamples.description:
Add a description below the title using subtitle prop.

Use it to explain item details, such as a supported file format of a maximum allowed file size.
featureExamples.example: <AddItem subtitle="Subtitle">Title</AddItem>;

featureExamples.title: Icon
featureExamples.description: Control a '+' icon visibility with showIcon prop. The icon is always shown by default.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <AddItem>Default</AddItem>
  <AddItem showIcon={false}>No icon</AddItem>
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Custom icon or illustration
featureExamples.description:
Override a default '+' icon with a custom icon or illustration by passing it to icon prop.

Align dimensions of the icon or illustration based on add item size:

  • Use S2 illustrations in large and medium size components.
  • Use S1 for small size component.
  • Use 24×24 px or 18×18 px icons for tiny size component.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack width="50%" flexDirection="column">
  <Box height="212px">
    <AddItem
      size="large"
      icon={
        <StorybookComponents.Placeholder width="96px" height="96px">
          <StorybookComponents.Stack
            justifyContent="center"
            height="100%"
            alignItems="center"
          >
            <Text weight="bold" secondary>
              S2
            </Text>
          </StorybookComponents.Stack>
        </StorybookComponents.Placeholder>
      }
    >
      Large
    </AddItem>
  </Box>
  <Box height="162px">
    <AddItem
      size="medium"
      icon={
        <StorybookComponents.Placeholder width="96px" height="96px">
          <StorybookComponents.Stack
            justifyContent="center"
            height="100%"
            alignItems="center"
          >
            <Text weight="bold" secondary>
              S2
            </Text>
          </StorybookComponents.Stack>
        </StorybookComponents.Placeholder>
      }
    >
      Medium
    </AddItem>
  </Box>
  <Box height="120px">
    <AddItem
      size="small"
      icon={
        <StorybookComponents.Placeholder width="60px" height="60px">
          <StorybookComponents.Stack
            justifyContent="center"
            height="100%"
            alignItems="center"
          >
            <Text weight="bold" secondary>
              S1
            </Text>
          </StorybookComponents.Stack>
        </StorybookComponents.Placeholder>
      }
    >
      Small
    </AddItem>
  </Box>
  <Box>
    <AddItem size="tiny" icon={<Icons.Image />}>
      Tiny
    </AddItem>
  </Box>
  <Box>
    <AddItem size="tiny" icon={<Icons.ImageSmall />}>
      Tiny with small icon
    </AddItem>
  </Box>
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Disabled
featureExamples.description: Disable all component interactions with disabled prop. Use it to show that no new item can be added to the list at a moment.
featureExamples.example: <AddItem disabled>Disabled</AddItem>;

featureExamples.title: Tooltip
featureExamples.description:
Describe add item action with tooltipContent. Tooltip is shown when users hover on the item with a mouse.

Control tooltip design with tooltipProps.

<AddItem
  tooltipContent="Description for the add item action"
  tooltipProps={{ placement: 'bottom' }}
>
  Hover to see tooltip
</AddItem>;

developerExamples.title: Using item builders
developerExamples.description:
Accordion is composed from a list of items that share expand/collapse feature. To create them in the most efficient way, use accordionItemBuilder.

Note: presenting accordion items as plain objects is still available as a legacy pattern, but it shouldn't be used in any new projects.

          </Box>
        </StorybookComponents.Placeholder>

      title: 'Second item',
      children: (
        <StorybookComponents.Placeholder>

developerExamples.title: Controlled
developerExamples.description: Component can be used in controlled mode by passing open and onToggle props to accordionItemBuilder.

content.description: Accordion is a list of items that shows and hides content in collapsible sections.
do: Use it to organize content by grouping it into collapsible sections.
Use it to show information on user demand only.
dont: Don't use when content is crucial to read in full. Use <Card/> with section titles instead.

commonUseCaseExamples.title: In a side panel
commonUseCaseExamples.description:
Accordion in a side panel allows for efficient use of space.

Allow to open only one accordion item at a time. This will minimise the cognitive load and scrolling required by the user.

commonUseCaseExamples.title: In FAQs
commonUseCaseExamples.description: Use accordion in FAQs or similar content-heavy sections. It improves scanning and navigation across related content sections.
commonUseCaseExamples.example:
<Layout>
  <Cell span={12}>
    <Card hideOverflow>
      <Card.Header title="FAQ"></Card.Header>
      <Card.Divider />
      <Accordion
        size="tiny"
        skin="light"
        hideShadow
        items={[
          accordionItemBuilder({
            title: (
              <Text size="small" weight="normal">
                What are Core Web Vitals?
              </Text>
            ),
            children: (
              <Box direction="vertical" width="100%" gap="SP1">
                <Text size="small" secondary>
                  Core Web Vitals are three performance factors Google takes
                  into account for SEO ranking: Largest Contentful Paint,
                  Cumulative Layout Shift, and First Input Delay. When measured
                  in a lab, they don’t affect your SEO directly.
                </Text>
                <TextButton
                  size="small"
                  suffixIcon={<Icons.ExternalLinkSmall />}
                  underline="onHover"
                >
                  Learn more about Core Web Vitals
                </TextButton>
              </Box>
            ),
          }),
          accordionItemBuilder({
            title: (
              <Text size="small" weight="normal">
                Why are my scores different for desktop and mobile?
              </Text>
            ),
            children: (
              <Box direction="vertical" width="100%" gap="SP1">
                <Text size="small" secondary>
                  PageSpeed scores for mobile are often lower than for desktop.
                  That’s because mobile devices have slower processors and take
                  more time to resize texts and images. Lab settings are another
                  reason: Google’s mobile test is on a simulated 3G connection,
                  which is different from the 4G and Wifi connections most
                  visitors use to access your site.
                </Text>
                <TextButton
                  size="small"
                  suffixIcon={<Icons.ExternalLinkSmall />}
                  underline="onHover"
                >
                  Learn more about scores
                </TextButton>
              </Box>
            ),
          }),
          accordionItemBuilder({
            title: (
              <Text size="small" weight="normal">
                Why is Google’s simulation different from real visitor
                experience?
              </Text>
            ),
            children: (
              <Text size="small" secondary>
                The measurements above are based on the experience of people who
                have actually visited your site over the last 30 day period.
                What Google does is check your site’s average metrics in lab
                conditions, using a very basic network and device. This means
                Google’s estimate is probably different from what your actual
                site visitors experience.
              </Text>
            ),
          }),
          accordionItemBuilder({
            title: (
              <Text size="small" weight="normal">
                Why does my score change from one test to another?
              </Text>
            ),
            children: (
              <Box direction="vertical" width="100%" gap="SP1">
                <Text size="small" secondary>
                  This can be due to a number of factors, including local
                  networks and CPU load at the time of the test, as well as
                  changes to your site's home page. In most cases, changes to
                  the score are minimal.
                </Text>
                <TextButton
                  size="small"
                  suffixIcon={<Icons.ExternalLinkSmall />}
                  underline="onHover"
                >
                  Learn more about scores
                </TextButton>
              </Box>
            ),
          }),
          accordionItemBuilder({
            title: (
              <Text size="small" weight="normal">
                Does my PageSpeed score affect my SEO ranking?
              </Text>
            ),
            children: (
              <Box direction="vertical" width="100%" gap="SP1">
                <Text size="small" secondary>
                  Not exactly. Even though site speed is one of the many factors
                  affecting your SEO ranking, only data collected from real user
                  sessions counts. The PageSpeed score you see here is based on
                  a lab test and doesn’t affect your site’s SEO directly.
                </Text>
                <TextButton
                  size="small"
                  suffixIcon={<Icons.ExternalLinkSmall />}
                  underline="onHover"
                >
                  Learn more about SEO ranking
                </TextButton>
              </Box>
            ),
          }),
        ]}
      />
    </Card>
  </Cell>
</Layout>;

featureExamples.title: Horizontal padding
featureExamples.description:
Control horizontal padding of accordion items and their inner content with horizontalPadding prop:

  • large (default) is a standard size for common cases.
  • medium is a more compact size.
  • small and tiny are the most compact sizes used to display more content in narrow spaces.

developerExamples.title: Custom HTML tag
developerExamples.description:
Render toggle button as any given HTML tag with as prop. For example, it can be rendered as:

  • <a> when attributes like href, target, etc., are needed.
  • <Link> when props like to, replace, etc. are needed.

    • All attributes will be passed to the rendered HTML tag.
developerExamples.example:
() => {
  const ReactRouterLink = (props) => <div {...props} />;
  return (
    <StorybookComponents.Stack>
      <ToggleButton
        as="a"
        href="https://www.wix.com"
        target="_blank"
        labelValue="Native <a/> tag"
        labelPlacement="bottom"
      >
        <Icons.CropRotate />
      </ToggleButton>

      <ToggleButton
        as={ReactRouterLink}
        to="/home"
        labelValue="React Router <Link/> tag"
        labelPlacement="bottom"
      >
        <Icons.CropRotate />
      </ToggleButton>

      <ToggleButton
        as="button"
        onClick={() => alert('You have clicked on a button!')}
        labelValue="Native <button/> tag"
        labelPlacement="bottom"
      >
        <Icons.CropRotate />
      </ToggleButton>
    </StorybookComponents.Stack>
  );
};

content.description: Toggle button allows users to switch between states or trigger actions through clicking or selection, and is commonly used in toolbars.
do: Use it to build composer actions like Undo and Redo.
Use it in toolbars for actions like bolding or aligning text.
Use it as a tab to navigate in a composer interface.
Use it in main layouts to enable users to switch between two states.
dont: Don’t use it for regular form actions like Save or Cancel. Use <Button/> instead.
Don't use it to turn settings on/off. Use <ToggleSwitch/> instead.

commonUseCaseExamples.title: Composer interface
commonUseCaseExamples.description:
Toggle button is one of the main components used in Wix composers. Use it in:

  • <ComposerHeader/> for Undo and Redo actions.
  • <ComposerSidebar/> as built-in button for navigation.
  • Any other toolbar to show actions or select states.

commonUseCaseExamples.title: Video stream
commonUseCaseExamples.description: Use toggle buttons in control toolbars to enable/disable actions like screen sharing.

commonUseCaseExamples.title: Switch between states
commonUseCaseExamples.description: Use toggle buttons as selectors that switch between two states.

featureExamples.title: Size
featureExamples.description:
Control toggle button size with size prop:

  • large is best for main actions in a composer.
  • medium (default) is for main composer toolbars.
  • small fits into smaller toolbars and UI elements like cards and widgets.
  • tiny is used in dense layouts.

featureExamples.title: Label placement
featureExamples.description:

  • tooltip (default) - use it in dense layouts and for repetitive intuitive actions that don't need the exposed label, such as making text italic.
  • end saves vertical space.
  • bottom saves horizontal space.

featureExamples.title: Skin
featureExamples.description:
Control the appearance of a button with skin prop:

  • standard (default) is used it in all default cases.
  • inverted is used when selected actions need additional emphasis.
  • destructive is best for actions that might have a negative effect, for example, when the microphone is muted.
  • success is best for actions that have a positive effect, for example when camera is on or screen is shared.
  • dark is used on colored backgrounds.

    • Note: by design, different skins are only visible when toggle buttons are selected.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack>
  <ToggleButton labelValue="Standard" skin="standard" selected>
    <Icons.CropRotate />
  </ToggleButton>
  <ToggleButton labelValue="Inverted" skin="inverted" selected>
    <Icons.CropRotate />
  </ToggleButton>
  <ToggleButton labelValue="Destructive" skin="destructive" selected>
    <Icons.CropRotate />
  </ToggleButton>
  <ToggleButton labelValue="Success" skin="success" selected>
    <Icons.CropRotate />
  </ToggleButton>
  <ToggleButton labelValue="Dark" skin="dark" selected>
    <Icons.CropRotate />
  </ToggleButton>
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Shape
featureExamples.description:
Control toggle button form with shape prop:

  • square (default) is best for composer toolbars and top bars.
  • round is built in composer sidebars.
  • pill is for main page layouts.

content.description: Composer header is a local navigation of a composer environment.
do: Use it to navigate within a composer.
Use it to display actions and data related to the composer environment, such as content state, undo actions, etc.
dont: Don’t use it in layouts other than the composer.
Don’t use it as a global navigation (top bar). Composer header exists together with global navigation and should be positioned right below it.

commonUseCaseExamples.title: Composer
commonUseCaseExamples.description: Include a Composer header on top of the composer environment.

commonUseCaseExamples.title: Multiple Steps
commonUseCaseExamples.description:
Allow users to break the creation process into multiple steps by placing `` inside the Composer header.

Use `` container to store it.

featureExamples.title: Structure
featureExamples.description:
Composer header consists of 3 areas:
 - Back button on the left.
 - Additional actions container in the center.
 - Main actions container on the right.

There can be multiple containers with Additional actions in the middle. Available space will be evenly divided among them.

Note that all areas are optional.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <ComposerHeader backButtonValue="Back button">
    <ComposerHeader.Actions>
      <StorybookComponents.Placeholder height="35px">
        Additional actions
      </StorybookComponents.Placeholder>
    </ComposerHeader.Actions>
    <ComposerHeader.MainActions>
      <StorybookComponents.Placeholder height="35px">
        Main actions
      </StorybookComponents.Placeholder>
    </ComposerHeader.MainActions>
  </ComposerHeader>
  <ComposerHeader backButtonValue="Back button">
    <ComposerHeader.Actions justifyContent="flex-start">
      <StorybookComponents.Placeholder height="35px">
        Additional actions (1)
      </StorybookComponents.Placeholder>
    </ComposerHeader.Actions>
    <ComposerHeader.Actions justifyContent="flex-end">
      <StorybookComponents.Placeholder height="35px">
        Additional actions (2)
      </StorybookComponents.Placeholder>
    </ComposerHeader.Actions>
    <ComposerHeader.MainActions>
      <StorybookComponents.Placeholder height="35px">
        Main actions
      </StorybookComponents.Placeholder>
    </ComposerHeader.MainActions>
  </ComposerHeader>
</StorybookComponents.Stack>

featureExamples.title: Size
featureExamples.description:
Control component height and back button size with `size` prop:
 - `medium` (default) - use it in all common cases. Height is fixed at 66 px.
 - `small` - use it to maximise space for the content area. Height is fixed at 54 px.

Note that the size for child items in ``, ``, and `` containers will have to be adjusted manually.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection='column'>
  <ComposerHeader backButtonValue="Medium Size">
    <ComposerHeader.Actions justifyContent="flex-end">
      <ComposerHeader.SaveStatus saveStatusValue="Medium size..." />
    </ComposerHeader.Actions>
    <ComposerHeader.MainActions>
      <Button skin="inverted">Medium</Button>
      <Button>Medium</Button>
    </ComposerHeader.MainActions>
  </ComposerHeader>
  <ComposerHeader size="small" backButtonValue="Small Size">
    <ComposerHeader.Actions justifyContent="flex-end">
      <ComposerHeader.SaveStatus size="small" saveStatusValue="Small size..."/>
    </ComposerHeader.Actions>
    <ComposerHeader.MainActions>
      <Button size="small" skin="inverted">Small</Button>
      <Button size="small">Small</Button>
    </ComposerHeader.MainActions>
  </ComposerHeader>
</StorybookComponents.Stack>

featureExamples.title: Shadow

featureExamples.title: Back Button
featureExamples.description:
Add a back button by specifying its label with `backButtonValue` prop.

Button is added to the left side of a Composer header. Its position cannot be changed.
featureExamples.example: <ComposerHeader backButtonValue="Back to Posts" />

featureExamples.title: Main Actions
featureExamples.description:
Add main actions as children items to `` container on the right side of the Composer header. Container position is fixed and cannot be changed.

In all common cases, use `
featureExamples.example:

featureExamples.title: Additional Actions
featureExamples.description:
Add secondary actions or content to <ComposerHeader.Actions/> container in the middle of the Composer header.

Use justifyContent prop to distribute content inside the container. It accepts 3 values:

  • flex-start (default) - aligns items to the left.
  • center - centers items within the container.
  • flex-end - aligns items to the right.

    • Vertical dividers will be added automatically to separate primary and secondary actions.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="Column">
  <ComposerHeader backButtonValue="Back to Posts">
    <ComposerHeader.Actions justifyContent="flex-end">
      <ToggleButton labelValue="Undo">
        <Icons.Undo />
      </ToggleButton>
      <ToggleButton labelValue="Redo">
        <Icons.Redo />
      </ToggleButton>
    </ComposerHeader.Actions>
    <ComposerHeader.MainActions>
      <Button skin="inverted">Preview</Button>
      <Button>Publish</Button>
    </ComposerHeader.MainActions>
  </ComposerHeader>
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Save Status
featureExamples.description:
Add a save status to the Composer header with a compound `` component. Include it in the additional actions container, justified to the end.

Set save status label with `saveStatusValue` prop.

Change its status to error with `saveStatusError` prop.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="Column">
  <ComposerHeader backButtonValue="Back to Posts">
    <ComposerHeader.Actions justifyContent="flex-end">
      <ComposerHeader.SaveStatus saveStatusValue="Saving..." />
    </ComposerHeader.Actions>
    <ComposerHeader.MainActions>
      <Button skin="inverted">Preview</Button>
      <Button>Publish</Button>
    </ComposerHeader.MainActions>
  </ComposerHeader>
  <ComposerHeader backButtonValue="Back to Posts">
    <ComposerHeader.Actions justifyContent="flex-end">
      <ComposerHeader.SaveStatus
        saveStatusValue="Draft not saved"
        saveStatusError
      />
    </ComposerHeader.Actions>
    <ComposerHeader.MainActions>
      <Button skin="inverted">Preview</Button>
      <Button>Publish</Button>
    </ComposerHeader.MainActions>
  </ComposerHeader>
</StorybookComponents.Stack>

content.description: Section helper is a notification message that allows us to communicate with users and provide feedback anywhere on the page.
do: Use it to provide information about application status, for example to inform about the expired payment method.
Use it to share the status of application sections, for example to inform that settings are turned on the way users might not see a benefit.
dont: Don’t use it for status updates after users perform actions like validation errors and success messages. Use <StatusToast/> instead.

commonUseCaseExamples.title: Application error
commonUseCaseExamples.description:
Errors occur because of breaches in application logic or conditions, for example when users reach storage limits or their payment method has expired. These errors can occur before users even open the application or a specific page, making it essential for them to be visible upon arrival.

Place application errors first in the page, below the page header using the error banner.

featureExamples.title: Structure
featureExamples.description:
The component consists of 4 majors elements: title, children, action and close button.

Control action label with actionText and its interaction with onAction props, close button with onClose prop.
featureExamples.example:
<SectionHelper title="Title" actionText="Action" onAction={() => {}} onClose={() => {}}>
  Content
</SectionHelper>

featureExamples.title: Size
featureExamples.description:
Adjust Section helper size by using the size prop:

  • medium (default) - can be used in all common cases.
  • small - best for dense layouts.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <SectionHelper size="medium">Medium </SectionHelper>
  <SectionHelper size="small">Small </SectionHelper>
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Skin
featureExamples.description:
Control the style of the Section helper with the appearance prop. It supports 7 options:

  • standard - use it to provide additional information relevant to current user task.
  • success - use it to inform users about successful operation.
  • warning (default) - use it to draw the user's attention to unresolved issues.
  • danger - use it for error messages and information about critical issues.
  • premium - use it for premium upgrades only — packages that let accept payments, connect domain and have business email. Read more about Premium patterns.
  • preview - use it to present process status or related additional data.
  • experimentalDark - use it to emphasize informational messages in the context of other content.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <SectionHelper appearance="standard">Standard </SectionHelper>
  <SectionHelper appearance="success">Success </SectionHelper>
  <SectionHelper appearance="warning">Warning </SectionHelper>
  <SectionHelper appearance="danger">Danger </SectionHelper>
  <SectionHelper appearance="premium">Premium</SectionHelper>
  <SectionHelper appearance="preview">Preview </SectionHelper>
  <SectionHelper appearance="experimentalDark">Dark </SectionHelper>
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Prefix
featureExamples.description:
• Use showPrefixIcon prop to show default status icon.

 </SectionHelper>

featureExamples.title: Layout

  • horizontal arranges content vertically.

content.description: Address input allows users to enter a location address. This component provides UI definition only and requires an address provider to be specified from the product side.
do: Use it to search for a location.
Use it to enter addresses that must be validated before they are submitted.
Use it as a UI element together with a required address provider passed from the side.
dont: Don’t use it as a standalone solution. Use <AtlasAddressInput/> instead.

commonUseCaseExamples.title: Custom options list
commonUseCaseExamples.description: Use list item builders to build a custom options list layout.

featureExamples.title: Size
featureExamples.description:
Adjust the component size using size prop. It supports 3 sizes:

  • large - use it in onboarding flows, where input needs emphasis.
  • medium (default) - use in all common cases.
  • small - use in dense and narrow layouts.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <AddressInput placeholder="Large" size="large" />
  <AddressInput placeholder="Medium" size="medium" />
  <AddressInput placeholder="Small" size="small" />
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Border
featureExamples.description:
Style the component using border prop. It supports 4 styles:

  • round (default) - use it when input acts as a data filter.
  • standard - use it in forms.
  • bottomLine - use as a title which can be edited on the click.
  • none - use in Content Manager's spreadsheet cell.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <AddressInput placeholder="Round" border="round" />
  <AddressInput placeholder="Standard" border="standard" />
  <AddressInput placeholder="Bottom Line" border="bottomLine" />
  <AddressInput placeholder="None" border="none" />
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Status
featureExamples.description:
Control component status using status prop. It supports 3 states:

  • error - use it to highlight an invalid input value.
  • warning - use it to highlight a value that can’t be validated.
  • loading - use it to indicate a delayed response from the server.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <AddressInput placeholder="Error" status="error" />
  <AddressInput placeholder="Warning" status="warning" />
  <AddressInput placeholder="Loading" status="loading" />
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Status message
featureExamples.description:
Add text that explains the status or what action the user should take with the statusMessage prop.

Showing the status message inline, directly below the input is preferred in all default cases.

  • To add an accessible inline message, wrap the component in a <FormField/> and add the statusMessage.
  • To add a status message in a tooltip that requires users to hover on the icon, use the statusMessage prop.

    • View more inline status message examples in <FormField/>.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column" gap="12px">
    <Text secondary>For all default cases:</Text>
    <FormField status="error" statusMessage="This is an error message.">
      <AddressInput placeholder="See message below" />
    </FormField>
  </StorybookComponents.Stack>
  <StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column" gap="12px">
    <Text secondary>For narrow layouts only:</Text>
    <AddressInput
      placeholder="Hover on status icon"
      status="error"
      statusMessage="This is an error message."
    />
  </StorybookComponents.Stack>
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Disabled
featureExamples.description: Disable all input interactions with disabled prop. Use it to highlight unavailable functions.
featureExamples.example: <AddressInput placeholder="Disabled" disabled />;

featureExamples.title: Clear button
featureExamples.description: Control whether to show a clear button with the clearButton prop. It allows to clear the field quickly when a value is optional.

featureExamples.title: No results message
featureExamples.description: Control the message displayed in the dropdown layout when no results are found via noResultsText.

featureExamples.title: Options layout
featureExamples.description:
Control an options list layout with optionLayout prop. It support 2 layouts for main and secondary labels:

  • single-line (default) - use it to display labels side by side.
  • double-line - use it to stack labels vertically.

featureExamples.title: Prefix
featureExamples.description:
Specify icons on the left side with prefix prop or choose not to show it by setting prefix to null.

By default, <LocationIcon /> is displayed.

content.description: Variable input allows you to display <Tag/> components in between plain text. Each tag represents a known variable. Input recognizes predefined text strings and matches them with an assigned variable when input loses focus (on blur).
do: Use it to automatically generate a message or a value that includes one or multiple dynamic values.
dont: Don’t use it to add multiple new values as tags. Use <Multiselect/> with manual input feature instead.

Showing the status message inline, directly below the input is preferred in all default cases.

  • To add an accessible inline message, wrap the component in a <FormField/> and add the statusMessage.
  • To add a status message in a tooltip that requires users to hover on the icon, use the statusMessage prop.

featureExamples.title: Read-only and disabled
featureExamples.description:
Control input interaction with:

  • readOnly - disables writing new values, but allows to copy the current value.
  • disabled - disables all input interactions. Use to highlight unavailable functions.
featureExamples.example:

  <VariableInput
    initialValue="{{interactions}} are read only"
    variableParser={(value) =>
      value === 'interactions' ? 'Interactions' : false
    }
    readOnly
  />
  <VariableInput
    initialValue="{{interactions}} are disabled"
    variableParser={(value) =>
      value === 'interactions' ? 'Interactions' : false
    }
    disabled
  />
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Multiline
featureExamples.description:
Control content scroll direction with the multiline prop.

Multiline is allowed by default. Disabling it results in content scrolling horizontally inside of an input.

content.description: Thumbnail allows to display a specified object as a select item.
do: Use it to select single or multiple items from a mixed list of options.
Use it when select items need to be emphasised with graphics or images.
Use it to build gallery selections.
dont: Don’t use it to switch between alternative options or views. Use <SegmentedToggle/> or <SelectableAccordion/> instead.
Don’t use it to display images. Use <ImageViewer/> instead.
Don’t use it to distribute content within a page. Use <Tabs/> instead.

commonUseCaseExamples.title: List of options
commonUseCaseExamples.description: Use a thumbnail to list down a larger list of options using icons as visual clues.

commonUseCaseExamples.title: Gallery selection
commonUseCaseExamples.description: Use a thumbnail with backgroundImage to construct gallery type selections.

commonUseCaseExamples.title: Custom content
commonUseCaseExamples.description:
Render custom content inside of a thumbnail to provide more details about the selection option.

In example, add graphics, images or custom actions such as links to read more.

commonUseCaseExamples.title: In settings panel
commonUseCaseExamples.description: Use thumbnails with illustrations to visually clarify the result of the selection the user makes.

featureExamples.title: Structure
featureExamples.description:
Component consist of 3 optional content areas:

  • image
  • title
  • description
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack>
  <Thumbnail
    image={<Image />}
    title={
      <StorybookComponents.Placeholder>Title</StorybookComponents.Placeholder>
    }
    description={
      <StorybookComponents.Placeholder>
        Description
      </StorybookComponents.Placeholder>
    }
  />
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Size
featureExamples.description:
Adjust the component size using size prop. It supports 3 sizes:

  • medium (default) - use in all common cases.
  • small - use in more dense and narrow layouts.
  • tiny - use in more dense and narrow layouts.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <Thumbnail size="medium" title="Medium" description="Size" />
  <Thumbnail size="small" title="Small" description="Size" />
  <Thumbnail size="tiny" title="Tiny" description="Size" />
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Dimensions
featureExamples.description: Set thumbnail dimensions in pixels or percentage with height and width properties.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <Thumbnail title="Title" width="50%" height="120px" />
  <Thumbnail title="Title" width="25%" height="60px" />
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Content alignment
featureExamples.description:
Control vertical alignment of thumbnail content with contentAlignment prop. It supports 2 options:

  • center (default) - use in all common cases.
  • top - use when thumbnail list contain items with different content lengths.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack>
  <Thumbnail
    title="Center"
    description="Alignment"
    image={<Image width="90px" />}
    height={240}
    contentAlignment="center"
    width={165}
  />
  <Thumbnail
    title="Top"
    description="Alignment"
    image={<Image width="90px" />}
    height={240}
    contentAlignment="top"
    width={165}
  />
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Text position
featureExamples.description:
Control thumbnail text position with textPosition prop. Choose between:

  • inside (default) - use for text only thumbnails or thumbnails that require more emphasis.
  • outside - use for side panel thumbnails or large group of illustrated thumbnails.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack>
  <Thumbnail
    title="Inside"
    description="Description"
    image={<Image />}
    contentAlignment="top"
    width={165}
    height={200}
  />
    <Thumbnail
    title="Outside"
    description="Alignment"
    image={<Image height="100%"/>}
    contentAlignment="top"
    textPosition="outside"
    width={165}
    height={200}
  />
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Background image
featureExamples.description:
Render image as a background of a thumbnail with backgroundImage prop.

Use it for gallery type selections, such as product cover image selection.
featureExamples.example:
<Thumbnail
  backgroundImage="example.jpg"
  width={240}
  height={240}
  title="Title"
/>;

featureExamples.title: States
featureExamples.description:
Control the state of a component with:

  • selected - use it to mark active selection.
  • disabled - use it to mark item that cannot be selected or deselected.

    • Remove selected item checkmark icon with hideSelectedIcon prop.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack gap="12px">
  <Thumbnail title="Default" width={140} />
  <Thumbnail title="Selected" selected width={140} />
  <Thumbnail title="Disabled" disabled width={140} />
  <Thumbnail
    title="Disabled with image"
    disabled
    image={<Image />}
    width={140}
  />
  <Thumbnail
    title="Disabled with image background"
    disabled
    backgroundImage="example.jpg"
    height={120}
    width={140}
  />
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Status message
featureExamples.description:
Add text that explains the status or what action the user should take with the statusMessage prop.

Show the status message inline, directly below the thumbnails by wrapping it in a <FormField/> and adding statusMessage.

View more inline status message examples in <FormField/>.
featureExamples.example:
<FormField status="error" statusMessage="This is an error message.">
  <StorybookComponents.Stack gap="12px">
    <Thumbnail title="Option 1" width={140} />
    <Thumbnail title="Option 2" width={140} />
    <Thumbnail title="Option 3" width={140} />
  </StorybookComponents.Stack>
</FormField>;

featureExamples.title: Custom content
featureExamples.description:
Render any component or set of them as a child item to the thumbnail content area.

When passed, a title will be displayed below the thumbnail.
featureExamples.example:
<Thumbnail title="Title" width="50%">
  <StorybookComponents.Stack padding="24px">
    <StorybookComponents.Placeholder>Content</StorybookComponents.Placeholder>
  </StorybookComponents.Stack>
</Thumbnail>;

content.description: A star rating bar allows the user to rate the quality of an item or an experience, such as a purchased product, completed service or received meal from a restaurant.
do: Use it to collect feedback about the quality an item or a service.
Use it to display the rating of an item or a service.
dont: Don’t use it to rate the experience with an item or service on an emotional level, use <FacesRatingBar/> instead

commonUseCaseExamples.title: Collecting feedback
commonUseCaseExamples.description: Use an interactive rating bar to collect feedback from your users.

commonUseCaseExamples.title: Displaying feedback
commonUseCaseExamples.description: Use readOnly mode to display individual or general ratings of an item or service.
commonUseCaseExamples.example: Pauline0187 / Apr 07, 2021 Amazing App, Amazing Support team I love this app! I have a Membership only website with over 100 pages. Site Search let's a user type in any word they want to find on the site and it serv... Read more ;

featureExamples.title: Mode
featureExamples.description:
Specify the mode of component:

  • Interactive (default) - used to collect individual feedback.
  • readOnly - used to display overall rating.

featureExamples.title: Size
featureExamples.description:
Control the size of a component:

  • large
  • medium
  • small
  • tiny

    • Interactive mode, which requires input from the user, supports large and medium sizes only.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack>
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <StarsRatingBar size="large" />
  <StarsRatingBar size="medium" />
  </StorybookComponents.Stack>
  <StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
    <StarsRatingBar size="large" readOnly />
    <StarsRatingBar size="medium" readOnly />
    <StarsRatingBar size="small" readOnly />
    <StarsRatingBar size="tiny" readOnly />
  </StorybookComponents.Stack>
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Captions
featureExamples.description:
Give more context to the rating scale by providing value labels.

Captions will be shown only if all 5 labels are defined.

featureExamples.title: Status message
featureExamples.description:
Add text that explains the status or what action the user should take with the statusMessage prop.

Show the status message inline, directly below the rating bar by wrapping it in a <FormField/> and adding statusMessage.

View more inline status message examples in <FormField/>.
featureExamples.example:
<FormField status="error" statusMessage="This is an error message.">
  <StarsRatingBar />
</FormField>;

content.description: MultiSelectCheckbox allows to select multiple items from a predefined list of options.
do: Use it to select multiple items from a list of options.
Use it as a filter for data sets.
dont: Don’t use it to select a single item only. Use <Dropdown/> instead.
Don’t use it if user should be able to add new values to the list as well. Use <Multiselect/> instead.

commonUseCaseExamples.title: Form element
commonUseCaseExamples.description: Use MultiSelectCheckbox in forms to apply multiple values.

commonUseCaseExamples.title: List item builders
commonUseCaseExamples.description: Build custom layouts within a list item builder for advanced filters.

featureExamples.title: Size
featureExamples.description:
Adjust the component size using the size prop. It supports 3 sizes:

  • large - use it in onboarding flows, where the field needs emphasis.
  • medium (default) - use in all common cases.
  • small - use in more dense and narrow layouts.

featureExamples.title: Border
featureExamples.description:
Style the component using the border prop. It supports 4 styles:

  • standard (default) - use in forms.
  • round - use when the component is used as a filter.
  • bottomLine - use as a title which can be edited on the click.
  • none - use in Content Manager's spreadsheet cell.

featureExamples.title: Status
featureExamples.description:
Control the component status using a status prop. It supports 3 states:

  • error - use to highlight an invalid selection.
  • warning - use to highlight a value that impacts the user or that can’t be validated.
  • loading - use to show that the value is being uploaded to the server.

featureExamples.title: Status message
featureExamples.description:
Add text that explains the status or what action the user should take with the statusMessage prop.

Showing the status message inline, directly below the component is preferred in all default cases.

  • To add an accessible inline message, wrap the component in a <FormField/> and add the statusMessage.
  • To add a status message in a tooltip that requires users to hover on the icon, use the statusMessage prop. Control tooltip placement with tooltipPlacement prop.

    • View more inline status message examples in <FormField/>.

featureExamples.title: Disabled
featureExamples.description: Disable all input interactions with disabled prop. Use to highlight unavailable functions.

featureExamples.title: Affix
featureExamples.description:
Support the input value with additional information added to the prefix and suffix props.

These areas can contain text, icons and even badges.

featureExamples.title: Clear button
featureExamples.description: Enable a button that clears the dropdown value by using clearButton prop. Show it when the field value is optional or needs to be cleared.

featureExamples.title: Fixed header and footer
featureExamples.description: Add related actions to fixedFooter or fixedHeader areas. Areas keep their position on scroll.

featureExamples.title: List item builders
featureExamples.description:
Build custom options layouts with:

  • listItemSectionBuilder - use to group items into sections by type. See <ListItemSection/> for more details.
  • listItemActionBuilder - use to add text button for related list actions, i.e. ‘Manage categories’. See <ListItemAction/> for more details.
  • listItemSelectBuilder - use to build custom list designs. See <ListItemSelect/> for more details.

featureExamples.title: List container dimensions
featureExamples.description:
Control the container size for options with:

  • maxHeightPixels - use to specify maximum height for longer lists.
  • dropdownWidth - set width to 'auto' or 'max-content' to match content width or specify it in pixels.
  • minWidthPixels - use to increase dropdown popover width manually.

    • By default, the dropdown matches the input field width.

featureExamples.title: Marked option
featureExamples.description: Control what to highlight with a hover state once the dropdown is opened with the markedOption prop.
featureExamples.example:
<MultiSelectCheckbox
  placeholder="Select"
  markedOption={1}
  options={[
    { id: 0, value: 'Option 1' },
    { id: 1, value: 'Option 2' },
    { id: 2, value: 'Option 3' },
  ]}
/>;

featureExamples.title: Delimiter
featureExamples.description: Specify what character to use to separate selected options with the delimiter prop.

featureExamples.title: Lazy loading
featureExamples.description: Indicate that options are loading from a server or load a large list of items gradually with the infiniteScroll, loadMore and hasMore props.

featureExamples.title: Text overflow
featureExamples.description:
Control text overflow for:

  • The field itself: set the textOverflow prop either to clip or ellipsis.
  • The dropdown layout: it wraps longer values by default. In order to have ellipses, select the items that have to be rendered with the listItemSelectBuilder.

featureExamples.title: Selected items value
featureExamples.description: Customize how the selected values are represented inside of an input.

<Box align="center">
