content.description:
AtlasAddressInput allows users to search for an address with a built-in autocomplete service.

To use this component you must install the following peer-dependencies:

npm install @wix/ambassador @wix/ambassador-wix-atlas-service-web
do: Use it as a built-in solution for a location search.
Use it to enter addresses that must be validated before submitting.
dont: Don’t use it when a custom address provider is necessary. Use <AddressInput/> which provides the UI only.

commonUseCaseExamples.title: Custom address
commonUseCaseExamples.description:
Define custom address formatting using onSelect callback that provides a getAddress function to fetch a Wix Address Object from Atlas.

This example displays a post code along with the address.

featureExamples.title: Authorization
featureExamples.description:
Requests to Atlas must be authorized using an authorization header. Check out this Wix Doc about how to retrieve a signed instance in your environment.

Pass an authorization token to AtlasAddressInput using the token prop.
featureExamples.example: <AtlasAddressInput placeholder="Search..." token="some_auth_token" />;

featureExamples.title: Size
featureExamples.description:
Adjust the component size using size prop. It supports 3 sizes:

  • large - use it in onboarding flows, where input needs emphasis.
  • medium (default) - use in all common cases.
  • small - use in more dense and narrow layouts.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <AtlasAddressInput placeholder="Large" size="large" />
  <AtlasAddressInput placeholder="Medium" size="medium" />
  <AtlasAddressInput placeholder="Small" size="small" />
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Border
featureExamples.description:
Style the component using border prop. It supports 4 styles:

  • round (default) - use it when input acts as a filter.
  • standard - use it in a form.
  • bottomLine - use as a title which can be edited on the click.
  • none - use in Content Manager's spreadsheet cell.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <AtlasAddressInput placeholder="Round" border="round" />
  <AtlasAddressInput placeholder="Standard" border="standard" />
  <AtlasAddressInput placeholder="Bottom Line" border="bottomLine" />
  <AtlasAddressInput placeholder="None" border="none" />
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Status
featureExamples.description:
Control component status using status prop. It supports 3 states:

  • error - use it to highlight invalid input value.
  • warning - use it to highlight value that can’t be validated.
  • loading - use it to indicate a delayed response from the server.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <AtlasAddressInput placeholder="Error" status="error" />
  <AtlasAddressInput placeholder="Warning" status="warning" />
  <AtlasAddressInput placeholder="Loading" status="loading" />
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Status message
featureExamples.description:
Add text that explains the status or what action the user should take with the statusMessage prop.

Showing the status message inline, directly below the input is preferred in all default cases.

  • To add an accessible inline message, wrap the component in a <FormField/> and add the statusMessage.
  • To add a status message in a tooltip that requires users to hover on the icon, use the statusMessage prop.

    • View more inline status message examples in <FormField/>.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column" gap="12px">
    <Text secondary>For all default cases:</Text>
    <FormField statusMessage="This is an error message." status="error">
      <AtlasAddressInput placeholder="See message below" />
    </FormField>
  </StorybookComponents.Stack>
  <StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column" gap="12px">
    <Text secondary>For narrow layouts only:</Text>
    <AtlasAddressInput
      placeholder="Hover on status icon"
      status="error"
      statusMessage="This is an error message."
    />
  </StorybookComponents.Stack>
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Disabled
featureExamples.description: Disable all input interactions with disabled prop. Use it to highlight unavailable functions.
featureExamples.example: <AtlasAddressInput placeholder="Disabled" disabled />;

featureExamples.title: Clear button
featureExamples.description: Control whether to show a clear button with clearButton prop. It allows you to clear the field quickly when a value is optional.

featureExamples.title: Options layout
featureExamples.description:
Control options list layout with optionLayout prop. It supports 2 layouts for main and secondary labels:

  • single-line (default) - use it to display labels side by side.
  • double-line - use it to stack labels vertically.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <AtlasAddressInput placeholder="Single Line" optionLayout="single-line" />
  <AtlasAddressInput placeholder="Double Line" optionLayout="double-line" />
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Options affix
featureExamples.description:
Add supportive info to an options list in defined affix areas:

  • optionPrefix - use the location icon by default. Override only in cases where more specific context is needed, i.e. defining work address.
  • optionSuffix - use it to provide extra info about address.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <AtlasAddressInput
    optionPrefix={<Icons.Toolbox />}
    placeholder="Option prefix"
  />
  <AtlasAddressInput optionSuffix="5km away" placeholder="Option suffix" />
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Localization
featureExamples.description:
Translate search results per country by providing language and locale details.

  • Specify the language with language prop.
  • Specify a required address formatting with locale prop.
featureExamples.example: <AtlasAddressInput placeholder="Search..." language="en" locale="en-us" />;

content.description: Notification informs users about the status change in application. Floating notification is used as a temporary overlay element or inline element within cards.
do: Use it to provide contextual feedback on the outcome of user action.
Use it to notify users about a happened change in the application.
Display notifications inside modals as a temporary overlay.
Place as a section message first in the section that it applies to.
dont: Don’t use it to display system-wide alerts. Use <Notification/> instead.
Don't place an application level messages. Use <SectionHelper/> instead.

commonUseCaseExamples.title: In front of content
commonUseCaseExamples.description: Position notification on top of content in modals to update users about the status change.
commonUseCaseExamples.example:
() => {
  const [state, setState] = React.useState(true);
  return (
    <CustomModalLayout
      title="Account details"
      subtitle="Manage name and email details."
      secondaryButtonText="Cancel"
      primaryButtonText="Save"
      showHeaderDivider

      secondaryButtonOnClick={() => setState(true)}

          <Box
            position="absolute"
            top="24px"
            left="50%"
            transform="translateX(-50%)"
          >
            <FloatingNotification
              prefixIcon={<Icons.StatusAlert />}
              type="destructive"
              text="Fix email value to save account details."
              onClose={() => setState(false)}
            />
          </Box>
        )}
        <Cell span={6}>
          <FormField label="First name">
            <Input defaultValue="John" />
          </FormField>
        </Cell>
        <Cell span={6}>
          <FormField label="Last name">
            <Input defaultValue="Smith" />
          </FormField>
        </Cell>
        <Cell>
          <FormField
            label="Email address"
            status="error"
            statusMessage='Provide the email in format "your@email.com"'
          >
            <Input defaultValue="asfljaokfjalk" type="email" />
          </FormField>
        </Cell>
      </Layout>
    </CustomModalLayout>
  );
};

        ),
      },
      {
        value: (
          <IconButton priority="secondary" size="small">
            <Icons.MoreSmall />
          </IconButton>
        ),
        width: 'auto',
      },
    ]}
  />
</Card>;

featureExamples.title: Skin
featureExamples.description:
Control the appearance of the floating notification with type prop. It supports 7 options:

  • standard (default) - use it to provide additional information relevant to current user task or an action.
  • success - use it to inform users about successful operation.
  • destructive - use it for error messages and information about critical issues that prevent to continue.
  • warning - use it to draw the user's attention to unresolved issues that might affect the application, but doesn't block the process.
  • premium - use it for premium upgrades only — packages that let accept payments, connect domain and have business email. Read more about Premium patterns.
  • preview - use it to present process status or related additional data.
  • dark - use it to emphasize informational messages in the context of other content.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <FloatingNotification type="standard" text="Standard (default)" />
  <FloatingNotification type="success" text="Success" />
  <FloatingNotification type="warning" text="Warning" />
  <FloatingNotification type="destructive" text="Destructive" />
  <FloatingNotification type="premium" text="Premium" />
  <FloatingNotification type="preview" text="Preview" />
  <FloatingNotification type="dark" text="Dark" />
</StorybookComponents.Stack>

featureExamples.title: Width
featureExamples.description:
Control component width in pixels or percentage with width prop.

Set component to fill 100% of its parent container width with fullWidth prop. Prop has an effect on notification appearance - it removes left/right borders and corner radius, changes component height and paddings.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <FloatingNotification width="300px" text="Fixed width" />
  <FloatingNotification fullWidth text="Full width" />
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Actions
featureExamples.description:
Add call to actions to a notification with:

  • buttonProps - use to add a primary action
  • textButtonProps - use it to add a text button. Add a link to an external URL with href prop.

    • Component can have both actions at the same time.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <FloatingNotification
    text="Text message"
    buttonProps={{ label: 'Action' }}
  />
  <FloatingNotification
    text="Text message"
    showTextButton
    textButtonProps={{ label: 'Link' }}
  />
  <FloatingNotification
    text="Text message"
    buttonProps={{ label: 'Action' }}
    textButtonProps={{ label: 'Link to wix.com', as: 'a', href: 'https://www.wix.com' }}
  />
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Close Button
featureExamples.description: Control whether notification can be dismissed by a user with showCloseButton prop.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <FloatingNotification text="Dismissable" />
  <FloatingNotification text="Non-dismissable" showCloseButton={false} />
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Prefix
featureExamples.description: Add more context for the notification purpose with prefixIcon.
featureExamples.example:
<FloatingNotification
  text="Notification message here"
  prefixIcon={<Icons.InfoCircle />}
/>;

content.description: Nestable lists let users sort their list items into sub-levels using drag and drop.
do: Organize items into sub-levels and categories.
Create lists that users can add to.
dont: Don’t show static lists. Use <Accordion/> or <Table/> instead.
Don’t use them for lists that span across multiple pages.

commonUseCaseExamples.title: Sort items into sub-categories
commonUseCaseExamples.description:
Use nestable lists to let the users organize their items (posts, articles, products, etc.) into categories and subcategories.

Use any necessary <TableListItem/> props to format the style and content inside the list of items.

commonUseCaseExamples.title: Rearrange the order of items
commonUseCaseExamples.description:
Use nestable lists to allow quick rearrangement of list items.

In <SidePanel/> or on other white backgrounds, use the withBottomBorder prop to add a border divider at the end of the list.

  <NestableList

featureExamples.title: Prevent changing depth
featureExamples.description:
Lock the existing depth for all items in the list with the preventChangeDepth prop. This property allows users to change the order of items, but only at the same level of hierarchy.

By default the value of the preventChangeDepth property is false. This means users can drag and drop any item to any level.
featureExamples.example:
<NestableList
  preventChangeDepth={true}
  items={[
    {
      id: 1,
      options: [
        { value: <Text size="small">This item can only move in level 1</Text> },
      ],
      children: [
        {
          id: 2,
          options: [
            { value: <Text size="small">This item can only move in level 2</Text> },
          ],
        },
        {
          id: 3,
          options: [
            { value: <Text size="small">This item can only move in level 2</Text> },
          ],
        },
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 4,
      options: [
        { value: <Text size="small">This item can only move in level 1</Text> },
      ],
      children: [
        {
          id: 5,
          options: [
            { value: <Text size="small">This item can only move in level 2</Text> },
          ],
        },
      ],
    },
  ]}
  onChange={() => {}}
/>;

featureExamples.title: Lock dragging
featureExamples.description:
To lock an individual item’s position, use the items prop and set draggable to false.

Items that aren't locked can still freely change their position in the list.
featureExamples.example:
<NestableList
  items={[
    {
      id: 1,
      options: [{ value: <Text size="small">This item can't be dragged</Text> }],
      draggable: false,
      children: [
        {
          id: 2,
          options: [{ value: <Text size="small">This item can't be dragged</Text> }],
          draggable: false,
        },
        {
          id: 3,
          options: [
            { value: <Text size="small">This item can be moved freely</Text> },
          ],
        },
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 4,
      options: [{ value: <Text size="small">This item can be moved freely</Text> }],
      children: [
        {
          id: 5,
          options: [
            { value: <Text size="small">This item can be moved freely</Text> },
          ],
        },
      ],
    },
  ]}
  onChange={() => {}}
/>;

featureExamples.title: Read only mode
featureExamples.description: Prevent any reordering in the list with the readOnly prop. The list won't display any interactive icons.
featureExamples.example:
<NestableList

featureExamples.title: Collapse items
featureExamples.description:
To hide children and only show the parent item, use the items prop and set isCollapsed to true.

By default, parent items hide their children when they're being selected and dragged.

featureExamples.title: Bottom border
featureExamples.description:
Add a bottom border to the last item in the list with the withBottomBorder prop. The default value is set to false.

Use the border when the list is outside the card or modal, for example, in the sidebar and on white backgrounds.

<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">

</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

content.description: Radio groups (radio buttons) allow users to choose a single item from a list of options.
do: Allow the user to select a single item from a short list of options (e.g., 2-5 items).
Use it to show all available options.
Have a preselected option where possible, or add a neutral option (e.g., "None" or "All").
dont: Don’t use it when multiple options can be selected. Use the <Checkbox/> component instead.
Don’t use it for lists of more than 5 options. Use the <Dropdown/> or <Autocomplete/> components instead.

commonUseCaseExamples.title: Settings panel
commonUseCaseExamples.description: Only use small size radio buttons in settings panels to ensure consistency across all panels.

commonUseCaseExamples.title: Default selection
commonUseCaseExamples.description: Have a default option selected whenever possible, ideally a neutral choice such as "None" or "All".

commonUseCaseExamples.title: Additional info
commonUseCaseExamples.description: Use <InfoIcon/> to add a tooltip next to an option to provide additional information.

commonUseCaseExamples.title: Horizontal layout
commonUseCaseExamples.description: Use a horizontal layout when displaying radio lists with 2-3 options and short descriptions. This layout is great for situations where vertical space is limited.

commonUseCaseExamples.title: Custom button
commonUseCaseExamples.description: Other components can also be used in radio option labels (e.g., avatar, illustration, additional text).
commonUseCaseExamples.example:
() => {
  const [selected, setSelected] = React.useState(1);
  return (
    <Card>
      <Card.Header
        title="Business type"
        subtitle="Define your business type for legal purposes."
      />
      <Card.Divider />
      <Card.Content>
        <RadioGroup
          selectionArea="always"
          selectionAreaSkin="outlined"
          selectionAreaPadding="18px"
          spacing="12px"
          value={selected}
          onChange={setSelected}
        >
          <RadioGroup.Radio value={1}>
            <Box gap={2} verticalAlign="middle">
              <Avatar />
              <Box direction="vertical">
                <Text weight="normal">Individual</Text>
                <Text size="small">
                  You own and run the business with a personal bank account.
                </Text>
              </Box>
            </Box>
          </RadioGroup.Radio>
          <RadioGroup.Radio value={2}>
            <Box gap={2} verticalAlign="middle">
              <Avatar shape="square" />
              <Box direction="vertical">
                <Text weight="normal">Partnership, LLC or Corporation</Text>
                <Text size="small">
                  You have a business registration number and a business bank
                  account.
                </Text>
              </Box>
            </Box>
          </RadioGroup.Radio>
        </RadioGroup>
      </Card.Content>
    </Card>
  );
};

featureExamples.title: Structure
featureExamples.description:
The component consists of a list of options with radio buttons wrapped inside <RadioGroup>.

Option labels are plain text by default, but they can be replaced with any other component or set of components.
featureExamples.example:
<RadioGroup value={1}>
  <RadioGroup.Radio value={1}>Option 1</RadioGroup.Radio>
  <RadioGroup.Radio value={2}>Option 2</RadioGroup.Radio>
  <RadioGroup.Radio value={3}>Option 3</RadioGroup.Radio>
  <RadioGroup.Radio value={4}>Option 4</RadioGroup.Radio>
</RadioGroup>;

featureExamples.title: Size
featureExamples.description:
Adjust the component size using the size prop. It supports 2 sizes:

medium (default) - use in all common cases

small - use in more dense layouts
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <RadioGroup size="medium" value={1}>
    <RadioGroup.Radio value={1}>Option 1</RadioGroup.Radio>
    <RadioGroup.Radio value={2}>Option 2</RadioGroup.Radio>
    <RadioGroup.Radio value={3}>Option 3</RadioGroup.Radio>
  </RadioGroup>
  <RadioGroup size="small" value={1}>
    <RadioGroup.Radio value={1}>Option 1</RadioGroup.Radio>
    <RadioGroup.Radio value={2}>Option 2</RadioGroup.Radio>
    <RadioGroup.Radio value={3}>Option 3</RadioGroup.Radio>
  </RadioGroup>
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Layout
featureExamples.description:
Control the layout of the options with the display prop. Choose from 2 layouts:

  • For most common cases, use the default vertical.
  • Use horizontal for options with short labels (e.g., Yes/No selections in a form), or when there is limited space.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <RadioGroup value={1} display="vertical">
    <RadioGroup.Radio value={1}>Vertical 1</RadioGroup.Radio>
    <RadioGroup.Radio value={2}>Vertical 2</RadioGroup.Radio>
    <RadioGroup.Radio value={3}>Vertical 3</RadioGroup.Radio>
  </RadioGroup>
  <RadioGroup value={1} display="horizontal">
    <RadioGroup.Radio value={1}>Horizontal 1</RadioGroup.Radio>
    <RadioGroup.Radio value={2}>Horizontal 2</RadioGroup.Radio>
    <RadioGroup.Radio value={3}>Horizontal 3</RadioGroup.Radio>
  </RadioGroup>
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Spacing
featureExamples.description: Control the pixel spacing between options with the spacing prop.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack gap="72px">
  <RadioGroup spacing="12px">
    <RadioGroup.Radio value={1}>Option 1</RadioGroup.Radio>
    <RadioGroup.Radio value={2}>Option 2</RadioGroup.Radio>
    <RadioGroup.Radio value={3}>Option 3</RadioGroup.Radio>
  </RadioGroup>
  <RadioGroup spacing="18px">
    <RadioGroup.Radio value={1}>Option 1</RadioGroup.Radio>
    <RadioGroup.Radio value={2}>Option 2</RadioGroup.Radio>
    <RadioGroup.Radio value={3}>Option 3</RadioGroup.Radio>
  </RadioGroup>
  <RadioGroup spacing="24px">
    <RadioGroup.Radio value={1}>Option 1</RadioGroup.Radio>
    <RadioGroup.Radio value={2}>Option 2</RadioGroup.Radio>
    <RadioGroup.Radio value={3}>Option 3</RadioGroup.Radio>
  </RadioGroup>
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Button alignment
featureExamples.description:
Control how the radio buttons align to the text with the vAlign prop. Choose from 2 alignments:

  • center (the default) aligns the radio button to the middle of the text. It is recommended for most common cases.
  • top aligns the radio buttons to the top of the text. This is good for options that go over 3 or more lines of text.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <RadioGroup vAlign="center">
    <RadioGroup.Radio>
      <Heading size="small">Center aligned radio</Heading>
      <Text secondary size="small">
        Subtitle
      </Text>
    </RadioGroup.Radio>
  </RadioGroup>
  <RadioGroup vAlign="top">
    <RadioGroup.Radio>
      <Heading size="small">Top aligned radio</Heading>
      <Text secondary size="small">
        Subtitle
      </Text>
    </RadioGroup.Radio>
  </RadioGroup>
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Disabled buttons
featureExamples.description:
Radio options can be disabled in 2 ways:

  • Disable all options at once with disabled.
  • Choose which options to disable with disabledRadios.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack gap="60px">
  <RadioGroup disabled value={1}>
    <RadioGroup.Radio value={1}>All disabled</RadioGroup.Radio>
    <RadioGroup.Radio value={2}>All disabled</RadioGroup.Radio>
    <RadioGroup.Radio value={3}>All disabled</RadioGroup.Radio>
  </RadioGroup>
  <RadioGroup disabledRadios={[3]} value={1}>
    <RadioGroup.Radio value={1}>Selected</RadioGroup.Radio>
    <RadioGroup.Radio value={2}>Unselected</RadioGroup.Radio>
    <RadioGroup.Radio value={3}>Disabled</RadioGroup.Radio>
  </RadioGroup>
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Status message
featureExamples.description:
Add text that explains the status or what action the user should take with the statusMessage prop.

Show the status message inline, directly below the radio group by wrapping it in a <FormField/> and adding statusMessage.

View more inline status message examples in <FormField/>.
featureExamples.example:
<FormField status="error" statusMessage="This is an error message.">
  <RadioGroup>
    <RadioGroup.Radio value={1}>Option 1</RadioGroup.Radio>
    <RadioGroup.Radio value={2}>Option 2</RadioGroup.Radio>
    <RadioGroup.Radio value={3}>Option 3</RadioGroup.Radio>
  </RadioGroup>
</FormField>;

featureExamples.title: Button area
featureExamples.description:
Highlight the clickable area of an option by controlling the design. It's recommended to always use this on mobile.

  • Specify when the button area should be highlighted (on hover, always, or not at all) with selectionArea.
  • To choose a filled or outlined design, use selectionAreaSkin.
  • Define the white pixel spacing around each radio button with selectionAreaPadding.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <RadioGroup
    value={1}
    selectionArea="always"
    selectionAreaSkin="outlined"
    selectionAreaPadding="12px 18px"
  >
    <RadioGroup.Radio value={1}>Option 1</RadioGroup.Radio>
    <RadioGroup.Radio value={2}>Option 2</RadioGroup.Radio>
    <RadioGroup.Radio value={3}>Option 3</RadioGroup.Radio>
  </RadioGroup>
  <RadioGroup
    value={1}
    selectionArea="hover"
    selectionAreaSkin="filled"
    selectionAreaPadding="12px 18px"
  >
    <RadioGroup.Radio value={1}>Option 1</RadioGroup.Radio>
    <RadioGroup.Radio value={2}>Option 2</RadioGroup.Radio>
    <RadioGroup.Radio value={3}>Option 3</RadioGroup.Radio>
  </RadioGroup>
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Additional content
featureExamples.description: Use the content prop to show additional details for an option. It accepts any kind of content and places it outside of a radio option.
featureExamples.example:
<RadioGroup value={1} selectionArea="always">
  <RadioGroup.Radio
    value={1}
    content={
      <StorybookComponents.Placeholder margin={2}>
        Details about Option 1
      </StorybookComponents.Placeholder>
    }
  >
    Option 1
  </RadioGroup.Radio>
  <RadioGroup.Radio
    value={2}
    content={
      <StorybookComponents.Placeholder margin={2}>
        Details about Option 2
      </StorybookComponents.Placeholder>
    }
  >
    Option 2
  </RadioGroup.Radio>
</RadioGroup>;

content.demo: <Divider />
content.description: Dividers are thin lines that separate content, or groups it into clear sections. They act like visual punctuation marks and make web pages easier to read.
do: Separate content in lists and layouts.
Use dividers to support visual hierarchy.
dont: Don't overuse dividers when white space can be used instead.
Don't place two dividers together without content in between.

commonUseCaseExamples.title: Lists
commonUseCaseExamples.description: Separate entities from one another with a divider for an easy-to-read list.

commonUseCaseExamples.title: Separated content
commonUseCaseExamples.description: Create a full-bleed divider to separate secondary content.

content.demo:
<Page>
  <Page.Content>
    <Layout>
      <Cell>
        <Layout>

content.description: The page header appears at the top of a page, orients the user and focuses their attention on the primary action to be taken.
do: Always use it within the  <Page/> component.
Provide a title for each page on the site. Use it to describe what the page is about.
Keep the entire page header text visible at all times. Make sure it doesn't get truncated with an ellipsis.
dont: Don’t use it as a stand alone component, always use it within the <Page/> component.
Don’t use it for content sections. Use <PageSection/> instead.
Don’t use it for cards or other widgets. Use <Heading/> instead.

featureExamples.title: Structure
featureExamples.description:
Page header structures can vary, but they can include up to three elements:

  • title
  • subtitle (optional)
  • actionBar (optional)
featureExamples.example:
<Page.Header
  title="Page Title"
  subtitle="Subtitle"
  actionsBar={
    <StorybookComponents.Placeholder width='300px'>
      Action bar (optional)
    </StorybookComponents.Placeholder>
  }
/>;

featureExamples.title: Action bar
featureExamples.description:
Place page actions on the right side of the header using the actionsBar prop.

Pages should only have one primary action. If more actions are needed, place them in a "More Actions" popover menu, which can be displayed from a <Button/> or <IconButton/>.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <Page.Header
    title="Form Pages"
    actionsBar={
      <StorybookComponents.Stack gap="12px">
        <PopoverMenu
          triggerElement={
            <IconButton skin="inverted">
              <Icons.More />
            </IconButton>
          }
        >
          <PopoverMenu.MenuItem
            text="Duplicate"
            prefixIcon={<Icons.Duplicate />}
          />
          <PopoverMenu.MenuItem text="Delete" prefixIcon={<Icons.Delete />} />
        </PopoverMenu>
        <Button priority="secondary" skin="inverted">
          Cancel
        </Button>
        <Button>Save</Button>
      </StorybookComponents.Stack>
    }
  />
  <Page.Header
    title="Display Pages"
    actionsBar={
      <StorybookComponents.Stack gap="12px">
        <PopoverMenu
          triggerElement={
            <Button skin="inverted" suffixIcon={<Icons.ChevronDown />}>
              More Actions
            </Button>
          }
        >
          <PopoverMenu.MenuItem
            text="Export to CSV "
            prefixIcon={<Icons.DownloadImport />}
          />
          <PopoverMenu.MenuItem
            text="View analytics"
            prefixIcon={<Icons.Statistics />}
          />
        </PopoverMenu>
        <Button prefixIcon={<Icons.Add />}>Create New</Button>
      </StorybookComponents.Stack>
    }
  />
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Inverted
featureExamples.description:
Invert the header styles with the hasBackgroundImage prop when using an image or dark-colored background.

This property only affects the styles of the title, subtitle, breadcrumbs and back button. Button styles must be changed manually.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">

  />
  <StorybookComponents.Background skin="dark">
    <Page.Header
      actionsBar={

          <Button skin="light" priority="secondary">
            Secondary Action
          </Button>
          <Button skin="light">Main Action</Button>
        </StorybookComponents.Stack>
      }
      breadcrumbs={
        <Breadcrumbs
          activeId="3"
          items={[
            { id: '1', value: 'Page' },
            { id: '2', value: 'Page' },
            { id: '3', value: 'Inverted Page Header' },
          ]}
          onClick={() => {}}
        />
      }
      hasBackgroundImage
      onBackClicked={() => {}}
      showBackButton
      title="Inverted Page Header"
      subtitle="Use an inverted header on image or dark colored backgrounds."
    />
  </StorybookComponents.Background>
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Editable
featureExamples.description: Let users edit the page title by rendering <EditableTitle/> as the title prop value.

featureExamples.title: Overflow text
featureExamples.description:
The page title is limited to a single line of text. The subtitle has a limit of 2 lines.

Longer values will be truncated with ellipses and the full text will be displayed in a tooltip on hover.

Note: Keeping all title text visible on the screen at all times is very important for accessibility and usability overall. Keep page titles short.
featureExamples.example:
<Page.Header
  title="This is a long page title which exceeds the limit of a single line"
  subtitle="This is an explanatory subtitle which exceeds the limit of two lines. Text that is longer than two lines will be hidden and can be previewed in a tooltip message only. Avoid long descriptions. If two lines are not enough, maybe this description should be part of the content instead."
/>;

featureExamples.title: Minimized
featureExamples.description:
The page header minimizes automatically on scroll. You can also choose to use the minimized header manually with the minimized prop. The minimized version is displayed on top of the page content when users scroll down.

Breadcrumbs show in a minimized header instead of the page title when they're on a page.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <Page.Header
    title="Minimized Page Title"
    minimized
    actionsBar={<Button>Action</Button>}
  />
  <Page.Header
    title="Minimized Page Title with Breadcrumbs"
    breadcrumbs={
      <Breadcrumbs
        activeId="3"
        items={[
          { id: '1', value: 'Page' },
          { id: '2', value: 'Page' },
          { id: '3', value: 'Minimized Page Title with Breadcrumbs' },
        ]}
        onClick={() => {}}
      />
    }
    minimized
    actionsBar={<Button>Action</Button>}
  />
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

content.description: A card divider is a horizontal line that separates the card content into clear sections. It extends to the full width of the container and is a compound component of the <Card/>.
do: Separate <Card.Header/> from <Card.Content/>.
Organize card content into sections.
dont: Don’t use card dividers outside of <Card/> components. Use the standard <Divider/> instead.
Don't overuse dividers. Use white space whenever possible.

commonUseCaseExamples.title: Header separation
commonUseCaseExamples.description: Use the <Card.Divider/> to separate the header from the content area.

commonUseCaseExamples.title: Content grouping
commonUseCaseExamples.description: Use the <Card.Divider/> to structure information inside the card.
commonUseCaseExamples.example:
() => {
  const [checked, setChecked] = React.useState({
    vegan: false,
    vegetarian: false,
    glutenFree: false,
    organic: false,
  });
  return (
    <Card>
      <Card.Header title="New dish" />
      <Card.Divider />
      <Card.Content>
        <Layout>
          <Cell span={4}>
            <FormField label="Image">
              <ImageViewer width="100%" height="180px" />
            </FormField>
          </Cell>
          <Cell span={8}>
            <Layout>
              <Cell span={6}>
                <FormField label="Name">
                  <Input value="" />
                </FormField>
              </Cell>
              <Cell span={3}>
                <FormField label="Price">
                  <Input value="0" prefix={<Input.Affix>$</Input.Affix>} />
                </FormField>
              </Cell>
              <Cell span={3}>
                <FormField label="Tax">
                  <Input value="0" prefix={<Input.Affix>%</Input.Affix>} />
                </FormField>
              </Cell>
              <Cell>
                <FormField label="Description">
                  <InputArea
                    placeholder="Enter more details about the dish."
                    resizable
                    rows={3}
                  />
                </FormField>
              </Cell>
            </Layout>
          </Cell>
          <Cell span={12}>
            <Card.Divider />
          </Cell>
          <Cell span={12}>
            <FormField label="Labels">
              <Box direction="horizontal" gap="4">
                <Checkbox
                  onChange={() =>
                    setChecked({ ...checked, vegan: !checked.vegan })
                  }
                  checked={checked.vegan}
                >
                  Vegan
                </Checkbox>
                <Checkbox
                  checked={checked.vegetarian}
                  onChange={() =>
                    setChecked({ ...checked, vegetarian: !checked.vegetarian })
                  }
                >
                  Vegetarian
                </Checkbox>
                <Checkbox
                  checked={checked.glutenFree}
                  onChange={() =>
                    setChecked({ ...checked, glutenFree: !checked.glutenFree })
                  }
                >
                  Gluten Free
                </Checkbox>
                <Checkbox
                  checked={checked.organic}
                  onChange={() =>
                    setChecked({ ...checked, organic: !checked.organic })
                  }
                >
                  Organic
                </Checkbox>
              </Box>
            </FormField>
          </Cell>
        </Layout>
      </Card.Content>
    </Card>
  );
};

Don’t use it outside of the <Card/> component.

content.description: The card subheader divides card content into sections. It's an optional compound component of the <Card/>.
do: Group related content under subheaders within a card.
dont: Don’t use it outside of the <Card/> component.

commonUseCaseExamples.title: Grouping card content
commonUseCaseExamples.description: Use card subheaders to organize card info into categories. It will make the whole card easier to scan.

featureExamples.title: Structure
featureExamples.description:
Card subheaders consist of 2 parts:

  • title labels contents under the subheader.
  • suffix is a container for an action button or other components.

    • Note that both parts are optional and their position is fixed.
featureExamples.example:
<Card.Subheader
  title="Title"
  suffix={
    <StorybookComponents.Placeholder width="50px" height="20px">
      Suffix
    </StorybookComponents.Placeholder>
  }
/>;

featureExamples.title: Skin
featureExamples.description:
Control the background color with the skin:

  • standard is the default and is used in most cases.
  • neutral is used to minimize the component’s visual weight.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <Card.Subheader skin="standard" title="Standard" />
  <Card>
    <Card.Subheader skin="neutral" title="Neutral" />
  </Card>
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Title
featureExamples.description: Use title to summarize the content below the subheader.
featureExamples.example: <Card.Subheader title="Title" />;

featureExamples.title: Suffix
featureExamples.description:
Use a suffix container to add info or actions that apply to the card content.

A variety of components can be used in the suffix:

  • <Button/>
  • <TextButton/>
  • <IconButton/>
  • <Text/>
  • <InfoIcon/>
  • Other components
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <Card.Subheader
    suffix={
      <Button size="tiny" priority="secondary">
        Suffix
      </Button>
    }
  />
  <Card.Subheader
    suffix={
      <TextButton size="tiny" priority="secondary">
        Suffix
      </TextButton>
    }
  />
  <Card.Subheader
    suffix={
      <IconButton size="tiny" priority="secondary">
        <Icons.MoreSmall />
      </IconButton>
    }
  />
  <Card.Subheader suffix={<Text size="tiny">Suffix</Text>} />
  <Card.Subheader suffix={<InfoIcon content="Context info" />} />
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

content.description: Modal is the overlay that appears as the background for all types of modal layouts. It is triggered by a user’s action and is a container for components like <CustomModalLayout/> and <MessageModalLayout/>.
do: Use it as the background for all types of modal layouts.
Use it only when it is completely necessary. Because they are intrusive, modals should be used sparingly.
dont: Don't use modals without any intentional user action.

commonUseCaseExamples.title: Desktop modal with popover elements
commonUseCaseExamples.description:
By default, modal layouts do not allow content to overflow into the background.

Use popoverProps, appendTo and dynamicWidth props to display overlays as intended. For more guidance, read about the <Popover/> component.

featureExamples.title: Structure
featureExamples.description:
Modal consists of an overlay only and should contain one of the following layouts:

  • <CustomModalLayout/>
  • <ModalPreviewLayout/>
  • <AnnouncementModalLayout/>
  • <ModalMobileLayout/>

featureExamples.title: Side margins
featureExamples.description:
Control the spacing between the viewport and the modal content by using screen prop. It has 3 options:

  • full (default) - used with <ModalPreviewLayout/>.
  • desktop - used with all major desktop modals.
  • mobile - used with <ModalMobileLayout/> component.

featureExamples.title: Navigation controls
featureExamples.description: Add the option to navigate between modals by using the showNavigationPreviousButton and showNavigationNextButton props.

featureExamples.title: Structure
featureExamples.description:
Card headers consist of 3 parts:

  • title is the main text of the card, showing its main topic.
  • subtitle is an additional explanation or description of the card’s topic.
  • suffix is a container for buttons, links, or other components.

    • All 3 parts are optional and their position is fixed.
featureExamples.example:
<Card>
  <Card.Header
    title="Title"
    subtitle="Subtitle"
    suffix={
      <StorybookComponents.Placeholder width="50px" height="40px">
        Suffix
      </StorybookComponents.Placeholder>
    }
  />
</Card>;

featureExamples.title: Title and subtitle
featureExamples.description:
Use a short title so the card’s topic stands out and is easier to scan.

Add a subtitle to give further explanation.
featureExamples.example:
<Card>
  <Card.Header title="Title" subtitle="Subtitle" />
</Card>;

featureExamples.title: Suffix
featureExamples.description:
Use a suffix container to add actions that apply to the whole card.

A variety of components can be used in the suffix, including:

  • <Button/>
  • <TextButton/>
  • <IconButton/>
  • <ToggleSwitch/> (use for collapsible cards)

developerExamples.title: Controlled
developerExamples.description: Component can be used in controlled mode by passing value and onChange props.

developerExamples.title: Force autogrow when controlled externally
developerExamples.description: Auto grow feature does not work when component is used in controlled way which means using value and onChange properties. To force auto grow behaviour on state change just call ref method of component called calculateComputedRows which will recalculate rows on every value change.

content.description: Input areas let users insert long text values. The large size of the field indicates that a user is expected to insert at least a few sentences.
do: Use it to insert multiple lines of text.
dont: Don’t use it to insert short text values. Use <Input/> instead.

commonUseCaseExamples.title: Forms
commonUseCaseExamples.description:
Use input area when the user needs to enter multiple lines of text such as product descriptions and policies.

Use <FormField/> to provide a label for the field.

commonUseCaseExamples.title: Settings panel
commonUseCaseExamples.description: Use input area in settings panels to allow users to edit longer descriptions and titles.
commonUseCaseExamples.example:
() => {

featureExamples.title: Size
featureExamples.description:
Adjust the size of the input using the size prop. It supports 2 sizes:

  • For most common cases, use the default medium.
  • Use small for more dense and compact layouts.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <InputArea placeholder="Medium" size="medium" />
  <InputArea placeholder="Small" size="small" />
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Height
featureExamples.description:
Control the height of an area by defining a minimum or maximum number of pixels, or a certain number of rows.

  • To define the minimum and maximum height in pixels, use minHeight and maxHeight.
  • Define the height of a specified number of rows with rows.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <InputArea
    placeholder="Height defined in pixels"
    minHeight="120px"
    maxHeight="300px"
  />
  <InputArea placeholder="Height that fits 4 rows of text" rows={4} />
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Status
featureExamples.description:
Control the status of the input using the status prop. It supports 3 states:

  • error demonstrates that a required input is missing something or the entry was invalid.
  • warning highlights an input value that might have a significant impact to a user.
  • loading shows when an input value is being uploaded to the server.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <InputArea placeholder="Error" status="error" />
  <InputArea placeholder="Warning" status="warning" />
  <InputArea placeholder="Loading" status="loading" />
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Status message
featureExamples.description:
Add text that explains the status or what action the user should take with the statusMessage prop.

Showing the status message inline, directly below the component is preferred in all default cases.

  • To add an accessible inline message, wrap the component in a <FormField/> and add the statusMessage.
  • To add a status message in a tooltip that requires users to hover on the icon, use the statusMessage prop. Control tooltip placement with tooltipPlacement prop.

    • View more inline status message examples in <FormField/>.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column" gap="12px">
    <Text secondary>For all default cases:</Text>
    <FormField status="error" statusMessage="This is an error message.">
      <InputArea placeholder="See message below" tooltipPlacement="top-end" />
    </FormField>
  </StorybookComponents.Stack>
  <StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column" gap="12px">
    <Text secondary>For narrow layouts only:</Text>
    <InputArea
      placeholder="Hover on status icon"
      status="error"
      statusMessage="This is an error message."
      tooltipPlacement="top-end"
    />
  </StorybookComponents.Stack>
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Read-only and disabled
featureExamples.description:
Inputs can also be made read-only or disabled entirely.

  • readOnly disables adding or editing, but allows the user to copy the current value.
  • disabledremoves all interactions and creates a disabled input state. Use it to highlight functions that are unavailable.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <InputArea value="Read-only" readOnly />
  <InputArea value="Disabled" disabled />
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Resize
featureExamples.description: Allow users to manually adjust the size of the input area by enabling theresizable prop.
featureExamples.example:
<InputArea
  placeholder="Drag the handle in the bottom right corner to change the height of an area."
  resizable
/>;

featureExamples.title: Character count
featureExamples.description: Indicate how many characters the input area contains by enabling the hasCounter prop. To display a counter, specify the maxLength of characters allowed in the field.

featureExamples.title: Auto grow
featureExamples.description: Grow and shrink area size according to the input by enabling autoGrow. Specify the starting height of an area with minRowsAutoGrow.
featureExamples.example:
<InputArea
  placeholder="Enter a lot of text into this area to see how it grows according to the length of content."
  autoGrow={true}
  minRowsAutoGrow={1}
/>;

featureExamples.title: Auto select
featureExamples.description: Click to select/highlight all the text in the area with the autoSelect prop.
featureExamples.example: <InputArea value="Click on the field to select the entire text." autoSelect />;

content.description: Rich text input areas let users insert and format long sections of text, and add lists and links.
do: Let users add multiple sentences or paragraphs.
Let users format the text they write.
dont: Don’t use for text inputs that are a single line. Use <Input/> instead.

commonUseCaseExamples.title: Form
commonUseCaseExamples.description:
The rich text input area is often used when there are multiple paragraphs of text.

When content is longer than a sentence or two, text formatting greatly improves readability and allows people to scan easily.

  <Card.Divider />

        minHeight="120px"

      />

</Card>;

featureExamples.title: Height
featureExamples.description:
Control the height of the text area (excluding the toolbar):

  • minHeight sets a minimum height in pixels.
  • maxHeight sets a maximum height in pixels. Once the maximum height is reached, an inner scroll appears.

    • If undefined, the text area height is dynamic and grows or shrinks based on the user input.
featureExamples.example: <RichTextInputArea minHeight="120px" maxHeight="400px" />;

featureExamples.title: Status

  • error demonstrates that required input is missing something or the entry was invalid.

  • loading shows that text is being saved.

  <RichTextInputArea status="warning" placeholder="Warning" />
  <RichTextInputArea status="loading" placeholder="Loading" />
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Status message

Showing the status message inline, directly below the input area is preferred in all default cases.

  • To add an accessible inline message, wrap the component in a <FormField/> and add the statusMessage.
  • To add a status message in a tooltip that requires users to hover on the icon, use the statusMessage prop.

featureExamples.example:

This component supports the following formatting:

content.description: Checkboxes allows to select single or multiple items from a list of predefined options.
do: Use it in forms to select one or multiple items from a list of options.
Use it when all options need to be displayed right away.
Use it when an explicit action is required to apply a setting, e.g., Agree to terms and conditions.
dont: Don’t use it to select a single item from a list. Use <RadioGroup/> instead.
Don’t use it to activate a setting or a feature. Use <ToggleSwitch/> instead.
Don’t use it to select more than 5-10 options, use <MultiSelectCheckbox/>, <MultiSelect/> or <SelectorList/> instead.

commonUseCaseExamples.title: Forms
commonUseCaseExamples.description: Use checkboxes in a form to display all available options.

commonUseCaseExamples.title: With a label
commonUseCaseExamples.description: Use any component for checkbox labels, make sure that they are either textual components or self-explanatory within the given context.

featureExamples.title: Size
featureExamples.description:
Adjust the component size using the size prop. It supports 2 sizes:

  • medium (default) - use in all common cases
  • small - use in more dense layouts
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <Checkbox size="medium">Medium</Checkbox>
  <Checkbox size="small">Small</Checkbox>
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: State
featureExamples.description:
A checkbox can exist in multiple states:

  • In the default state, the checkbox is empty and the user is able to select it.
  • checked - the selected item is marked.
  • indeterminate - represent a mixed value for bulk selection checkbox (both selected and not selected values included).
  • disabled - highlight that a selection exists but it’s not available at that time.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <Checkbox>Default</Checkbox>
  <Checkbox checked>Checked</Checkbox>
  <Checkbox indeterminate>Indeterminate</Checkbox>
  <Checkbox disabled>Disabled</Checkbox>
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Status message
featureExamples.description:
Add text that explains the status or what action the user should take with the statusMessage prop.

Show the status message inline, directly below the checkboxes by wrapping them in a <FormField/> and adding statusMessage.

View more inline status message examples in <FormField/>.
featureExamples.example:
<FormField status="error" statusMessage="This is an error message.">
  <StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column" gap="12px">
    <Checkbox>Option 1</Checkbox>
    <Checkbox>Option 2</Checkbox>
  </StorybookComponents.Stack>
</FormField>;

featureExamples.title: Vertical alignment
featureExamples.description:
Control checkbox alignment with a label using the vAlign prop. It supports 2 values:

  • center (default) - use it in all common cases
  • top - use it to align the checkbox to the top to handle text overflow
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack width="300px" flexDirection="column" >
  <Checkbox vAlign="center">Checkbox label that wraps to multiple lines (center)</Checkbox>
  <Checkbox vAlign="top">Checkbox label that wraps to multiple lines (top)</Checkbox>
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Selection area
featureExamples.description:
Emphasize the clickable space with a selection area. Control the style with:

  • selectionArea - to specify whether to display an area on hover, always or not display it at all
  • selectionAreaSkin - to specify which design to use: filled or outline
  • selectionAreaPadding - to define white space around the checkbox in pixels
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack>
  <StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column" width="50%">
    <Checkbox
      selectionArea="always"
      selectionAreaSkin="outlined"
      selectionAreaPadding="12px 18px"
      checked
    >
      Option 1
    </Checkbox>
    <Checkbox
      selectionArea="always"
      selectionAreaSkin="outlined"
      selectionAreaPadding="12px 18px"
    >
      Option 2
    </Checkbox>
    <Checkbox
      selectionArea="always"
      selectionAreaSkin="outlined"
      selectionAreaPadding="12px 18px"
    >
      Option 3
    </Checkbox>
  </StorybookComponents.Stack>
  <StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column" width="50%">
    <Checkbox
      selectionArea="hover"
      selectionAreaSkin="filled"
      selectionAreaPadding="12px 18px"
      checked
    >
      Option 1
    </Checkbox>
    <Checkbox
      selectionArea="hover"
      selectionAreaSkin="filled"
      selectionAreaPadding="12px 18px"
    >
      Option 2
    </Checkbox>
    <Checkbox
      selectionArea="hover"
      selectionAreaSkin="filled"
      selectionAreaPadding="12px 18px"
    >
      Option 3
    </Checkbox>
  </StorybookComponents.Stack>
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Max lines
featureExamples.description: Use maxLines prop to limit the amount of lines and show ellipsis.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack width="300px" flexDirection="column">
  <Checkbox>
    Checkbox label that wraps to multiple lines
  </Checkbox>
  <Checkbox ellipsis={true} maxLines="1">
    Checkbox label that has max lines applied
  </Checkbox>
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Tooltip
featureExamples.description: Use a tooltip to give added explanation for the checkbox. Use the tooltipContent prop, and control the design with tooltipProps (it accepts all standard <Tooltip/> properties).
featureExamples.example:
<Checkbox
  tooltipContent="Message explaining the select option"
  tooltipProps={{
    placement: 'top-start',
    textAlign: 'start',
  }}
>
  Hover the mouse on a checkbox to see a tooltip
</Checkbox>;

            placeholder={'Select'}
            emptyStateMessage={`Couldn't find: ${value}`}
            predicate={option =>
              option.value.toLowerCase().indexOf(value.toLowerCase()) !== -1
            }
            popoverProps={{
              appendTo: 'window',
            }}
          />
        </FormField>
      </StorybookComponents.Stack>
    </Box>
  );
};
content.description: Autocomplete allows users to select a single item from a predefined list of options. Users can type into the input field to filter the list.
do: Use it to select an item from a list with 10 or more options.
Use it with user-generated data (e.g., a staff member list, custom categories, labels, products, etc.)
dont: Don’t use it when there are fewer than 10 options. Use the <Dropdown/> component instead.

commonUseCaseExamples.title: Custom lists
commonUseCaseExamples.description: To create a custom options layout with avatars, icons, images and more, use the listItemSelectBuilder.

featureExamples.title: Size
featureExamples.description:
Adjust the component size using the size prop. It supports 3 sizes.

  • Give the dropdown more emphasis with the large size.
  • medium is the default size and should be used in most cases.
  • In layouts with a lot of dense content use small.

featureExamples.title: Border
featureExamples.description:
Style the component using the border prop, which supports 4 styles.

  • For forms, use standard.
  • When the component is used to filter, use round.
  • For titles that can be edited on click, use bottomLine.
  • In the Content Manager’s spreadsheet, use none.

featureExamples.title: Status
featureExamples.description:
Control the component's state using the status prop. There are 3 states:

  • error highlights an invalid selection.
  • warning highlights a value that can't be validated or impacts the user's business.
  • loading shows that the server is loading the value.

    • Hide the status suffix and indicate the state with a border color by setting hideStatusSuffix to true.

featureExamples.title: Status message
featureExamples.description:
Add text that explains the status or what action the user should take with the statusMessage prop.

Showing the status message inline, directly below the input is preferred in all default cases.

  • To add an accessible inline message, wrap the component in a <FormField/> and add the statusMessage.
  • To add a status message in a tooltip that requires users to hover on the icon, use the statusMessage prop. Control tooltip placement with tooltipPlacement prop.

    • View more inline status message examples in <FormField/>.

featureExamples.title: Disabled
featureExamples.description: Disable all input interactions with the disabled prop. Use it to highlight unavailable functions.
featureExamples.example: <AutoComplete placeholder="Disabled" disabled />;

featureExamples.title: Affix
featureExamples.description: Explain field value with additional information added to prefix and suffix. Props can contain text, icons and even buttons.

featureExamples.title: Clear button
featureExamples.description: Enable a button that clears the selected value with the clearButton prop. Show it when the field value is optional or often has to be cleared.

featureExamples.title: Fixed header and footer
featureExamples.description: Add a list of related actions to a fixed footer or header area. These areas keep their positions on scroll.

featureExamples.title: List item builders
featureExamples.description:
There are a few props for building custom layouts:

  • Group list items into sections with titles using listItemSectionBuilder.
  • Add text buttons for related list actions with listItemActionBuilder.
  • Build custom options list designs with listItemSelectBuilder.

featureExamples.title: List container dimensions
featureExamples.description:
There are a few ways to control the container size:

  • Specify the max height for longer lists with maxHeightPixels prop.
  • Set the width to 'auto' or 'max-content' to match the content width or specify it in pixels with dropdownWidth prop.
  • Increase the dropdown popover width manually using minWidthPixels prop.

featureExamples.title: Marked option
featureExamples.description: Control what to highlight with a hover state when autocomplete dropdown is opened with the markedOption prop.

featureExamples.title: Infinite scroll
featureExamples.description: Load items gradually with infiniteScroll, loadMore and hasMore props.

featureExamples.title: Text overflow
featureExamples.description:
Control text overflow in the input field itself withtextOverflow. This allows you to clip the content or add ellipsis.

For the dropdown items, the text wraps by default. To add ellipsis, use the listItemSelectBuilder prop.

featureExamples.title: Clear button

featureExamples.title: Options

Provide common suggestions by passing an array of options to a component. A predicate function can be used to filter these options.

In this example, predicate makes the search input case sensitive.

featureExamples.title: Options container dimensions
featureExamples.description:
Control container size with three properties.

  • maxHeightPixels specifies the maximum height for longer lists.
  • dropdownWidth sets the width to "auto" or "max-content" to match the content width or specify it in pixels.
  • minWidthPixels increases the width of the dropdown popover manually.

<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <ColorInput value="#FF0000" status="error" />
  <ColorInput value="#FF0000" status="warning" />
  <ColorInput value="#FF0000" status="loading" />
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Status message
featureExamples.description:
Add text that explains the status or what action the user should take with the statusMessage prop.

Showing the status message inline, directly below the input is preferred in all default cases.

  • To add an accessible inline message, wrap the component in a <FormField/> and add the statusMessage.
  • To add a status message in a tooltip that requires users to hover on the icon, use the statusMessage prop. Control tooltip placement with tooltipPlacement prop.

    • View more inline status message examples in <FormField/>.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column" gap="12px">
    <Text secondary>For all default cases:</Text>
    <FormField status="error" statusMessage="This is an error message.">
      <ColorInput placeholder="See message below" />
    </FormField>
  </StorybookComponents.Stack>
  <StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column" gap="12px">
    <Text secondary>For narrow layouts only:</Text>
    <ColorInput
      placeholder="Hover on status icon"
      status="error"
      statusMessage="This is an error message."
    />
  </StorybookComponents.Stack>
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Disabled
featureExamples.description: Prevent the user from using the color input field with the disabled prop. Use it to indicate that the field is unavailable for editing (e.g., if the element already has a pre-defined color that can't be changed).

featureExamples.title: Popover
featureExamples.description: Adjust the placement and behavior of the color picker popover by using any of the properties in popoverProps. Check the <Popover/> component API for a full list.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack>
  <StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column" gap="6px">
    <Text size="small">Popover placement: Left</Text>
    <ColorInput
      value="#FF4136"
      popoverProps={{
        placement: 'left',
        appendTo: 'viewport',
      }}
    />
  </StorybookComponents.Stack>
  <StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column" gap="6px">
    <Text size="small">Animate: true</Text>
    <ColorInput
      value="#FF4136"
      popoverProps={{
        animate: true,
      }}
    />
  </StorybookComponents.Stack>
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Add color presets
featureExamples.description: Allow users to add new color presets inside the color picker by clicking an "Add color" button. Use a combination of the colorPickerChildren and the onAddColor properties to add this ability.

developerExamples.title: Predefined time validations
developerExamples.description:
The component's validations cover the following cases:

  • formatError: when a user enters a time that’s invalid and impossible to parse.
  • outOfBoundsError: when a user types in a time out of the accepted range. This validation is triggered when the excludePastTimes or filterTime props are enabled.

    • Note: In order for the error to be cleared, use onChange. This way, the error will not show when the user enters a valid time.

developerExamples.title: Custom time validations
developerExamples.description: To apply custom validations to the component, use information returned by onChange and onInvalid props. The onInvalid prop provides validationType and input value parameters.

content.description: Time inputs allow users to to enter or select a specific time value.
do: Use time input to select a specific time. For example, to set an event start time, schedule an appointment, or set an alarm.
dont: Don’t use it to specify duration. Use <NumberInput/> instead.

commonUseCaseExamples.title: Scheduling
commonUseCaseExamples.description: Use the time input together with a <DatePicker/> to schedule specific times for events, appointments, delivery hours, etc.

commonUseCaseExamples.title: Range
commonUseCaseExamples.description: Use the <Range/> component to merge two input fields to specify a time duration.
commonUseCaseExamples.example:
<FormField label="Duration">
  <Range>
    <TimeInput />
    <TimeInput />
  </Range>
</FormField>;

featureExamples.title: Size
featureExamples.description:
Adjust the size of the input using the size prop. 3 sizes are supported:

  • For most common cases, use the default medium.
  • Use large when the time input needs emphasis.
  • In more dense and compact layouts, use small.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <TimeInput size="large" placeholder="Large" />
  <TimeInput size="medium" placeholder="Medium" />
  <TimeInput size="small" placeholder="Small" />
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Width
featureExamples.description:
Control the width of the input with the width property. 2 values are supported:

  • To adjust the width of the field according to the size of the value use the default auto.
  • Fill the parent container completely with 100%.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <StorybookComponents.Stack>
    <TimeInput width="auto" placeholder="Auto" />
  </StorybookComponents.Stack>
  <TimeInput width="100%" placeholder="Full width" />
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Border
featureExamples.description:
Style the component using the border prop. It supports 4 styles:

  • For most common cases, use standard.
  • To build inputs that can be used to filter data, use round.
  • Use bottomLine to create an editable, underlined title field.
  • When a component provides its own hover and focus styles, such as a table or spreadsheet cells, use none.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <TimeInput border="standard" placeholder="Standard" />
  <TimeInput border="round" placeholder="Round" />
  <TimeInput border="bottomLine" placeholder="Bottom Line" />
  <TimeInput border="none" placeholder="None" />
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Status
featureExamples.description:
Control the status of the time input using the status prop. It supports 3 states:

  • error demonstrates that something is missing or the entry was invalid. The conditions for an error status must be defined when using this prop.
  • warning highlights an input value that might have a significant impact to the user or it can't be validated.
  • loading shows when an input value is being uploaded to the server.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <TimeInput status="error" placeholder="Error" />
  <TimeInput status="warning" placeholder="Warning" />
  <TimeInput status="loading" placeholder="Loading" />
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Status message
featureExamples.description:
Add text that explains the status or what action the user should take with the statusMessage prop.

Showing the status message inline, directly below the input is preferred in all default cases.

  • To add an accessible inline message, wrap the component in a <FormField/> and add the statusMessage.
  • To add a status message in a tooltip that requires users to hover on the icon, use the statusMessage prop. Control tooltip placement with tooltipPlacement prop.

    • View more inline status message examples in <FormField/>.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column" gap="12px">
    <Text secondary>For all default cases:</Text>{' '}
    <FormField status="error" statusMessage="This is an error message.">
      <TimeInput placeholder="See message below" />
    </FormField>
  </StorybookComponents.Stack>
  <StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column" gap="12px">
    <Text secondary>For narrow layouts only:</Text>
    <TimeInput
      placeholder="Hover on status icon"
      status="error"
      statusMessage="This is an error message."
    />
  </StorybookComponents.Stack>
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Invalid message
featureExamples.description:
To add predefined validations to the Time Input, use the invalidMessage prop.

The error icon and tooltip message are triggered when a user enters an invalid syntax, e.g., 15:99 am.

To exclude past times from the calendar view, use the excludePastTimes prop. To exclude specific times, use the filterTime prop.

The error message shows in a tooltip on hover over the icon by default. The message can be updated or removed.

Note: When both statusMessage and invalidMessage props are used, the input will display the statusMessage, unless internal validation fails. Then it would display the invalidMessage.
featureExamples.example: <TimeInput invalidMessage="Enter a time in 12 hour format using AM or PM." />;

featureExamples.title: Disabled
featureExamples.description: Disable all input interactions with the disabled prop. Use it to demonstrate that the user cannot select the time.
featureExamples.example: <TimeInput disabled />;

featureExamples.title: Prefix & suffix
featureExamples.description: Add text, icons or a button at the beginning or end of an input field using prefix and suffix.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <TimeInput
    prefix={<Input.Affix>From</Input.Affix>}
    suffix={<Input.Affix>GMT+1</Input.Affix>}
  />
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Locale
featureExamples.description: Specify a correct time formatting (e.g., AM/PM or military time) per country using the locale prop.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <TimeInput locale="en" />
  <TimeInput locale="de" />
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Time style
featureExamples.description:
Control whether to display the time zone info with timeStyle. It supports 2 values:

  • short (the default) displays the time only.
  • long shows the time together with the time zone.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <TimeInput timeStyle="short" />
  <TimeInput timeStyle="long" />
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Step
featureExamples.description:
In a dropdown layout, control the interval between timestamps using the step prop.

By default, the interval between timestamps is 15 minutes.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack>
  <StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column" gap="6px">
    15 min (default):
    <TimeInput step={15} />
  </StorybookComponents.Stack>
  <StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column" gap="6px">
    5 min:
    <TimeInput step={5} />
  </StorybookComponents.Stack>
  <StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column" gap="6px">
    30 min:
    <TimeInput step={30} />
  </StorybookComponents.Stack>
  <StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column" gap="6px">
    60 min:
    <TimeInput step={60} />
  </StorybookComponents.Stack>
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

do: Use it to upload files using drag and drop to a specified region.
Use it to upload single or multiple files.

commonUseCaseExamples.title: Add item
commonUseCaseExamples.description:

content.description: File upload allows users to upload one or multiple files at once. This wrapper opens a native upload dialog box when the user clicks a trigger.
do: Let users upload all types of text or media files.
Let users upload one or more files at once.
Use it to add a file type selection to existing components like <AddItem/>.
dont: Don't use it as a standalone item. It must always wrap a trigger component. For a standalone solution, use <FilePicker/> instead.

commonUseCaseExamples.title: Upload files
commonUseCaseExamples.description: Any library component can be used to open an upload dialog box. Nevertheless, it's better to use buttons or viewer components that have predefined interaction states and can be accessed with the keyboard (for accessibility reasons).
commonUseCaseExamples.example:
<FileUpload multiple accept=".jpeg,.gif,.png">

    </AddItem>

</FileUpload>;

commonUseCaseExamples.title: Add images
commonUseCaseExamples.description: To let users add images, set <ImageViewer/> as the trigger component.
commonUseCaseExamples.example:
<FileUpload multiple accept=".jpeg,.gif,.png">

</FileUpload>;

content.description: Form fields are labels used to tell the user what they need to select or enter in the field of a form. They can indicate if a field is mandatory and can include a tooltip to provide more information.
do: Use it to add a label to the field to tell the user what info they need to enter or select.
Mark required fields as mandatory.
Provide additional information about the form element in a tooltip.
dont: Don’t use it as a title for sections or groups of elements. Use the appropriate <Heading/> component instead.

commonUseCaseExamples.title: Regular form
commonUseCaseExamples.description: Use a top label on forms whenever possible. This creates a clear hierarchy and is the most readable format.
