commonUseCaseExamples.title: Settings panel
commonUseCaseExamples.description: Use a top label or a left label depending on the layout. For example, a left label works best with a single toggle button.

featureExamples.title: Structure
featureExamples.description: A form field consists of label, suffix and children areas. Children areas can include any kind of form element.
featureExamples.example:
<FormField
  label="Label"
  suffix={
    <StorybookComponents.Placeholder>
      Suffix area
    </StorybookComponents.Placeholder>
  }
>
  <StorybookComponents.Placeholder>
    Any form element
  </StorybookComponents.Placeholder>
</FormField>;

featureExamples.title: Label placement
featureExamples.description:
Control the label position with the labelPlacement prop. It supports 3 options:

  • Use top in all common cases.
  • Use left to save vertical space in less spacious layouts. This only works well with short labels. When using, be mindful of localization.
  • For <ToggleSwitch/>, use right.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <FormField label="Top" labelPlacement="top">
    <Input />
  </FormField>
  <FormField label="Left" labelPlacement="left">
    <Input />
  </FormField>
  <FormField label="Right" labelPlacement="right" stretchContent={false}>
    <ToggleSwitch checked />
  </FormField>
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Label alignment
featureExamples.description:
When the field label is placed on the side, its vertical position can be controlled with the labelAlignment prop. It supports 2 options:

  • For larger form elements like <InputArea/> or <RadioGroup/>, use top.
  • Use middle for single line inputs.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack>
  <FormField label="Top" labelPlacement="left" labelAlignment="top">
    <InputArea minHeight="90px" />
  </FormField>
  <FormField label="Middle" labelPlacement="left" labelAlignment="middle">
    <Input />
  </FormField>
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Required
featureExamples.description: Mark mandatory fields with an asterisk by using required.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack>
  <FormField label="Mandatory field" required>
    <Input />
  </FormField>
  <FormField label="Not mandatory field (optional)">
    <Input />
  </FormField>
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Status and message
featureExamples.description:
To change the status and display an inline message below any component, use the status and statusMessage props.

  • For error messages, set the status prop to error.
  • For warning messages, set the status prop to warning.
  • For loading messages, set the status prop to loading.
  • To show helper text, use the statusMessage prop with no status.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <FormField
    labelSize="small"
    label="Label"
    status="error"
    statusMessage="This is an error message."
  >
    <Input />
  </FormField>
  <FormField
    labelSize="small"
    label="Label"
    status="warning"
    statusMessage="This is a warning message."
  >
    <Input />
  </FormField>
  <FormField
    labelSize="small"
    label="Label"
    status="loading"
    statusMessage="This is a loading message."
  >
    <Input />
  </FormField>
  <FormField
    labelSize="small"
    label="Label"
    statusMessage="This is helper text."
  >
    <Input />
  </FormField>
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Additional info
featureExamples.description: Use a tooltip to provide users with more information about the field and what they need to input.
featureExamples.example:
<FormField
  label="Hover over info icon"
  infoContent="This tooltip provides additional info about what the user needs to put in the input field."
>
  <Input />
</FormField>;

featureExamples.title: Suffix
featureExamples.description:
Add a custom element on the top right of the input to provide more options or information. This area accepts any component as a child.

Note: The suffix area replaces the character count; they can’t be used simultaneously.
featureExamples.example:
<FormField
  label="Label"
  suffix={
    <TextButton size="small" suffixIcon={<Icons.ExternalLinkSmall />}>
      Go to External Site
    </TextButton>
  }
>
  <InputArea />
</FormField>;

featureExamples.title: Character count
featureExamples.description: Define the maximum length of the field value by using the charCount prop. Any value over the allowed character count will not be added.

featureExamples.title: Stretch content
featureExamples.description: Control the container width with stretchContent. This property is enabled by default and must be turned off when the form element has a fixed width, like when a <ToggleSwitch/> is used.
featureExamples.example:
<FormField
  label="Not stretched content"
  labelPlacement="right"
  stretchContent={false}
>
  <ToggleSwitch checked />
</FormField>;

featureExamples.title: Text overflow
featureExamples.description:
Use the ellipsis prop for overflow text. The full text will be displayed in a <Tooltip/> when a user hovers over the button. Control the style of the tooltip using the tooltipProps.

To display label in multiple lines, use maxLines to define how many lines should be visible. maxLines can be used together with ellipsis to control after how many lines label would get truncated.

NOTE: it's not recommended to have labels longer than two lines, as the content would become too text heavy.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack>
<SidePanel width="288px">
      <SidePanel.Field>
        <FormField label="This is an example text that overflows and is shown in tooltip">
    <Input placeholder="Placeholder" />
        </FormField>
      </SidePanel.Field>
    </SidePanel>
<SidePanel width="288px">
      <SidePanel.Field>
        <FormField         ellipsis
        maxLines="2" label="This is an example text that fits and is shown in two lines">
    <Input placeholder="Placeholder" />
        </FormField>
      </SidePanel.Field>
    </SidePanel>
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

content.description: Multiselect allows users to enter and display multiple keyword tags.
do: Use it when the site owner needs to enter multiple keywords like names, emails, countries, etc.
Use it as a tag input.
dont: Don’t use it to insert tags in combination with free text. Use <VariableInput/> instead.

commonUseCaseExamples.title: Enter contact emails
commonUseCaseExamples.description:
Multiselect input can be useful for entering contacts or emails.

If combined with advanced list item props, multiselect can provide explicit information, therefore, making multiple keyboard entries easier.

featureExamples.title: Size
featureExamples.description:
Adjust the component size using the size prop. It supports 3 sizes:

  • large is best for onboarding flows, where input needs emphasis.
  • medium (default) – use for most cases.
  • small is appropriate for dense and narrow layouts.

featureExamples.title: Border
featureExamples.description:
Style the component using the border prop. It supports 4 styles:

  • For forms and most common cases, use default.
  • When component is used to filter data, use round.
  • Use bottomLine to create an editable, underlined title field.
  • When a component provides its own hover and focus styles, such as a table or spreadsheet cells, use none.

featureExamples.title: Status
featureExamples.description:
Control the component status using a status prop. It supports 3 states:

  • error demonstrates that a required input is missing something or the entry was invalid.
  • warning highlights a value that might have a significant impact to a user.
  • loading shows when a value is being uploaded to the server.

featureExamples.title: Status message
featureExamples.description:
Add text that explains the status or what action the user should take with the statusMessage prop.

Showing the status message inline, directly below the component is preferred in all default cases.

  • To add an accessible inline message, wrap the component in a <FormField/> and add the statusMessage.
  • To add a status message in a tooltip that requires users to hover on the icon, use the statusMessage prop. Control tooltip placement with tooltipPlacement prop.

    • View more inline status message examples in <FormField/>.

featureExamples.title: Read-only and disabled
featureExamples.description:
Multi select can also be made read-only or disabled entirely.

  • readOnly disables adding or editing, but allows the user to copy the current value. Use it to display URLs, code, etc.
  • disabled removes all interactions and creates a disabled component state. Use it to highlight functions that are unavailable.

featureExamples.title: Action
featureExamples.description: Encourage user engagement by displaying the call to action. To add a <TextButton/>, use the customSuffix property.

featureExamples.title: Select mode
featureExamples.description: Allow users to select only options that are listed with mode prop.

featureExamples.title: Manual input
featureExamples.description: Allow users to enter their own tags using the keyboard with onManuallyInput property.

featureExamples.title: Predicate
featureExamples.description: Build autocomplete features using the predicate property.

featureExamples.title: Reorder
featureExamples.description: Use the onReorder property to allow users to change the order in which keywords are displayed.

content.description: Inputs let users enter short values into a text field. It can be used for forms and tables, or to build other form components like <AutoComplete/> or <NumberInput/>.
do: Use it to insert names, titles, addresses, and other areas where users will enter short bits of text.
Use it to build custom input fields.
dont: Don't use it to insert long paragraphs. Use the <InputArea/> component instead.
Don't use it as a search input. Use the <Search/> component instead.

commonUseCaseExamples.title: Compound input
commonUseCaseExamples.description: When multiple inputs represent the same kinds of data, like phone numbers or addresses, fields can be shown together under a single title using the <Layout/> component.

commonUseCaseExamples.title: Input as a title
commonUseCaseExamples.description: Inputs can also be used as card titles to help organize groups and files. This works best with the bottomLine border.

featureExamples.title: Size
featureExamples.description:
Adjust the size of the input using the size prop. It supports 3 sizes:

  • For most common cases, use the default medium.
  • To emphasize specific inputs in onboarding flows, use large.
  • Use small for more dense and compact layouts.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <Input size="large" placeholder="Large" />
  <Input size="medium" placeholder="Medium" />
  <Input size="small" placeholder="Small" />
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Border
featureExamples.description:
Style the input using the border prop. It supports 4 styles:

  • For forms and most common cases, use standard.
  • To build inputs that can be used to filter data, use round.
  • Use bottomLine to create an editable, underlined title field.
  • When a component provides its own hover and focus styles, such as a table or spreadsheet cells, use none.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <Input border="standard" placeholder="Standard" />
  <Input border="round" placeholder="Round" />
  <Input border="bottomLine" placeholder="Bottom line" />
  <Input border="none" placeholder="None" />
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Status
featureExamples.description:
Control the status of the input using the status prop. It supports 3 states:

  • error demonstrates that a required input is missing something or the entry was invalid.
  • warning highlights an input value that might have a significant impact to a user.
  • loading shows when an input value is being uploaded to the server.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <Input status="error" placeholder="Error" />
  <Input status="warning" placeholder="Warning" />
  <Input status="loading" placeholder="Loading" />
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Status message
featureExamples.description:
Add text that explains the status or what action the user should take with the statusMessage prop.

Showing the status message inline, directly below the input is preferred in all default cases.

  • To add an accessible inline message, wrap the component in a <FormField/> and add the statusMessage.
  • To add a status message in a tooltip that requires users to hover on the icon, use the statusMessage prop. Control tooltip placement with tooltipPlacement prop.

    • View more inline status message examples in <FormField/>.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column" gap="12px">
    <Text secondary>For all default cases:</Text>
    <FormField status="error" statusMessage="This is an error message.">
      <Input placeholder="See message below" />
    </FormField>
  </StorybookComponents.Stack>
  <StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column" gap="12px">
    <Text secondary>For narrow layouts only:</Text>
    <Input
      placeholder="Hover on status icon"
      status="error"
      statusMessage="This is an error message."
      tooltipPlacement="top-end"
    />
  </StorybookComponents.Stack>
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Read-only and disabled
featureExamples.description:
Inputs can also be made read-only or disabled entirely.

  • readOnly disables adding or editing, but allows the user to copy the current value. Use it to display URLs, code, etc.
  • disabledremoves all interactions and creates a disabled input state. Use it to highlight functions that are unavailable.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <Input readOnly value="Read-only" />
  <Input disabled value="Disabled" />
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Prefix & suffix
featureExamples.description: Add text, icons or a button at the beginning or end of a text field using prefix and suffix.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <Input
    prefix={<Input.Affix>https://</Input.Affix>}
    suffix={<Input.Affix>.com</Input.Affix>}
    value=""
  />
  <Input
    prefix={
      <Input.IconAffix>
        <Icons.GitHub />
      </Input.IconAffix>
    }
    suffix={
      <Input.IconAffix>
        <TextButton>Button</TextButton>
      </Input.IconAffix>
    }
    value=""
  />
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Clear button
featureExamples.description: Enable a button that lets users easily clear the input value by using the clearButton prop.

featureExamples.title: Text overflow
featureExamples.description:
Control long text values with the textOverflow prop. There are 2 options:

  • clip (the default) cuts off text that is longer than the input field.
  • ellipsis truncates the additional text with an ellipsis. This is especially useful with the bottomLine input style.
featureExamples.example:
<Input
  textOverflow="ellipsis"
  border="bottomLine"
  value="This is an extremely long sentence that takes up far more space than can fit inside this input field, so it has to be shortened so that the beginning can be read, but with an ellipsis to indicate there is more text than can be shown at once."
/>;

content.description: Images communicate product information to users with visuals.
do: Use them to display images like product thumbnails.
dont: Don’t display photos of users. Use <Avatar/> instead.
Don’t display images that can be uploaded, updated or removed. Use a built-in <ImageViewer/> solution instead.

accessibilityExamples.title: Alt text
accessibilityExamples.description:
By default, all images have empty alt text.

  • For decorative images, leave alt text empty.
  • For informative images that need to be described to screen readers, add alt text which describes the image in context.
  • For images that have links, the alt text should also tell the screen reader where the link goes.

    • Use this alt decision tree to determine whether an image needs alt text.

commonUseCaseExamples.title: Mixed border radius
commonUseCaseExamples.description: Use images with mixed corner radius levels in cases when they touch the edges of cards.

commonUseCaseExamples.title: Product list
commonUseCaseExamples.description: Use images to display product thumbnails in lists and widgets.

featureExamples.title: Dimensions
featureExamples.description: Specify image dimensions in pixels or percentage with width and height props.
featureExamples.example: <Image width="33%" height="180px" />;

featureExamples.title: Border
featureExamples.description: To separate images from backgrounds, enable the image bordershowBorder.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack width="25%">
  <Image showBorder />
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Border radius
featureExamples.description: Control the rounded corners of the image box with the borderRadius prop. Radius levels can be specified for every corner.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack>
  <Image />
  <Image borderRadius={'24px'} />
  <Image borderRadius={'36px 0px 0px 36px'} />
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: States
featureExamples.description: Use the src prop to display a link to a media file. If the src prop is added without a link, the default placeholder shows.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack>
  <Image />
  <Image src="example.jpg" />
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Background fill
featureExamples.description: To remove the background color for PNG images or vector graphics, use the transparent prop.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack>
  <Image fit="contain" height="240" src="example.jpg" />
  <Image fit="contain" height="240" src="example.jpg" transparent />
  <Image fit="contain" src="PromotionalPromoteMarketingHomeEmail.svg" />
  <Image
    fit="contain"
    src="PromotionalPromoteMarketingHomeEmail.svg"
    transparent
  />
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Fit mode
featureExamples.description:
Control how images are displayed when their dimensions don't match the size of their containers with the fit prop. It supports all default object-fit values, but there are four that are most commonly used:

  • contain maintains the aspect ratio while fitting images within containers.
  • cover maintains the aspect ratio and clips images to fill containers.
  • none loads the original image size and positions it in the center of the container.
  • tile repeats images when their dimensions are smaller than the containers.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack>
  <Image fit="contain" height="300" src="example.jpg" />
  <Image fit="cover" height="300" src="example.jpg" />
  <Image fit="none" height="300" src="example.jpg" />
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Position
featureExamples.description: Control image placement inside of a bounding box with the position property. Specify the starting position of the image from where its fit will be defined.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack>
  <Image src="example.jpg" fit="none" position="top" />
  <Image src="example.jpg" fit="none" position="center left" />
  <Image src="example.jpg" fit="none" position="bottom right" />
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

content.description: Image viewers let users display images with built-in functions like upload, update and remove.
do: Use them to upload images, such as event covers.
Use them to display images that can be updated or removed.
dont: Don’t use them to display images that aren't interactive. Use static <Image/> instead.

commonUseCaseExamples.title: Form
commonUseCaseExamples.description: Use image viewer in forms where only a single image can be uploaded at a time, e.g., a cover for an event, group or program.

featureExamples.title: Dimensions
featureExamples.description: Specify the component's dimensions in pixels or by percentage using the width and height properties.
featureExamples.example: <ImageViewer width="35%" height="240px" />;

featureExamples.title: Status
featureExamples.description:
Control the component's status using the status prop. It supports three states:

  • error indicates when an image failed to upload.
  • warning highlights that the media can’t be validated.
  • loading shows that the media file is loading.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack>
  <ImageViewer status="error" />
  <ImageViewer status="warning" />
  <ImageViewer status="loading" />
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Status message
featureExamples.description:
Add text that explains the status or what action the user should take with the statusMessage prop.

Showing the status message inline, directly below the image viewer is preferred in all default cases.

  • To add an accessible inline message, wrap the component in a <FormField/> and add the statusMessage.
  • To add a status message in a tooltip that requires users to hover on the icon, use the statusMessage prop. Control tooltip placement with tooltipPlacement prop.

    • View more inline status message examples in <FormField/>.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column" gap="12px">
    <Text secondary>For all default cases:</Text>
    <FormField status="error" statusMessage="This is an error message.">
      <ImageViewer />
    </FormField>

featureExamples.title: States
featureExamples.description:
Supports two states:

  • No image source - uses <AddItem/> component to upload media in a required way. Use addImageInfo to specify a message to display in a tooltip when users hover over the component.
  • With image source - use imageUrl prop to pass a link to a media file.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack>
  <ImageViewer />
  <ImageViewer imageUrl="example.jpg" />
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Border radius
featureExamples.description: Remove default corner radius with the removeRoundedBorders prop. Use it when component is used as a part of another widget.
featureExamples.example: <ImageViewer imageUrl="example.jpg" removeRoundedBorders />;

featureExamples.title: Disabled
featureExamples.description:
Disable all viewer interactions with the disabled prop. Use it to highlight unavailable functions.

Customize the tooltip's style with all common tooltipProps.
featureExamples.example: <ImageViewer disabled addImageInfo="Message explaining disabled item status" />;

featureExamples.title: Actions
featureExamples.description: Control which actions are visible with the showUpdateButton, showDownloadButton and showRemoveButton props. Tooltip messages explaining the actions can be customized according to their need.
featureExamples.example:
<ImageViewer
  imageUrl="example.jpg"
  showUpdateButton={true}
  showDownloadButton={true}
  showRemoveButton={true}
  updateImageInfo="Change image"
  downloadImageInfo="Download image"
  removeImageInfo="Delete image"
  moreImageInfo="More actions"
/>;

content.description: Tag lists are groups of tag and button components. They show active keywords or filters applied to a data table.
do: Display a summary of applied filters in a table.
Control the applied filters individually or all at once.
dont: Don’t use tag lists outside of the <Table.SubToolbar/> component.
Don’t use tag lists to indicate the status or category of an item. Use <Badge/> instead.

commonUseCaseExamples.title: Applied filters list
commonUseCaseExamples.description: Use a tag list to show which filters are applied in a <Table/>.

featureExamples.title: Structure
featureExamples.description:
A tag list consists of any number of tags followed by 2 action buttons:

  • Use toggleMoreButton to expand/collapse the list.
  • Use actionButton to control bulk list actions (e.g., Clear All).

    • Both buttons are optional. The order of the tags and buttons is fixed.
featureExamples.example:
<TagList
  tags={[
    { id: '1', children: 'Tag 1' },
    { id: '2', children: 'Tag 2' },
    { id: '3', children: 'Tag 3' },
    { id: '4', children: 'Tag 4' },
    { id: '5', children: 'Tag 5' },
  ]}
  toggleMoreButton={(amountOfHiddenTags, isExpanded) => ({
    label: isExpanded ? 'Show Less' : `+${amountOfHiddenTags} More`,
    tooltipContent: !isExpanded && 'Show More',
  })}
  actionButton={{ label: 'Action Button' }}
  onTagRemove={() => {}}
/>;

featureExamples.title: Size
featureExamples.description:
Control the size of entire tag lists with size prop:

  • Use small (default) in all default cases.
  • Use medium in bigger layouts.
  • Use large when tag lists need to be emphasized.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <StorybookComponents.Stack>
    <TagList
      tags={[{ id: '1', children: 'Small' }]}
      actionButton={{ label: 'Small' }}
      onTagRemove={() => {}}
    />
  </StorybookComponents.Stack>
  <StorybookComponents.Stack>
    <TagList
      size="medium"
      tags={[{ id: '1', children: 'Medium' }]}
      actionButton={{ label: 'Medium' }}
      onTagRemove={() => {}}
    />
  </StorybookComponents.Stack>

  <StorybookComponents.Stack>
    <TagList
      size="large"
      tags={[{ id: '1', children: 'Large' }]}
      actionButton={{ label: 'Large' }}
      onTagRemove={() => {}}
    />
  </StorybookComponents.Stack>
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Tag props
featureExamples.description:
Customize individual tags with <Tag/> component props:

  • Set the color of a tag using theme.
  • Display a thumbnail inside a tag using thumb.
  • Switch tag to a disabled state using disabled.
  • Show or hide a close button on the right side of a tag using removable .
  • Set a max tag width in px using maxWidth. If a label is longer, text gets truncated with ellipses.

    • See <Tag/> for a full prop description.
featureExamples.example:
<TagList
  tags={[
    {
      id: '1',
      theme: 'success',
      children: 'theme',
    },
    {
      id: '2',
      children: 'thumb',
      thumb: (
        <Avatar
          imgProps={{
            src: 'AvatarExample1.jpg',
          }}
          size="size18"
        />
      ),
    },
    {
      id: '3',
      disabled: true,
      children: 'disabled',
    },
    {
      id: '4',
      removable: false,
      children: 'removable',
    },
    {
      id: '5',
      maxWidth: 100,
      children: 'maxWidth',
    },
  ]}
  maxVisibleTags="5"
  onTagRemove={() => {}}
/>;

featureExamples.title: Toggle more button props
featureExamples.description:
Control the appearance of toggleMoreButton with skin and priority props.

Set its skin as standard and priority as secondary to emphasize the component actionButton on the left.
featureExamples.example:
<TagList
  tags={[
    { id: '1', children: 'Tag 1' },
    { id: '2', children: 'Tag 2' },
    { id: '3', children: 'Tag 3' },
    { id: '4', children: 'Tag 4' },
    { id: '5', children: 'Tag 5' },
  ]}
  maxVisibleTags={3}
  actionButton={{ label: 'Action Button' }}
  toggleMoreButton={(amountOfHiddenTags, isExpanded) => ({
    label: isExpanded ? 'Show Less' : `+${amountOfHiddenTags} More`,
    tooltipContent: !isExpanded && 'Show More',
    skin: 'standard',
    priority: 'secondary',
  })}
  onTagRemove={() => {}}
/>;

featureExamples.title: Max visible tags
featureExamples.description:
Limit the number of visible tags with maxVisibleTags prop (default is 3).

Use it to fit a tag list in one line and keep the layout compact.

If tags surpass the limit, give an option to expand the full list with toggleMoreButton prop.

Note that if the component width is larger than the parent container, it will display on multiple lines when expanded.

  tags={[
    { id: '1', children: 'Tag 1' },
    { id: '2', children: 'Tag 2' },
    { id: '3', children: 'Tag 3' },
    { id: '4', children: 'Tag 4' },
    { id: '5', children: 'Tag 5' },
    { id: '6', children: 'Tag 6' },
    { id: '7', children: 'Tag 7' },
    { id: '8', children: 'Tag 8' },
    { id: '9', children: 'Tag 9' },
    { id: '10', children: 'Tag 10' },
    { id: '11', children: 'Tag 11' },
    { id: '12', children: 'Tag 12' },
  ]}
  maxVisibleTags={3}
  toggleMoreButton={(amountOfHiddenTags, isExpanded) => ({
    label: isExpanded ? 'Show Less' : `+${amountOfHiddenTags} More`,

/>;

featureExamples.description: Define whether the list is expanded initially with an initiallyExpanded prop.

do: Store components in <Page.Footer/> that allow users to navigate between chunks of content or entirely different pages.
Store components in it that allow users to act on the page, such as submit or cancel actions.
Use it at the very bottom of the page.
dont: Don’t use it to store content at the top or the middle of a page. Use <Page.Header/> or <Page.Content/> instead.

commonUseCaseExamples.title: Pagination
commonUseCaseExamples.description: Use page footer to insert <Pagination/> at the bottom center of the page.

                </Layout>

              <Button>Save</Button>

featureExamples.title: Source
featureExamples.description:
Pass a link to the audio file source with src prop. Component detects your file format from the extension.

In situations where extraction does not work, specify a file format with format prop.

featureExamples.title: Preload
featureExamples.description:
Specify what to download when component is rendered with a preload prop. It supports 3 values:

  • auto downloads the full file.
  • metadata downloads the file's metadata only. The full file will be downloaded when play is clicked.
  • none is used when nothing should be preloaded. The file and its data will be downloaded when the user clicks play.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <AudioPlayer preload="auto" src="AudioTrack2.mp3" />
  <AudioPlayer preload="metadata" src="AudioTrack2.mp3" />
  <AudioPlayer preload="none" src="AudioTrack2.mp3" />
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Structure
featureExamples.description:
Card layouts can vary, but they can include up to four related components:

  • <Card.Header/>
  • <SectionHeader/>
  • <Card.Content/>
  • <Card.Divider/>
featureExamples.example:
<Card>
  <Card.Header title="Card header"></Card.Header>
  <SectionHeader title="Section header" />
  <Card.Content>
    <StorybookComponents.Placeholder height="120px">
      Card content
    </StorybookComponents.Placeholder>
  </Card.Content>
</Card>;

featureExamples.title: Header
featureExamples.description:
The <Card.Header/> communicates what the card is about. It can include three elements:

  • title
  • subtitle
  • suffix

    • The suffix can be a button or toggle component.
featureExamples.example:
<Card>
  <Card.Header
    title="Title"
    subtitle="Subtitle"
    suffix={<TextButton>Suffix</TextButton>}
  ></Card.Header>
  <Card.Divider />
  <Card.Content>
    <Box height="120px"/>
  </Card.Content>
</Card>;

featureExamples.title: Section header
featureExamples.description:
The <SectionHeader/> divides card content into scannable sections. It can include two elements:

  • title
  • suffix

    • Find more information in <SectionHeader/> story.
featureExamples.example:
<Card>
  <Card.Header title="Title" />
  <SectionHeader
    title="Section header title"
    suffix={<TextButton size="small">Suffix</TextButton>}
  ></SectionHeader>
  <Card.Content>
    <Box height="120px" />
  </Card.Content>
</Card>;

featureExamples.title: Content
featureExamples.description: Cards can support any type of content. For example, text, radio buttons, and tables all can be used in cards as child components.
featureExamples.example:
<Card>
  <Card.Header title="Title" />
  <Card.Divider />
  <Card.Content>
    <StorybookComponents.Placeholder height="120px">
      Content
    </StorybookComponents.Placeholder>
  </Card.Content>
</Card>;

featureExamples.title: Divider
featureExamples.description:
Dividers separate different content sections within cards.

When there's no <SectionHeader/>, use a divider to separate the header from other content.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <Card>
    <Card.Header title="Title" />
    <Card.Divider />
    <Card.Content>
      <Box height="120px" />
    </Card.Content>
  </Card>
  <Card>
    <Card.Header title="Title" />
    <Card.Divider />
    <Card.Content>
      <Layout>
        <Cell span={12}>
          <Box height="120px" />
        </Cell>
        <Cell span={12}>
          <Card.Divider />
        </Cell>
        <Cell span={12}>
          <Box height="120px" />
        </Cell>
      </Layout>
    </Card.Content>
  </Card>
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Controls
featureExamples.description: Add the <CloseButton/> (with a default or a help icon) to cards using the controls prop.

do: Arrange elements vertically or horizontally.

featureExamples.title: Padding
featureExamples.description:
Control the amount of white space around child elements inside a box. Padding can be defined by:

featureExamples.title: Margin

Control the amount of white space around the box component itself with different properties.

featureExamples.title: Color

featureExamples.title: Border

  • borderRadius specifies the corner radius.

do: Use it to display text paragraphs formed from a single sentence, or multiple sentences.
Use it to display form element values and labels.
dont: Don’t use it as a title for a section or a widget. Use <Heading/> instead.
Don’t use it to highlight status, use <Badge/> instead.

accessibilityExamples.title: Formatting
accessibilityExamples.description:
For better readability and accessibility:

  • Use either small or medium text size for all running text.
  • Keep text left-aligned (avoid center alignment, or don't overuse it).
  • Avoid lines longer than 75 characters in any language.
  • Divide long text into lists or short paragraphs.
accessibilityExamples.example:
Do: To ensure that text is easy to read:
  • Use font size that meets accessibility criteria.
  • Divide text into shorter paragraphs or lists.
  • Do not exceed 75 characters of line width in any language.
  • Use left-alignment.
 Don't: To ensure that text in a UI is easy to read, consider font size, paragraph length, line width, and text alignment. The font size should meet accessibility criteria, and the text should be divided into shorter paragraphs or lists. Line width should not exceed 75 characters in any language to enhance reading speed and comprehension. Lastly, text should be left-aligned, as center-aligned text is less readable. ;

accessibilityExamples.title: Contrast
accessibilityExamples.description:
All text should have a contrast ratio of at least 4.5:1, compared to its background.

For default running text:

  • Use standard and secondary skins on white and light backgrounds.
  • Use light and light secondary on dark backgrounds.
accessibilityExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column" gap="0px">
  <Box direction="vertical" padding="12px" backgroundColor="D80">
    <Text>Standard skin on white background.</Text>
    <Text secondary>Standard secondary skin on white background.</Text>
  </Box>
  <Box direction="vertical" padding="12px" backgroundColor="D10">
    <Text light>Light skin on dark background.</Text>
    <Text light secondary>
      Light secondary skin on dark background.
    </Text>
  </Box>
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

commonUseCaseExamples.title: Inline button
commonUseCaseExamples.description: Use inline <Box/> to place buttons or other elements inline to text.
commonUseCaseExamples.example:
<Text>
  Set up subscriptions, memberships or package plans to sell on your site.
  <Box inline paddingLeft="SP1">
    <TextButton underline="always">Learn more about Pricing Plans</TextButton>
  </Box>
</Text>;

commonUseCaseExamples.title: Show more
commonUseCaseExamples.description:
Toggle maxLines prop value to recreate 'Show more / Show less' behavior for text paragraphs.

This is a more accessible way to handle text overflow than using a tooltip only, since keyboard users can't access the complete text inside the tooltip.

featureExamples.title: Size
featureExamples.description:
Control the size of the text with the size prop. It supports 3 sizes:

  • medium is the default for all common cases of running text.
  • small is for field labels and secondary content.
  • tiny is for short messages of minor importance.

    • Note: Use tiny in exceptional cases only, as it's hard to read, and not recommended for accessibility.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <Text size="medium">
    Medium size is a default size that's used most of the time.
  </Text>
  <Text size="small">
    Small size is used where medium doesn't fit or content is less important.
  </Text>
  <Text size="tiny">
    Tiny size is used when there's no space or it's the last thing users need to
    see.
  </Text>
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Weight
featureExamples.description:
Control the weight of the text with the weight prop. It supports 3 weights:

  • bold emphasizes running text.
  • normal is for form field values and button labels.
  • thin is the default for all regular paragraphs.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <Text weight="bold">Bold weight is meant to emphasize running text.</Text>
  <Text weight="normal">
    Normal weight is for form field values and buttons.
  </Text>
  <Text weight="thin">
    Thin weight is for running text. Use it for all regular paragraphs. 
  </Text>
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Skin
featureExamples.description:
Control the color of text with the skin prop. It supports 6 skins:

  • standard
  • premium
  • success
  • error
  • disabled
  • primary

    • standard skin can be placed on backgrounds with color. All other skins can be used only on white or gray backgrounds.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <Text skin="standard">Standard skin appears in all regular texts.</Text>
  <Text skin="premium">
    Premium skin calls users to upgrade to get unlimited features.
  </Text>
  <Text skin="success">
    Success skin indicates that everything went smooth.
  </Text>
  <Text skin="error">Error skin alerts users that something went wrong.</Text>
  <Text skin="disabled">
    Disabled skin indicates that something cannot be accessed.
  </Text>
  <Text skin="primary">Primary skin is for inline links.</Text>
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Light
featureExamples.description: Invert text color so it can be used on a dark background with the light prop. It affects standard and disabled skins only.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <Text>Dark text is used on light backgrounds.</Text>
  <Box backgroundColor="D10">
    <Text light>Light text is used on dark backgrounds.</Text>
  </Box>
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Secondary
featureExamples.description: Emphasize content hierarchy by setting running text priority to secondary. It applies lower contrast font color for standard skin text only.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <Text skin="standard" secondary>
    Dark secondary text is used where it's less important than standard text.
  </Text>
  <Box backgroundColor="D10">

      background.
    </Text>
  </Box>

featureExamples.title: Text overflow
featureExamples.description:
Handle text overflow by wrapping text, truncating it or doing both.

By default, text wraps into any number of lines. With ellipsis enabled, it will truncate to fit the width of the parent container. Specify maxLines to truncate text after a specified number of rows.

Always provide full text content to view:

  • The most accessible pattern is to add a 'Show more' button which expands the full text.
  • Show full text on mouse hover with showTooltip prop. Control tooltip style by passing all default <Tooltip/> properties via tooltipProps.

featureExamples.description: Render text as a custom HTML tag by using the tagName prop.
featureExamples.example: <Text tagName="div">This text will be rendered as a "div" element.</Text>;

featureExamples.description: Use a default <a> HTML tag to add an inline link to a sentence.

content.description: Headings are titles for the main sections of a page. They help users understand what a page or section is about at a glance.
do: Use headings to describe each section on a page.
Keep the heading text short and clear.
Keep the entire heading text visible at all times. Make sure it doesn't get truncated with an ellipsis.
Follow a sequential, descending heading order, and do not skip levels.
dont: Don’t use headings for paragraphs of text or titles with multiple sentences. Use <Text/> instead.
Don't use headings for content that isn’t a heading.

accessibilityExamples.title: Heading structure
accessibilityExamples.description:
All pages must have a logical, descending heading structure that doesn't skip levels.

  • Each page should have an <h1> as the main page title, and the first page heading. It should describe what the page is about.
  • Use only one <h1> per page.
  • Use <h2> for sections of content and for modal headings.
  • Use <h3> for subsections.
  • Don't skip heading levels.

    • When necessary, use the as prop to override the default heading tag without changing the design.
accessibilityExamples.example:
<Page>
  <Page.Header title="H1" />
  <Page.Content>
    <Layout>
      <Cell span={8}>
        <Card stretchVertically={false}>
          <Card.Header
            title={
              <Heading size="medium" as="h2">
                Card title rendered as H2
              </Heading>
            }
          />
          <Card.Divider />
          <Card.Content>
            <Box height="120px" direction="vertical" gap="12px">
              <Heading size="tiny" as="h3">
                Card section title rendered as H3
              </Heading>
              <StorybookComponents.Placeholder height="24px" />
              <Heading size="tiny" as="h3">
                H3
              </Heading>
              <StorybookComponents.Placeholder height="24px" />
            </Box>
          </Card.Content>
        </Card>
      </Cell>
      <Cell span={4}>
        <Card stretchVertically={true}>
          <Card.Header
            title={
              <Heading size="medium" as="h2">
                H2
              </Heading>
            }
          />
          <Card.Divider />
          <Card.Content>
            <StorybookComponents.Placeholder height="120px" />
          </Card.Content>
        </Card>
      </Cell>
    </Layout>
  </Page.Content>
</Page>;

featureExamples.title: Size
featureExamples.description:
Control the size of a heading with the size prop.

  • extraLarge (heading tag – h1)
  • large (h2)
  • medium (h3)
  • small (h4)
  • tiny (h5)
  • extraTiny (h6)

    • Note: Building a page with proper heading structure is essential for accessibility. If the heading size has a tag that doesn’t fit the structure, it should be overridden using the as prop (see the 'Custom HTML tag' section).
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <Heading size="extraLarge">XL - Page Title (e.g., Contact List)</Heading>
  <Heading size="large">L - Modal title (e.g., Create a new contact)</Heading>
  <Heading size="medium">M - Card title (e.g., Subscribers)</Heading>
  <Heading size="small">S - Page section title (e.g., Contact info)</Heading>
  <Heading size="tiny">T - Card section title (e.g., Notes)</Heading>
  <Heading size="extraTiny">XT - Caption (e.g., Last activity)</Heading>
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Light
featureExamples.description: Invert the skin of a heading with the light prop. Use this skin for headings on backgrounds with colors or images.

<StorybookComponents.Background skin="dark">
  <StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column" padding="30px">
    <Heading size="extraLarge" light>
      XL - Page Title (e.g., Contact List)
    </Heading>
    <Heading size="large" light>
      L - Modal title (e.g., Create a new contact)
    </Heading>
    <Heading size="medium" light>
      M - Card title (e.g., Subscribers)
    </Heading>
    <Heading size="small" light>
      S - Page section title (e.g., Contact info)
    </Heading>
    <Heading size="tiny" light>
      T - Card section title (e.g., Notes)
    </Heading>
    <Heading size="extraTiny" light>
      XT - Caption (e.g., Last activity)
    </Heading>
  </StorybookComponents.Stack>
</StorybookComponents.Background>;

featureExamples.title: Ellipsis
featureExamples.description:
By default, the header wraps if the text is too long, but can be truncated at the end of a sentence with the ellipsis prop.

Note: For accessibility, avoid using the ellipsis prop on headings. Keep all heading text visible on the screen at all times.
featureExamples.example:

  </Heading>
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Children
featureExamples.description: Render any kind of component within the <Heading> tag. This is most commonly used to display an alternative style of text inline with the title.

featureExamples.title: Custom HTML tag
featureExamples.description:
Render the heading as an HTML tag with the as prop.

  • Using <h1> to <h6> overrides the default size heading tag. This is useful for creating an accessible page heading structure without changing the design.
  • <div> or <span> can be used when a heading shouldn't be perceived as a title.

    • All attributes will be passed to the rendered HTML tag.
featureExamples.example:
<Heading size="medium" as="h1">
  Medium size heading that appears as the main page header h1
</Heading>;

content.description: Live region is a mechanism that broadcasts a message for screen reader users to inform them about the change in the page layout or the status.
do: Use it to inform users with visual impairments about change in page content
Use it to inform users with visual impairments about page status change without moving users' focus
dont: Don’t use it when triggered action moves user focus to another element, for example to a newly created item. Use <LiveRegion/> when user focus remains where it is, but users must be aware of the changes that happened on the page.
Don’t use it to announce the opening of menus, modals or notifications. These types of announcements are a built-in definition of components.
Don’t use it to announce dynamic content that's not critical. Avoid adding unnecessary noise for assistive technologies.

commonUseCaseExamples.title: Remove item
commonUseCaseExamples.description: Use live region to inform screen reader users about items removed from the page.

commonUseCaseExamples.title: Duplicate item
commonUseCaseExamples.description: Use live region to inform screen reader users about duplicated items added to the page.

commonUseCaseExamples.title: Filter Table
commonUseCaseExamples.description: Use live region to inform users about the number of items that match their filter criteria.

content.title: LiveRegion

featureExamples.title: Broadcast
featureExamples.description: Specify a message to announce for screen reader users with broadcast prop.

featureExamples.title: Role
featureExamples.description:
Specify how urgently a message should be broadcasted with role prop.

There are 2 roles types:

  • status (default) - use it when it’s important that user receives updates about changes in the region, but not so rapidly that natural flow would be interrupted. Screen reader will announce a message after the current message is delivered.
  • alert - use for time sensitive and critical notifications that require immediate users attention. Message will be announced right away, even if screen reader is currently in the middle of a sentence. As such, it can be disruptive and should be used sparingly.

commonUseCaseExamples.title: Tabs
commonUseCaseExamples.description: <Tabs/> can be used to show more content with the same hierarchy level on the same page. Use <Page.Tail/> to fix tabs below the page header so visitors can navigate between content.

commonUseCaseExamples.title: Form layout: two-thirds
commonUseCaseExamples.description: For form page layouts, use an 8 column layout and keep 4 columns blank. This makes it easier to scan.

commonUseCaseExamples.title: Form layout: two-thirds with a sidebar column
commonUseCaseExamples.description: Use a <Layout/> grid to construct a ⅔ form layout that exposes primary and secondary content at the same time. To fix the sidebar's position while scrolling through the main page content, use <Page.Sticky/>.

commonUseCaseExamples.title: Table
commonUseCaseExamples.description: Use <Page.Sticky/> to fix the position of the content to a specific part of the page. For example, fixing the column titles of a table so visitors can sort and filter easily.

commonUseCaseExamples.title: 2 column list
commonUseCaseExamples.description: Use a 2-column page layout to list features, tools or products. This layout works well for items that have relatively long titles and descriptions.

commonUseCaseExamples.title: Dashboard

featureExamples.description: Set page height using viewport height unit (vh). By default, page height should equal 100vh (full screen size). If the page has a Business Manager top bar navigation, set the page height to calc(100vh-48px).

featureExamples.title: Width
featureExamples.description:
Add constraints to content width with the following props:

  • minWidth specifies the minimum content width.
  • maxWidth specifies the maximum content width. When the limit is reached, the side margins stretch and the content aligns to the center of the page.

    • By default, the page minimum width is 864px and the maximum width is 1248px (plus 48px padding on the sides). These values should be used across all Business Manager pages but can be changed for other use cases.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">

    <Page.Header
      title="Maximum width"
      subtitle="The maximum width for Business Manager Apps is 1248 pixels."
    />
    <Page.Content>
      <StorybookComponents.Placeholder height="180px" />
    </Page.Content>
  </Page>
  <Page minWidth={864} maxWidth={864}>
    <Page.Header
      title="Minimum width"
      subtitle="Minimum width for Business Manager Apps  is 864 pixels"
    />
    <Page.Content>
      <StorybookComponents.Placeholder height="180px" />
    </Page.Content>
  </Page>
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Side padding
featureExamples.description: Control left and right content padding with the sidePadding prop. The default value is 48px and should be used across all Business Manager pages. The default padding can be changed for other use cases.
featureExamples.example:

    <Page.Header title="Custom padding" />
    <Page.Content>
      <StorybookComponents.Placeholder height="180px" />
    </Page.Content>
  </Page>
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.description: The <Page.Header/> sticks to the top of the page and minimizes when visitors scroll down. This default behavior can't be changed.

featureExamples.title: Horizontal scroll
featureExamples.description:
Enable horizontal scroll with the horizontalScroll prop.

featureExamples.description:
Emphasize new or top items with a customizable label in the top left corner using the badge property.

Note that adding a badge increases the marketing layout's height. To keep layouts that are displayed in a row aligned, you can use the hiddenBadge property to add extra height to other layouts.

featureExamples.title: Vertical alignment
featureExamples.description:
Control how content is vertically aligned with the alignItems property. It supports two values:

  • center (default) centers the content vertically.
  • stretch vertically stretches content to match the height of the image.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <Card>
    <MarketingLayout
      title="Centered"
      description="This layout  centers its content vertically to the image on the right"
      actions={<Button size="small">Action</Button>}
      image={<Image height="180px" />}
    />
  </Card>
  <Card>
    <MarketingLayout
      alignItems="stretch"
      title="Stretched"
      description="This layout  stretches its content to fill the container instead of the default centered alignment."
      actions={<Button size="small">Action</Button>}
      image={<Image height="180px" />}
    />
  </Card>
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

content.demo:
<Box align="center">
  <Loader />
</Box>;
content.description: Loader is used to show users when an action is being processed.
do: Use to show that the requested action has started and will be completed soon, like changes on a page being saved.
Use when task completion time is unknown.
Place in the vertical and horizontal center of a layout.
dont: Don't use for an initial load of page content when you know how the final result will look. Use <Skeleton/> instead.
Don't use for processes that have a detected completion time or require a long time to complete. Use <CircularProgressBar/> or <LinearProgressBar/> instead.
Don't show multiple loaders on the page at a time. Use <Skeleton/> instead.

commonUseCaseExamples.title: Load more items
commonUseCaseExamples.description: Use loader to indicate that more items are being loaded to a list as a user scrolls down a component or layout, e.g., inside a <Table/>.

commonUseCaseExamples.title: Triggered action in process
commonUseCaseExamples.description: Add a loader inside of a <Button/> to inform users that the action has started and is currently being processed.

commonUseCaseExamples.title: Save page changes
commonUseCaseExamples.description: Use a loader to indicate that changes a user made on the page are being saved.

featureExamples.title: Size
featureExamples.description:
Adjust loader size using the size prop. It supports 4 sizes:

  • large - use for a full page, like when saving applied changes.
  • medium (default) - use for a specific area inside of a page.
  • small - use in larger components, like a table or a modal.
  • tiny - use in smaller components, like a button.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection='column' gap='48px'>
  <Loader size="large" />
  <Loader size="medium" />
  <Loader size="small" />
  <Loader size="tiny" />
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Color
featureExamples.description:
Change the colors of the loader circle with the color prop. There are 2 color options:

  • blue (default) - use on white and light grey backgrounds.
  • white - use on dark backgrounds.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <Box backgroundColor="D80" align="center" padding="SP4">
    <Loader color="blue" />
  </Box>
  <Box backgroundColor="D10" align="center" padding="SP4">
    <Loader color="white" />
  </Box>
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Status message
featureExamples.description:
Show the process status using the statusMessage prop. The message is displayed when a user mouse hovers over the loader.

Note: users navigating with a keyboard will not be able to see the message.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column" padding="48px">
  <Loader statusMessage="Uploading" />
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Text
featureExamples.description: Add a descriptive label below a loader with the text prop. Use it to explain what is happening when additional info is required.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column" padding="48px">
  <Loader text="Loading..." />
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

content.description: Side panel is a component that presents supplementary information, navigation options, or controls alongside or overlaying the main content of the page.
do: Display supplementary actions or settings that affect the main page content, such as data filters.
Display tools that can be used on the page.
Provide more details in context.
Allow to interact with the main page when side panel is open.
dont: Don't display content while blocking interactions on the main page. Use <Modal/> instead.

commonUseCaseExamples.title: Settings panel
commonUseCaseExamples.description: Use side panel to create settings panels that allow users to control the design and behavior aspects of their app.
commonUseCaseExamples.example:
<SidePanel onCloseButtonClick={() => {}} skin="floating" width="288px">
  <SidePanel.Header title="Button Settings" />
  <SidePanel.Field>
    <FormField label="Choose what displays">
      <Dropdown
        size="small"
        selectedId={0}
        options={[
          { id: 0, value: 'Text and icon' },
          { id: 1, value: 'Icon only' },

          { id: 3, value: 'Nothing' },

      />

  </SidePanel.Field>
  <SidePanel.Field>
    <FieldSet

      columns="auto 30px 30px"
      gap="small"

    >

      <IconButton size="small" priority="secondary">
        <Icons.ReplaceSmall />
      </IconButton>
      <IconButton size="small" priority="secondary">
        <Icons.DeleteSmall />
      </IconButton>
    </FieldSet>
  </SidePanel.Field>
  <SidePanel.Field>
    <FormField label="Links to">
      <Button
        size="small"
        priority="secondary"
        fullWidth
        suffixIcon={<Icons.LinkSmall />}
      >
        Choose a link
      </Button>
    </FormField>
  </SidePanel.Field>
</SidePanel>;

commonUseCaseExamples.title: Data filter
commonUseCaseExamples.description: Use side panels to display data filters. When opened, the panels should slide in from the right side of the screen. Add close buttons in the header and/or footer that can be used to close the panel.

commonUseCaseExamples.title: Quick view
commonUseCaseExamples.description:
Use side panels to provide quick views of list items.

Panels can either push the page content aside or overlay it, depending on the use case:

  • Overlay content when part of the page’s content can be covered.
  • Push content aside when the user should see all the information and actions on the main page.

commonUseCaseExamples.title: Composer actions
commonUseCaseExamples.description: Use side panels to display composer settings and actions. These should be anchored to the left edge of the screen since they're opened through the <ComposerSidebar/>.

featureExamples.title: Structure
featureExamples.description:
Side panels are composed of up to four compound components:

  • <SidePanel.Header/>
  • <SidePanel.Content/>
  • <SidePanel.Divider/>
  • <SidePanel.Footer/>

    • All of these components are optional.
featureExamples.example:
<SidePanel onCloseButtonClick={() => {}}>
  <SidePanel.Header title="Header" />
  <SidePanel.Content>
    <StorybookComponents.Placeholder height="480px">
      Content
    </StorybookComponents.Placeholder>
  </SidePanel.Content>
  <SidePanel.Footer>
    <StorybookComponents.Placeholder height="36px" >
      Footer
    </StorybookComponents.Placeholder>
  </SidePanel.Footer>
</SidePanel>;

featureExamples.title: Skin
featureExamples.description:
Control the component style with skin prop:

  • standard is the default style used in all common cases.
  • floating is used for settings panels that float on top of content in editor platforms (Wix or Wix Studio).
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack>
  <SidePanel onCloseButtonClick={() => {}}>
    <SidePanel.Header title="Standard" />
    <SidePanel.Content>
      <StorybookComponents.Stack height="480px" />
    </SidePanel.Content>
  </SidePanel>
  <SidePanel onCloseButtonClick={() => {}} skin="floating" width="288px">
    <SidePanel.Header title="Floating" />
    <SidePanel.Content>
      <StorybookComponents.Stack height="492px" />
    </SidePanel.Content>
  </SidePanel>
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Width
featureExamples.description: Set the side panel’s width using the width property. The default width is 420px.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack>
  <SidePanel onCloseButtonClick={() => {}} width="300px">
    <SidePanel.Header title="Narrow panel" />
    <SidePanel.Content>
      <StorybookComponents.Stack height="360px" />
    </SidePanel.Content>
  </SidePanel>
  <SidePanel onCloseButtonClick={() => {}} width="600px">
    <SidePanel.Header title="Wide panel" />
    <SidePanel.Content>
      <StorybookComponents.Stack height="360px" />
    </SidePanel.Content>
  </SidePanel>
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Height
featureExamples.description:
By default, panel height depends on the amount of content it contains. To define the maximum height it can grow to use maxHeight property.

Fix the panel height to a specific number with height property.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack>
  <SidePanel onCloseButtonClick={() => {}} maxHeight="480px">
    <SidePanel.Header title="No height set" />
    <SidePanel.Content>
      <StorybookComponents.Placeholder height="40px" />
    </SidePanel.Content>
  </SidePanel>
  <SidePanel onCloseButtonClick={() => {}} height="480px">
    <SidePanel.Header title="Fixed height set" />
    <SidePanel.Content>
      <StorybookComponents.Placeholder height="40px" />
    </SidePanel.Content>
  </SidePanel>
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Padding
featureExamples.description:
Content padding is enabled in the side panel by default, but can be disabled with the noPadding property for:

  • <SidePanel.Content/>
  • <SidePanel.Footer/>

    • The padding can be removed to display lists or other components with built-in padding.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack>
  <SidePanel onCloseButtonClick={() => {}}>
    <SidePanel.Header title="With padding" />
    <SidePanel.Content>
      <StorybookComponents.Placeholder height="360px" />
    </SidePanel.Content>
    <SidePanel.Footer>
      <StorybookComponents.Placeholder height="42px" />
    </SidePanel.Footer>
  </SidePanel>
  <SidePanel onCloseButtonClick={() => {}}>
    <SidePanel.Header title="No padding" />
    <SidePanel.Content noPadding={true}>
      <StorybookComponents.Placeholder height="360px" />
    </SidePanel.Content>
    <SidePanel.Footer noPadding={true}>
      <StorybookComponents.Placeholder height="42px" />
    </SidePanel.Footer>
  </SidePanel>
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Dividers
featureExamples.description:
Dividers are enabled in the side panel by default but can be disabled using the showDivider property for:

  • <SidePanel.Header/>
  • <SidePanel.Footer/>

    • Always show dividers in the side panel if users have the option to scroll vertically inside the panel.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack>
  <SidePanel onCloseButtonClick={() => {}}>
    <SidePanel.Header title="With divider" />
    <SidePanel.Content>
      <StorybookComponents.Stack height="360px" />
    </SidePanel.Content>
    <SidePanel.Footer>
      <StorybookComponents.Stack height="42px" />
    </SidePanel.Footer>
  </SidePanel>
  <SidePanel onCloseButtonClick={() => {}}>
    <SidePanel.Header title="No divider" showDivider={false} />
    <SidePanel.Content>
      <StorybookComponents.Stack height="360px" />
    </SidePanel.Content>
    <SidePanel.Footer showDivider={false}>
      <StorybookComponents.Stack height="42px" />
    </SidePanel.Footer>
  </SidePanel>
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Header
featureExamples.description:
Customize the side panel’s header using these properties:

  • title
  • subtitle
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <SidePanel onCloseButtonClick={() => {}}>
    <SidePanel.Header title="Title" showDivider={true} />
  </SidePanel>
  <SidePanel onCloseButtonClick={() => {}}>
    <SidePanel.Header title="Title" subtitle="Subtitle" showDivider={true} />
  </SidePanel>
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Header Actions
featureExamples.description:
Header has these properties for actions available:

  • infoTooltipContent - provides additional details or an explanation in a tooltip
  • onHelpButtonClick- allows users to access help articles and contextual information
  • onBackButtonClick- allows users to navigate back in the Side Panel
  • backButtonDescription - sets content of the back button's tooltip
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <SidePanel onCloseButtonClick={() => {}}>
    <SidePanel.Header
      title="Title"
      subtitle="Subtitle"
      infoTooltipContent="Additional info here"
      showDivider={true}
    />
  </SidePanel>
  <SidePanel onCloseButtonClick={() => {}} onHelpButtonClick={() => {}}>
    <SidePanel.Header title="Title" subtitle="Subtitle" showDivider={true} />
  </SidePanel>
  <SidePanel onCloseButtonClick={() => {}} onBackButtonClick={() => {}} backButtonDescription="Back">
    <SidePanel.Header
      title="Title"
      subtitle="Subtitle"
      showDivider={true}
    />
  </SidePanel>
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Custom header
featureExamples.description: Create a custom header layout by adding children elements to the <SidePanel.Header/> container.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">

  <SidePanel onCloseButtonClick={() => {}}>

        <Search />
      </StorybookComponents.Stack>
    </SidePanel.Header>
  </SidePanel>
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Text overflow
featureExamples.description:
Panel title and subtitle wraps to multiple lines by default. Limit the amount of lines using ellipsis and maxLines properties.

Ellipsis do not apply to the subtitle, as its main purpose is to provide more information.
featureExamples.example:

      showDivider={true}

  <SidePanel onCloseButtonClick={() => {}}>
    <SidePanel.Header
      ellipsis
      maxLines={1}
      title="A long title that needs to wrap into multiple lines"
      subtitle="A long subtitle that needs to wrap into multiple lines because it is so long."
      showDivider={true}
    />
  </SidePanel>
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Draggable
featureExamples.description:
Let users know that panel position on the screen can be changed by changing the mouse cursor to grab with draggable property.

The behaviour itself has to be developed separately.

<SidePanel onCloseButtonClick={() => {}} skin="floating" width="288px" draggable>

content.description: Table is a component used to display data in rows and columns. It organizes information in a way that is easy to scan.
do: Use it to organize and display information from a dataset.
Use it to display data for comparison and analysis.
dont: Don’t use it to build reordable lists of data. Use <NestableList/> instead.
Don’t use it as a replacement for a spreadsheet.
Don't use it in Business Manager - use Patterns (Cairo) table instead.

commonUseCaseExamples.title: Table in a modal
commonUseCaseExamples.description: Render table without a toolbar when it is displayed in an overlay component, such as a <CustomModalLayout/> or a <SidePanel/>. Make sure content paddings in a selected layout is turned off.

commonUseCaseExamples.title: Filters
commonUseCaseExamples.description:
Enable users to find relevant data quicker by providing them with data filters and search.

We recommend to store up to 3 filters at once in a toolbar container. Check <Table.Toolbar/> page for all available toolbar arrangement options.

commonUseCaseExamples.title: Advanced filters
commonUseCaseExamples.description:
If there are more than 3 filters, transfer them outside of a table to a side panel. Add a button to a toolbar to call out this panel.

Note: Make sure to inform users about currently active filters. Display them as a list of tags in a <Table.Subtoolbar/> container.

commonUseCaseExamples.title: Sticky table toolbar
commonUseCaseExamples.description: Wrap table toolbar to a<Page.Sticky/> element to keep it always visible to users. Use it for infinite scroll tables.

featureExamples.title: Structure
featureExamples.description:
Table structures can vary, but they can include up to four elements:

  • <TableToolbar/> that displays table titles, filters and actions.
  • <Table.SubToolbar/> that displays content related to toolbar actions (optional).
  • <Table.Titlebar/> that displays titles in data columns (optional).
  • <Table.Content/> that shows rows of data.

featureExamples.title: Skin
featureExamples.description:
Choose between two colors for column title bars by using the skin prop.

  • standard is used for common cases (default).
  • neutral is used to minimize the emphasis on column titles. It's also common for tables that don't support sorting.

featureExamples.title: Row vertical padding
featureExamples.description:
Use rowVerticalPadding to control the whitespace above and below row data. Choose one of the following options:

  • xxTiny - Adds 3px padding. Use it to create very compact tables that contain text only.
  • xTiny - Adds 6px padding. Use it to create dense tables with short content.
  • tiny - Adds 12px padding. Use it to create dense tables or for rows that contain media elements, such as images or avatars.
  • small (default) - Adds 15px padding. Use this for common cases.
  • medium - Adds 18px padding. Use this for short data lists.
  • large - Adds 24px padding. Use sparingly for short data lists with a few items only.

featureExamples.title: Width
featureExamples.description: Specify table width in pixels or percentage with the width property. If not set, table will have the same width as its parent container.

featureExamples.title: Number of columns
featureExamples.description: Define data columns via the columns array. Table can have any number of columns.

featureExamples.title: Column alignment
featureExamples.description:
Control content alignment in a column with the align prop. It supports 3 options:

  • start (default)
  • center
  • end

featureExamples.title: Column width
featureExamples.description: Specify width of each column with width prop. If not specified, columns will be sized equally.

featureExamples.title: Column info
featureExamples.description: Add a tooltip to give additional information about a specific column using infoTooltipProps. Style the tooltip message with all common <Tooltip/> properties.

featureExamples.title: Row content
featureExamples.description: Add any required content to the table cells. It accepts any component or a composition of multiple elements.

featureExamples.title: Row highlight
featureExamples.description:
Emphasize specific rows that require user attention by highlighting them. Define a condition which must be matched via isRowHighlight function.

Highlight affects row background color and a font weight.

featureExamples.title: Sorting
featureExamples.description:
Allow users to find relevant data quicker by enabling column sorting.

Specify which column is sortable in columns array using the sortable prop.

featureExamples.title: Expand rows
featureExamples.description:
Reveal more details about each row by allowing rows to expand. Define whether a specific row can be expanded or not with the expandable prop in data array.

By default one row can be expanded at a time only. Allow users to expand multiple rows simultaneously with the allowMultiDetailsExpansion prop.

Use the rowDetails prop to pass content to display once row is expanded. Control whether content has paddings or not with the removeRowDetailsPadding prop. Remove paddings when you want to display another table inside row details.

featureExamples.title: Column title visibility
featureExamples.description:
Specify whether column titles are visible with the titleBarDisplay prop.

Hide the titlebar only when column values are self explanatory.

Note: Column titles should be announced for assistive technology users even when titlebar is visually hidden.
featureExamples.example:
() => { const records = [ { name: `Light grey hoodie`, SKU: '00224239', price: '$59.00', inventory: 'In stock', }, { name: `Black watch`, SKU: '00352464', price: '$229.00', inventory: 'In stock', }, { name: 'Reading glasses', SKU: '00486430', price: '$69.00', inventory: 'In stock', }, { name: 'Leather shoes', SKU: '00515642', price: '$129.00', inventory: 'Out of stock', }, ]; const columns = [ { title: 'Name', render: row => row.name }, { title: 'SKU', render: row => row.SKU }, { title: 'Inventory', render: row => row.inventory }, { title: 'Price', render: row => row.price }, ]; return ( Products
Products
); };

featureExamples.title: Horizontal scroll
featureExamples.description: Allow table content to exceed the width of a table itself by enabling horizontalScroll. Use it to support any number of data columns.

featureExamples.title: Bulk actions
featureExamples.description:
Allow users to act upon multiple items at once by enabling row selection with the showSelection prop.

Control ‘Select all’ checkbox visibility with the hideBulkSelectionCheckbox prop.

featureExamples.title: Multiple bulk actions
featureExamples.description:
Display available bulk actions in the toolbar with following components:

  • <Button/> for main actions
  • <PopoverMenu/> for secondary actions

    • Note: There should be no more than 3 actions visible in the toolbar at once.

featureExamples.title: Select all checkbox behaviour
featureExamples.description:
Control what happens when user clicks on ‘Select all’ checkbox when one or few items are already selected.

By default, the first click on indeterminate state selects all remaining items in the list. Change it to deselecting all items first with the deselectRowsByDefault prop.

featureExamples.title: Disable selection
featureExamples.description:
Restrict users from selecting a specific row by:

  • Hiding a checkbox for a row when row cannot be selected in any case with the unselectable prop.
  • Disabling a checkbox for a row on a certain condition. Define this condition using the selectionDisabled function. Use the checkboxTooltipContent prop to pass a tooltip message that explains why the row is disabled .

    • Note: Tooltip message will not be reachable by assistive technologies and should be used as an additional explanation only. Make sure you explain the reason why item selection is not available in alternative ways, for example by using a subtitle or a different item status.

featureExamples.title: Infinite scroll
featureExamples.description:
Load data to the table progressively with infiniteScroll.

Specify a number of items to load at once with the itemsPerPage prop. The rest will load on demand when the user scrolls down the list.

Define how many items will be selected in infinite scroll table when user clicks on ‘Select All’ checkbox with the totalSelectableCount prop. Newly loaded items that fall into a specified range will be selected automatically once loaded.

featureExamples.title: Pagination
featureExamples.description:
Split up large amounts of data across multiple pages using <Pagination/>. Use it to give users control to manually navigate between pages. It's beneficial when users operate with data chunks instead of a full list.

In tables that have selection enabled, make sure to provide an option to ‘Select All’ items in a toolbar container next to selected items count.

featureExamples.title: No data empty state
featureExamples.description: Use <Table.EmptyState/> to indicate that there are no existing entries that could be shown in a table. Make sure the illustration you show reflects the type of items the table will contain.

featureExamples.title: No search results empty state
featureExamples.description: Make sure to provide an empty state when the user looks for content via search query or tries to narrow down the data list via filters and no items match the criterias.
