content.description: Breadcrumbs show the page a user is on within the site hierarchy and let them navigate back.
do: Use it in pages that are arranged in site hierarchy.
Add breadcrumbs to deeper level pages (i.e. second, third, etc.).
Use it when users navigate between folders or lists.
dont: Don't use it on first level pages.
Don’t use it to show the progress of a task or process. Use <Stepper/> instead.

commonUseCaseExamples.title: Navigation between pages
commonUseCaseExamples.description: Add breadcrumbs to <Page.Header/> to let users quickly navigate back to the previous page in the hierarchy.
commonUseCaseExamples.example:
<Page.Header
  title="Appointment Hours"
  subtitle="Set default hours for when you and your staff are available to take appointments."
  breadcrumbs={
    <Breadcrumbs
      activeId="3"
      items={[
        { id: '1', value: 'Home', link: '' },
        { id: '2', value: 'Booking Settings', link: '' },
        { id: '3', value: 'Appointment Hours', link: '' },
      ]}
      onClick={() => {}}
    />
  }
  showBackButton
  onBackClicked={() => {}}
  actionsBar={
    <StorybookComponents.Stack gap="12px">
      <Button skin="inverted">Cancel</Button>
      <Button>Save</Button>
    </StorybookComponents.Stack>
  }
/>;

commonUseCaseExamples.title: Navigate between folders
commonUseCaseExamples.description: Use breadcrumbs to let users navigate between folders and files.

featureExamples.title: Size
featureExamples.description:
Control the size of breadcrumbs with the size property. It supports 2 sizes:

  • medium is used by default in regular page layouts.
  • When it's necessary to emphasize the path, use large.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <Breadcrumbs
    items={[
      { id: 0, value: 'Medium' },
      { id: 1, value: 'Medium' },
      { id: 2, value: 'Medium' },
    ]}
    size="medium"
    activeId={2}
  />
  <Breadcrumbs
    items={[
      { id: 0, value: 'Large' },
      { id: 1, value: 'Large' },
      { id: 2, value: 'Large' },
    ]}
    size="large"
    activeId={2}
  />
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Theme
featureExamples.description:
Control breadcrumbs' appearance with the theme prop. It supports 3 styles:

  • onGrayBackground is used by default with the default page header style.
  • Use onDarkBackground when breadcrumbs appear on a dark background or an image.
  • Use onWhiteBackground when breadcrumbs appear on a white background, for example in a modal.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <StorybookComponents.Stack padding="24px">
    <Breadcrumbs
      theme="onGrayBackground"
      items={[
        { id: 0, value: 'On grey background' },
        { id: 1, value: 'On grey background' },
        { id: 2, value: 'On grey background' },
      ]}
      activeId={2}
    />
  </StorybookComponents.Stack>
  <StorybookComponents.Background skin="dark">
    <StorybookComponents.Stack padding="24px">
      <Breadcrumbs
        theme="onDarkBackground"
        items={[
          { id: 0, value: 'On dark background' },
          { id: 1, value: 'On dark background' },
          { id: 2, value: 'On dark background' },
        ]}
        activeId={2}
      />
    </StorybookComponents.Stack>
  </StorybookComponents.Background>
  <StorybookComponents.Background skin="light">
    <StorybookComponents.Stack padding="24px">
      <Breadcrumbs
        theme="onWhiteBackground"
        items={[
          { id: 0, value: 'On white background' },
          { id: 1, value: 'On white background' },
          { id: 2, value: 'On white background' },
        ]}
        activeId={2}
      />
    </StorybookComponents.Stack>
  </StorybookComponents.Background>
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Max width
featureExamples.description:
Control when a breadcrumb item gets truncated with the itemMaxWidth property. When truncated, the breadcrumb item shows an ellipsis and the full text appears in a tooltip on hover.

Default max width is 240 px.

Avoid truncating breadcrumb items at all by setting max width to max-content.

featureExamples.description:

  • hidden (default)
  • normal
  • checked
  • indeterminate
  • hasError

featureExamples.description:

content.description: A table list item is a single row of a table or a list, that allows users to scan and compare sets of data. These sets can be a list of similar items, like products, posts or contacts.
do: Use this component for a simple list when a <Table/> is too complex.
Group similar items together for improved readability.
Organize important information for users.
dont: Don't create tables with multiple actions like filtering, bulk operations and column sorting. Build a <Table/> instead.
Don't build drag and drop lists, a <NestableList/> is a better option for this.

featureExamples.title: Structure
featureExamples.description:
Table list item organizes different sets of information into columns. It can have any number of columns, which can be added through options.

Add any content to the column with the value prop.

Note that column width and alignment can be controlled separately.
featureExamples.example:
<TableListItem
  options={[
    {
      value: (
        <StorybookComponents.Placeholder>
          Column 1
        </StorybookComponents.Placeholder>
      ),
    },
    {
      value: (
        <StorybookComponents.Placeholder>
          Column 2
        </StorybookComponents.Placeholder>
      ),
    },
    {
      value: (
        <StorybookComponents.Placeholder>
          Column 3
        </StorybookComponents.Placeholder>
      ),
    },
    {
      value: (
        <StorybookComponents.Placeholder>
          Column 4
        </StorybookComponents.Placeholder>
      ),
    },
  ]}
/>;

featureExamples.title: Padding
featureExamples.description:
Adjust vertical spacing by using verticalPadding and horizontalPadding props. It supports 6 options:

  • xxTiny
  • xTiny
  • tiny
  • small (default)
  • medium
  • large

    • Use tiny size set for compact lists that display more items in smaller space.

    Small (default) is a standard list size for most common cases.

    While medium and large are used to emphasize a few items.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <TableListItem
    horizontalPadding="xxTiny"
    verticalPadding="xxTiny"
    options={[{ value: <Text>xxTiny</Text> }]}
  />
  <TableListItem
    horizontalPadding="xTiny"
    verticalPadding="xTiny"
    options={[{ value: <Text>xTiny</Text> }]}
  />
    <TableListItem
    horizontalPadding="tiny"
    verticalPadding="tiny"
    options={[{ value: <Text>Tiny</Text> }]}
  />
  <TableListItem
    horizontalPadding="small"
    verticalPadding="small"
    options={[{ value: <Text>Small (default)</Text> }]}
  />
  <TableListItem
    horizontalPadding="medium"
    verticalPadding="medium"
    options={[{ value: <Text>Medium</Text> }]}
  />
    <TableListItem
    horizontalPadding="large"
    verticalPadding="large"
    options={[{ value: <Text>Large</Text> }]}
  />
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Drag handle size
featureExamples.description:
Control a drag handle size with dragHandleSize prop. It supports two sizes:

  • small is used for more compact lists
  • large (default) is used for tables and more spacious UI layouts
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <TableListItem
    draggable
    dragHandleSize="large"
    showDivider
    verticalPadding="tiny"
    options={[
      {
        value: <Text size="medium">Large drag handle (default)</Text>,
      },
    ]}
  />
  <TableListItem
    draggable
    dragHandleSize="small"
    showDivider
    horizontalPadding="tiny"
    verticalPadding="xTiny"
    options={[
      { width: 'auto' },
      {
        value: <Text size="small">Small drag handle</Text>,
      },
    ]}
  />
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Draggable item indication
featureExamples.description:
Control a drag grip icon with props:

  • draggable marks that the component can be dragged.
  • dragging indicates that the component is being dragged.
  • showDragHandleOnHover shows handle only on hover
  • dragDisabled show that the component can't be dragged.

    • Note, drag and drop logic is not part of this component. For this solution, go to <NestableList/>.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <TableListItem draggable options={[{ value: <Text>Draggable</Text> }]} />
  <TableListItem
    draggable
    dragging
    options={[{ value: <Text>Draggable active</Text> }]}
  />
   <TableListItem
    draggable
    showDragHandleOnHover
    options={[{ value: <Text>Draggable on hover</Text> }]}
  />
  <TableListItem
    draggable
    dragDisabled
    options={[{ value: <Text>Draggable disabled</Text> }]}
  />
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Border
featureExamples.description:
Control the appearance of the component using the border prop.

Use this property to emphasize the separation between items in a list.
featureExamples.example:

  <TableListItem
    showDivider
    verticalPadding="tiny"
    options={[
      {
        value: <Text size="small">No border (default)</Text>,
      },
      
            ]}
          />
      
  <TableListItem
    border={true}
    showDivider
    verticalPadding="tiny"
    options={[
      {
        value: <Text size="small">Border</Text>,
      },
      
    ]}
  />
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Expandable
featureExamples.description: Give an ability to make an item expandable with expanded prop.

featureExamples.title: Selectable
featureExamples.description:
Make an item selectable with the following props:

  • Use checkbox to enable the checkbox and show that the item can be selected.
  • checked changes the checkbox's default state to selected.
  • showSelectionBorder allows to turn off the blue strip indication when the item is selected
  • checkboxDisabled disables the checkbox.
  • selectable enables the selected state on the item

featureExamples.title: Divider
featureExamples.description:
Enable the bottom divider with showDivider, which visually separates the items.

Note that the last item on the list shouldn't have a bottom divider.
featureExamples.example:

    <TableListItem options={[{ value: <Text>Divider off</Text> }]} />
    <TableListItem options={[{ value: <Text>Divider off</Text> }]} />
    <TableListItem options={[{ value: <Text>Divider off</Text> }]} />
  </StorybookComponents.Stack>
  <StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column" gap={0}>
    <TableListItem showDivider options={[{ value: <Text>Divider on</Text> }]} />
    <TableListItem showDivider options={[{ value: <Text>Divider on</Text> }]} />
    <TableListItem options={[{ value: <Text>Divider off</Text> }]} />
  </StorybookComponents.Stack>
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

      align: 'right',
    },
  ]}
/>;

content.description: An empty state is used when an app, page or section has no data to show.
do: Show it when there's no data to display.
Use it to give feedback when no search results are available.
Use it when the page content fails to load or there's a technical error.
Give an explanation and provide a next action.
dont: Don’t overwhelm the user with unnecessary content.
Don’t use it to promote new products or features. Use <MarketingPageLayout/> or <MarketingLayout/> instead.

commonUseCaseExamples.description:
Use the section skin empty state to tell users what will appear on the card once there’s data to display and, if relevant, what they can do to get started.

Keep the design minimal and avoid using illustrations.

          <Button size="small" priority="secondary">
            Manage Posts
          </Button>
        </Box>
      </EmptyState>

featureExamples.title: Structure
featureExamples.description:
An empty state has 4 optional elements:

  • image
  • title
  • subtitle
  • child container, which can hold any component but is primarily reserved for CTA buttons.
featureExamples.example:
<EmptyState
  image={<Image width="120px" height="120px" />}
  title="Title"
  subtitle="Subtitle"
>
  <StorybookComponents.Placeholder>Child container</StorybookComponents.Placeholder>
</EmptyState>;

featureExamples.title: Skin
featureExamples.description:
Control an empty state's appearance with the skin property. There are 3 types:

  • page is for full-page empty states where data is displayed in a full-width table or a card.
  • page-no-border is for full-page empty states where data is displayed in an unknown layout.
  • section is the default theme for layout elements such as cards, tables or modals.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column" gap="48px">
  <EmptyState
    image={<Image width="120px" height="120px" />}
    skin="page"
    title="Page theme"
    subtitle="A subtitle guides users to their next step."
  />
  <EmptyState
    image={<Image width="120px" height="120px" />}
    skin="page-no-border"
    title="Page-no-border theme"
    subtitle="A subtitle guides users to their next step."
  />
  <EmptyState
    image={<Image width="120px" height="120px" />}
    skin="section"
    title="Section theme"
    subtitle="A subtitle guides users to their next step."
  />
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Children
featureExamples.description:
Add 1 or more CTA buttons below the subtitle as child elements of the empty state.

Be sure to give the user clear next actions.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <EmptyState
    skin="page-no-border"
    title="Add your first product"
    subtitle="Start adding products so customers can shop your online store."
  >
    <StorybookComponents.Placeholder height="36px">
      Child elements
    </StorybookComponents.Placeholder>
  </EmptyState>
  <EmptyState
    skin="page-no-border"
    title="Add your first product"
    subtitle="Start adding products so customers can shop your online store."
  >
    <TextButton prefixIcon={<Icons.Add />}>Add Product</TextButton>
  </EmptyState>
  <EmptyState
    skin="page-no-border"
    title="Add your first product"
    subtitle="Start adding products so customers can shop your online store."
  >
    <StorybookComponents.Stack gap="16px">
      <TextButton prefixIcon={<Icons.Add />}>Add New Product</TextButton>
      <TextButton prefixIcon={<Icons.DownloadImport />}>
        Import Products
      </TextButton>
    </StorybookComponents.Stack>
  </EmptyState>
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

developerExamples.title: Number of items to load
developerExamples.description:
Control the number of items that load with two properties:

  • initialAmountToLoad is the number of items loaded after a search.
  • itemsPerPage is the number of items that load each consecutive time a user scrolls down to the end of the list. The default is 50.

    • If not specified, initialAmountToLoad will be the same as itemsPerPage.

content.description: Selector lists allow users to select one or multiple items within a data set. They have built-in search and loading behaviors.
do: Use when users can select one or multiple items in data sets.
Use when there's a long list of items and searching is helpful.
Use inside parent containers such as a <CustomModalLayout/>.
dont: Don't use them for lists that can be edited by users. Use <EditableSelector/> instead.
Don't use them for data sets that need to be displayed in rows and columns. Use <Table/> instead.

commonUseCaseExamples.title: Single selection
commonUseCaseExamples.description:
Use the selector list to load and display a set of items.

If the anticipated number of items is small, hide the default search input field.

Use the subtitle, subtitleNode or extraNode containers to explain why an item is unavailable for selection.

commonUseCaseExamples.title: Multiple selection
commonUseCaseExamples.description:
Use the selector list to search and select multiple items.

Allow users to select and deselect all items at once using the renderToggleAllCheckbox function.

featureExamples.title: Type
featureExamples.description:
Control the type of selection users can make with the multiple prop:

  • false allows users to select a single item only.
  • true allows users to select multiple items.

featureExamples.title: Item structure
featureExamples.description:
Add more elements to the list items with the following props:

  • image
  • title (required)
  • subtitle

    • To add additional text or other components to items, use container props.

  • subtitleNode shows content below the item subtitle.
  • extraNode shows content at the end of an item.

featureExamples.title: Image shape
featureExamples.description:
Control shape of the images with the imageShape prop:

  • rectangularis the default that's used for all common cases.
  • circle is for images that show users or user initials.

featureExamples.title: Image size
featureExamples.description:
Change the size of the images with imageSize props:

  • tiny is for especially dense layouts.
  • small is for dense layouts.
  • large is the default for all common cases.
  • portrait should be used to present images vertically.
  • cinema should be used to present images horizontally.

    • Note: Only use a rectangular image when the size is portrait or cinema.

featureExamples.title: Height
featureExamples.description:
Control the height of the selector list with these props:

  • height changes the component's height in pixels or percentage.
  • maxHeight sets the component's max height in pixels or percentage.

    • By default, the component fills in 100% of its parent container. If the selector list is longer than height or maxHeight , a vertical scrollbar appears.

featureExamples.title: Disabled item
featureExamples.description:
Mark a list item as unavailable for selection with the disabled prop.

The item will still be displayed in the list and search results.

featureExamples.title: Subtitle
featureExamples.description:
Add any component inside a subtitle container above the search input. Together with search input, they will stick to the top when users scroll the list.

Use this container to add text, a heading or filter to selector list items.

featureExamples.title: Search
featureExamples.description:
The selector list has a search input field by default. Control its visibility using withSearch prop.

Change the search placeholder value with searchPlaceholder prop.

featureExamples.title: Select or deselect all
featureExamples.description:
Allow users to select all items at once by adding a “Select all” checkbox below the list.

When the selector list is inside a <CustomModalLayout/>, add the checkbox to its footer sideActions container using the renderToggleAllCheckbox function.

Customize checkbox labels with the properties selectAllText and deselectAllText.

Note: Make sure the “Select all” checkbox is aligned with the list checkboxes by wrapping renderToggleAllCheckbox function to the <Box/> with 6 px left padding.

featureExamples.title: Below node
featureExamples.description: Add text or any other component to the container below each item using the belowNode prop, which shows once an item is selected. Be sure to set the showBelowNodeOnSelect property to true.

featureExamples.title: No items empty state
featureExamples.description:
Use emptyState prop to display the <EmptyState/> component in the section theme when there are no items show.

Make sure the illustration reflects the type of items the list should contain.

featureExamples.title: No search results empty state
featureExamples.description: Provide an empty state when users look for content via search query and no items match their criteria using the renderNoResults function and the <EmptyState/> in the section theme.

content.description: Table action cell is a built-in solution that displays actions inside of table cells. The primary action is displayed as a button, while secondary actions are displayed either as multiple icon buttons or listed in a popover menu. Component should be rendered in the last column of a data row.
do: Use it to display actions that a user can take on a specific table row.
Render it in the last column of a table row.
Group similar items together using dividers in popover menu for easy readability.
dont: Don’t use it to display single or multiple actions directly on a page or a widget. Use standard <Button/> instead.

commonUseCaseExamples.title: Row actions
commonUseCaseExamples.description: Use table action cell to display row actions in the last column of a data table.

commonUseCaseExamples.title: Groups
commonUseCaseExamples.description: Use dividers to group large lists of actions in a secondary actions menu.

featureExamples.title: Size
featureExamples.description:
Control the size of primary and secondary actions displayed in a table cell with the size prop. Component supports 2 sizes:

  • medium - use in all common cases
  • small - use for dense tables
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">

  />
  <TableListItem
    onClick={() => {}}
    options={[

          <TableActionCell
            size="small"

              text: 'Small',
            }}
          />
        ),
      },
    ]}
  />
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Primary action
featureExamples.description: Define a main action of a cell with the primaryAction prop. Action will be revealed on table row hover only.
featureExamples.example:
<TableListItem
  onClick={() => {}}
  options={[
    {

        <TableActionCell

    },

/>;

featureExamples.title: Primary action visibility
featureExamples.description:
Control the appearance of a primary action with the visibility prop. It supports 2 options:

  • onHover (default) - button is only visible when the mouse hovers over item.
  • always - button is always visible and appears as a secondary button.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <TableListItem
    onClick={() => {}}
    options={[
      {
        value: (

            primaryAction={{

              visibility: 'onHover',
            }}

        ),
      },
    ]}
  />
  <TableListItem
    onClick={() => {}}
    options={[
      {
        value: (
          <TableActionCell
            primaryAction={{
              text: 'Always',
              visibility: 'always',
            }}
          />
        ),
      },
    ]}
  />
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Primary action icon affix
featureExamples.description:
Give more context to the primary action by adding an icon affix. It can be added to 2 locations:

  • prefixIcon - use to add a descriptive icon in front of a label
  • suffixIcon - use to add a directional icon at the end of a label
featureExamples.example:

            primaryAction={{

featureExamples.title: Secondary actions
featureExamples.description:
Define an array of additional actions for each row with the secondaryActions prop. Icon and text label are required to be specified. Actions will be listed in a popover menu.

Add the label for an icon button that opens up a popover menu using moreActionsTooltipText. Recommended label text: 'More actions'. It will be shown in a tooltip on hover or focus.
featureExamples.example:
<TableListItem
  onClick={() => {}}
  options={[
    {
      value: (
        <TableActionCell
          secondaryActions={[
            {
              text: 'Star',
              icon: <Icons.FavoriteSmall />,
              onClick: () => {},
            },
            {
              text: 'Download',
              icon: <Icons.DownloadImportSmall />,
              onClick: () => {},
            },
            {
              text: 'Duplicate',
              icon: <Icons.DuplicateSmall />,
              onClick: () => {},
            },
            {
              text: 'Print',
              icon: <Icons.PrintSmall />,
              onClick: () => {},
            },
          ]}
          moreActionsTooltipText="More actions"
        />
      ),
    },
  ]}
/>;

featureExamples.title: Number of visible secondary actions
featureExamples.description:
Display a selected number of secondary actions as icon buttons with the numOfVisibleSecondaryActions prop. By default actions will be revealed on hover only.

To display the icons all the time use the alwaysShowSecondaryActions prop.

featureExamples.title: Divider
featureExamples.description: Add a separating line to group related actions or distinguish destructive actions from the rest. Do it in a popover menu by rendering divider as a separate action in the secondaryActions array.

featureExamples.title: Disabled
featureExamples.description:
Disable all interactions for primary or secondary actions with the disabled prop. Use it to highlight unavailable functions.

Always provide an explanation for the user why actions cannot be accessed. Use disabledDescription prop to show a descriptive message in a tooltip.

Note: at the moment description can be added to visible secondary actions only.

featureExamples.title: Popover menu
featureExamples.description:
Customize the appearance of secondary actions popover menu with popoverMenuProps.

Check <PopoverMenu/> API for a full list of available properties.

content.description: Message modals display short messages letting users confirm or cancel an action before moving forward. They're used inside <Modal/> overlays.
do: Get confirmation before destructive or irreversible actions.
Update users about important changes, e.g., updated terms and conditions.
Inform users that selected features are Premium and upgrading is required.
Use it after an intentional user action and only when it is completely necessary. Because they are intrusive, modals should be used sparingly.
dont: Don’t show more detailed custom content. Use <CustomModalLayout/> instead.
Don’t preview files like images, videos or PDFs. Use <ModalPreviewLayout/> instead.
Don’t use them in mobile environments. Use <ModalMobileLayout/> instead.

commonUseCaseExamples.title: Warn about destructive changes

      Urgent
    </Badge>
    <Badge uppercase="false"  skin="premium" type="transparent">
      Premium
    </Badge>
  </StorybookComponents.Stack>
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Letter case
featureExamples.description:
Decide whether a badge is written in all uppercase letters or in sentence case with the uppercase prop.

By default, badges are written in lowercase.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack>
  <StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
    <Badge>Upper case</Badge>
    <Badge uppercase={false}>Lower case</Badge>
  </StorybookComponents.Stack>
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Affix
featureExamples.description:
Add more context to a badge with affix icons:

  • prefixIcon - used to emphasize status message.
  • suffixIcon - used to emphasize statuses that trigger popovers.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack>
  <StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
    <Badge uppercase="false"  prefixIcon={<Icons.LockLockedSmall />}>Prefix icon</Badge>
    <Badge uppercase="false" suffixIcon={<Icons.ChevronDownSmall />}>Suffix icon</Badge>
  </StorybookComponents.Stack>
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

developerExamples.title: Fluid
developerExamples.description: The trigger element can be resized to a specific container width using the fluid prop. Use it with ellipsis inside the trigger element to display the full label in a tooltip on hover.
developerExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack width="150px">
  <PopoverMenu
    fluid
    triggerElement={
      <TextButton suffixIcon={<Icons.ChevronDown />} ellipsis>
        A very long trigger element title
      </TextButton>
    }
  >
    <PopoverMenu.MenuItem text="Action 1" />
    <PopoverMenu.MenuItem text="Action 2" />
    <PopoverMenu.MenuItem text="Action 3" />
  </PopoverMenu>
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

content.description: A popover menu displays a list of actions when a user either clicks or hovers on a trigger element.
do: Display a list of actions when there is not enough space to expose them right away.
Display secondary actions that are hidden to the user until clicked or hovered on.
dont: Don't use it to explain the functions of an item. Instead, use <Popover/> or <Tooltip/>.
Don't use it to promote new features. Instead, use <FloatingHelper/>.
Don't use it to display a list of options. Instead, use <Dropdown/>.

commonUseCaseExamples.title: Secondary actions in widgets
commonUseCaseExamples.description: The small size popover menu should be used in dense layouts and widgets. Irreversible actions should be highlighted with a destructive skin.
commonUseCaseExamples.example:
<Layout>
  <Cell span={4}>
    <Card>
      <Card.Content>
        <Box direction="vertical" gap={4}>
          <Box direction="horizontal" justify-content="space-between">

            <PopoverMenu
              textSize="small"

                </IconButton>

                prefixIcon={<Icons.EditSmall />}
                text="Edit info"
              />
              <PopoverMenu.MenuItem
                prefixIcon={<Icons.DateAndTimeSmall />}
                text="Edit availability"
              />
              <PopoverMenu.MenuItem
                prefixIcon={<Icons.AdminAccessSmall />}
                text="Manage permissions"
              />
              <PopoverMenu.Divider />
              <PopoverMenu.MenuItem
                prefixIcon={<Icons.DeleteSmall />}
                skin="destructive"

  </Cell>
</Layout>;

commonUseCaseExamples.title: Secondary page actions
commonUseCaseExamples.description:
Popover menus can be used to display a list of secondary page actions.

Use <PopoverMenu.Divider/> to organize actions into groups.

To make sure action titles will not wrap to multiple lines, set the minWidth value to max-content.

<Page>

            prefixIcon={<Icons.Settings />}
            text="Update booking settings"

            prefixIcon={<Icons.Payment />}
            text="Accept payments"
          />
          <PopoverMenu.MenuItem
            prefixIcon={<Icons.Users />}
            text="Manage staff"
          />
          <PopoverMenu.Divider />
          <PopoverMenu.MenuItem
            prefixIcon={<Icons.Coupon />}

      </Box>
    }
  />
  <Page.Content>
    <Card>
      <Box height="360px" />
    </Card>
  </Page.Content>
</Page>;

featureExamples.title: Trigger element
featureExamples.description:
Popover menus are opened by interacting with a trigger element. Common trigger elements are:

  • <Button/>
  • <Text Button/>
  • <IconButton/>
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack alignItems="center">
  <PopoverMenu
    triggerElement={
      <Button priority="secondary" suffixIcon={<Icons.ChevronDown />}>
        More Actions
      </Button>
    }
  >
    <PopoverMenu.MenuItem text="Action 1" />
    <PopoverMenu.MenuItem text="Action 2" />
    <PopoverMenu.MenuItem text="Action 3" />
  </PopoverMenu>
  <PopoverMenu
    triggerElement={
      <TextButton suffixIcon={<Icons.ChevronDown />}>
        More Actions
      </TextButton>
    }
  >
    <PopoverMenu.MenuItem text="Action 1" />
    <PopoverMenu.MenuItem text="Action 2" />
    <PopoverMenu.MenuItem text="Action 3" />
  </PopoverMenu>
  <PopoverMenu
    triggerElement={
      <IconButton priority="secondary">
        <Icons.More />
      </IconButton>
    }
  >
    <PopoverMenu.MenuItem text="Action 1" />
    <PopoverMenu.MenuItem text="Action 2" />
    <PopoverMenu.MenuItem text="Action 3" />
  </PopoverMenu>
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Trigger interaction
featureExamples.description: Popover menus are displayed when a trigger element is either clicked or hovered on.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack>
  <PopoverMenu
    triggerElement={
      <TextButton suffixIcon={<Icons.ChevronDown />}>Click Here</TextButton>
    }
  >
    <PopoverMenu.MenuItem text="Action 1" />
    <PopoverMenu.MenuItem text="Action 2" />
    <PopoverMenu.MenuItem text="Action 3" />
  </PopoverMenu>
  <PopoverMenu
    triggerElement={({ toggle, open, close }) => (
      <TextButton
        onClick={toggle}
        onMouseEnter={open}
        onMouseLeave={close}
        suffixIcon={<Icons.ChevronDown />}
      >
        Hover Here
      </TextButton>
    )}
  >
    <PopoverMenu.MenuItem text="Action 1" />
    <PopoverMenu.MenuItem text="Action 2" />
    <PopoverMenu.MenuItem text="Action 3" />
  </PopoverMenu>
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Size
featureExamples.description:
The size of menu items can be controlled using the textSize prop.

There are two sizes to choose from:

  • medium is the default used in common cases.
  • small should be used in dense layouts.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack alignItems="center">
  <PopoverMenu
    textSize="medium"
    triggerElement={
      <TextButton suffixIcon={<Icons.ChevronDown />}>
        View Medium Size
      </TextButton>
    }
  >
    <PopoverMenu.MenuItem text="Medium action 1" />
    <PopoverMenu.MenuItem text="Medium action 2" />
    <PopoverMenu.MenuItem text="Medium action 3" />
  </PopoverMenu>
  <PopoverMenu
    textSize="small"
    triggerElement={
      <TextButton suffixIcon={<Icons.ChevronDownSmall />} size="small">
        View Small Size
      </TextButton>
    }
  >
    <PopoverMenu.MenuItem text="Small action 1" />
    <PopoverMenu.MenuItem text="Small action 2" />
    <PopoverMenu.MenuItem text="Small action 3" />
  </PopoverMenu>
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Skin
featureExamples.description:
The appearance of each menu item can be controlled using the skin prop.

There are two skins to choose from:

  • dark should be used for all common cases.
  • destructive should be used to highlight destructive and permanent actions, e.g., deleting a contact.

    • Note: Destructive actions should be placed last in the menu.
featureExamples.example:
<PopoverMenu
  triggerElement={
    <TextButton suffixIcon={<Icons.ChevronDown />}>View Skins</TextButton>
  }
>
  <PopoverMenu.MenuItem skin="dark" text="Dark action" />
  <PopoverMenu.MenuItem skin="destructive" text="Destructive action" />
</PopoverMenu>;

featureExamples.title: Disabled
featureExamples.description: Actions that are unavailable to users at that time should be marked with the disabled prop.
featureExamples.example:
<PopoverMenu
  triggerElement={
    <TextButton suffixIcon={<Icons.ChevronDown />}>
      View Disabled State
    </TextButton>
  }
>
  <PopoverMenu.MenuItem text="Action 1" />
  <PopoverMenu.MenuItem text="Action 2" />
  <PopoverMenu.MenuItem text="Disabled action" disabled />
</PopoverMenu>;

featureExamples.title: Prefix
featureExamples.description:
Icons can be added to menu items using the prefixIcon prop. It can help users identify actions quicker.

Note: small size popovers should use the small icon size, 18x18.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack alignItems="center">
  <PopoverMenu
    triggerElement={
      <TextButton suffixIcon={<Icons.ChevronDown />}>View Prefix</TextButton>
    }
  >
    <PopoverMenu.MenuItem text="Add" prefixIcon={<Icons.Add />} />
    <PopoverMenu.MenuItem text="Edit" prefixIcon={<Icons.Edit />} />
    <PopoverMenu.MenuItem text="Delete" prefixIcon={<Icons.Delete />} />
  </PopoverMenu>
  <PopoverMenu
    textSize="small"
    triggerElement={
      <TextButton suffixIcon={<Icons.ChevronDownSmall />} size="small">
        View Small Prefix
      </TextButton>
    }
  >
    <PopoverMenu.MenuItem text="Add" prefixIcon={<Icons.AddSmall />} />
    <PopoverMenu.MenuItem text="Edit" prefixIcon={<Icons.EditSmall />} />
    <PopoverMenu.MenuItem text="Delete" prefixIcon={<Icons.DeleteSmall />} />
  </PopoverMenu>
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Subtitle
featureExamples.description: Add additional information that helps explain the purpose of a specific action using the subtitle prop.
featureExamples.example:
<PopoverMenu
  triggerElement={
    <TextButton suffixIcon={<Icons.ChevronDown />}>View Subtitle</TextButton>
  }
>
  <PopoverMenu.MenuItem
    text="Action 1"
    subtitle="Subtitle that explains action 1"
  />
  <PopoverMenu.MenuItem
    text="Action 2"
    subtitle="Subtitle that explains action 2"
  />
  <PopoverMenu.MenuItem
    text="Action 3"
    subtitle="Subtitle that explains action 3"
  />
</PopoverMenu>;

featureExamples.title: Divider
featureExamples.description: Menu items can be organized into groups by adding a <PopoverMenu.Divider/> between them.
featureExamples.example:
<PopoverMenu
  triggerElement={
    <TextButton suffixIcon={<Icons.ChevronDown />}>View Divider</TextButton>
  }
>
  <PopoverMenu.MenuItem text="Action 1" />
  <PopoverMenu.MenuItem text="Action 2" />
  <PopoverMenu.MenuItem text="Action 3" />
  <PopoverMenu.Divider />
  <PopoverMenu.MenuItem text="Action 4" />
</PopoverMenu>;

featureExamples.title: Placement
featureExamples.description:
The placement of the menu in relation to the trigger element can be controlled using the placement prop.

There are four placement types to choose from:

  • top, top-start, top-end
  • right, right-start, right-end
  • bottom (default), bottom-start, bottom-end
  • left, left-start, left-end
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <StorybookComponents.Stack justifyContent="center">
    <PopoverMenu
      placement="top"
      triggerElement={
        <TextButton suffixIcon={<Icons.ChevronDown />}>
          Top Placement
        </TextButton>
      }
    >
      <PopoverMenu.MenuItem text="Action 1" />
      <PopoverMenu.MenuItem text="Action 2" />
      <PopoverMenu.MenuItem text="Action 3" />
    </PopoverMenu>
  </StorybookComponents.Stack>
  <StorybookComponents.Stack justifyContent="space-between">
    <PopoverMenu
      placement="left"
      triggerElement={
        <TextButton suffixIcon={<Icons.ChevronDown />}>
          Left Placement
        </TextButton>
      }
    >
      <PopoverMenu.MenuItem text="Action 1" />
      <PopoverMenu.MenuItem text="Action 2" />
      <PopoverMenu.MenuItem text="Action 3" />
    </PopoverMenu>
    <PopoverMenu
      placement="right"
      triggerElement={
        <TextButton suffixIcon={<Icons.ChevronDown />}>
          Right Placement
        </TextButton>
      }
    >
      <PopoverMenu.MenuItem text="Action 1" />
      <PopoverMenu.MenuItem text="Action 2" />
      <PopoverMenu.MenuItem text="Action 3" />
    </PopoverMenu>
  </StorybookComponents.Stack>
  <StorybookComponents.Stack justifyContent="center">
    <PopoverMenu
      placement="bottom"
      triggerElement={
        <TextButton suffixIcon={<Icons.ChevronDown />}>
          Bottom Placement
        </TextButton>
      }
    >
      <PopoverMenu.MenuItem text="Action 1" />
      <PopoverMenu.MenuItem text="Action 2" />
      <PopoverMenu.MenuItem text="Action 3" />
    </PopoverMenu>
  </StorybookComponents.Stack>
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Pointer arrow
featureExamples.description: By default, a pointer arrow is visible on the top edge of the menu, pointing to the trigger element. To remove the pointer, use the showArrow prop.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack>
  <PopoverMenu
    triggerElement={
      <TextButton suffixIcon={<Icons.ChevronDown />}>
        View With Arrow
      </TextButton>
    }
  >
    <PopoverMenu.MenuItem text="Action 1" />
    <PopoverMenu.MenuItem text="Action 2" />
    <PopoverMenu.MenuItem text="Action 3" />
  </PopoverMenu>
  <PopoverMenu
    showArrow={false}
    triggerElement={
      <TextButton suffixIcon={<Icons.ChevronDown />}>
        View Without Arrow
      </TextButton>
    }
  >
    <PopoverMenu.MenuItem text="Action 1" />
    <PopoverMenu.MenuItem text="Action 2" />
    <PopoverMenu.MenuItem text="Action 3" />
  </PopoverMenu>
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Text overflow
featureExamples.description:
Define what happens with menu item text when it exceeds the popover maxWidth.

By default, text wraps into multiple lines. To limit menu item text to a single line, use the ellipsis prop. The full title is revealed in a tooltip on mouse hover.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack>
  <PopoverMenu
    triggerElement={
      <TextButton suffixIcon={<Icons.ChevronDown />}>
        View Wrapping Text
      </TextButton>
    }
  >
    <PopoverMenu.MenuItem text="Long action text here" />
    <PopoverMenu.MenuItem text="Long action text here" />
    <PopoverMenu.MenuItem text="Long action text here" />
  </PopoverMenu>
  <PopoverMenu
    ellipsis
    triggerElement={
      <TextButton suffixIcon={<Icons.ChevronDown />}>
        View Text With Ellipsis
      </TextButton>
    }
  >
    <PopoverMenu.MenuItem text="Long action text here" />
    <PopoverMenu.MenuItem text="Long action text here" />
    <PopoverMenu.MenuItem text="Long action text here" />
  </PopoverMenu>
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Custom dimensions
featureExamples.description:
Popover dimensions can be adjusted using the following props:

  • minWidth - sets the minimum pixel width (default: 144 px).
  • maxWidth - sets the maximum pixel width (default: 204 px).
  • maxHeight - sets the maximum pixel height. When the list of actions exceeds it, a scrollbar is visible.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack>
  <PopoverMenu
    minWidth="240px"
    triggerElement={
      <TextButton suffixIcon={<Icons.ChevronDown />}>
        View Min Width
      </TextButton>
    }
  >
    <PopoverMenu.MenuItem text="Action 1" />
    <PopoverMenu.MenuItem text="Action 2" />
    <PopoverMenu.MenuItem text="Action 3" />
  </PopoverMenu>
  <PopoverMenu
    maxWidth="180px"
    triggerElement={
      <TextButton suffixIcon={<Icons.ChevronDown />}>
        View Max Width
      </TextButton>
    }
  >
    <PopoverMenu.MenuItem text="Long action text here" />
    <PopoverMenu.MenuItem text="Long action text here" />
    <PopoverMenu.MenuItem text="Long action text here" />
  </PopoverMenu>
  <PopoverMenu
    maxHeight="180px"
    triggerElement={
      <TextButton suffixIcon={<Icons.ChevronDown />}>
        View Max Height
      </TextButton>
    }
  >
    <PopoverMenu.MenuItem text="Action 1" />
    <PopoverMenu.MenuItem text="Action 2" />
    <PopoverMenu.MenuItem text="Action 3" />
    <PopoverMenu.MenuItem text="Action 4" />
    <PopoverMenu.MenuItem text="Action 5" />
    <PopoverMenu.MenuItem text="Action 6" />
  </PopoverMenu>
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

developerExamples.title: Custom HTML tag
developerExamples.description:
Render buttons as any given HTML tag with the as prop. For example, they can be rendered as:

  • <a> when attributes like href, target are needed.
  • <Link> when props like to, replace, etc. are needed.

    • All attributes will be passed to the rendered element.
developerExamples.example:
() => {
  const ReactRouterLink = props => <div {...props} />;

  return (
    <StorybookComponents.Stack justifyContent="space-between">
      <StorybookComponents.Stack
        flexDirection="column"
        gap="12px"
        alignItems="center"
      >
        <Text secondary size="small">
          {'<a/> tag'}
        </Text>
        <IconButton as="a" href="https://www.wix.com" target="_blank">
          <Icons.Add />
        </IconButton>
      </StorybookComponents.Stack>
      <StorybookComponents.Stack
        flexDirection="column"
        gap="12px"
        alignItems="center"
      >
        <Text secondary size="small">
          {'React router <Link/> tag'}
        </Text>
        <IconButton as={ReactRouterLink} to="/home">
          <Icons.Add />
        </IconButton>
      </StorybookComponents.Stack>
      <StorybookComponents.Stack
        flexDirection="column"
        gap="12px"
        alignItems="center"
      >
        <Text secondary size="small">
          {'Native <button/> tag'}
        </Text>
        <IconButton as="button">
          <Icons.Add />
        </IconButton>
      </StorybookComponents.Stack>
    </StorybookComponents.Stack>
  );
};

content.description: Icon buttons highlight actions that users can take, used in compact or crowded layouts.
do: Add tooltip labels to icon buttons using a <Tooltip/>.
Only use icon buttons for low-emphasis actions.
Use them in compact or crowded layouts.
Make sure the meaning of the icons are simple and unambiguous.
dont: Don’t use them for secondary actions if there’s enough space to show the full label. Use <Button/> or <TextButton/> instead.

featureExamples.title: Skin

  • standard is the default for all general actions.
  • light is for dark backgrounds.
  • transparent is for backgrounds with colors or images.
  • premium is for actions that prompt users to upgrade their plans.
  • dark should be used with buttons on backgrounds with colors.
  • ai should be used with AI based features.

    • Each action can be primary, secondary or tertiary, depending on priority. There should only be one primary action per page.

    Note: Secondary buttons should be used alongside primary buttons for less utilized actions, such as cancel or back.

developerExamples.title: Custom HTML tag

Render buttons as any given HTML tag with the as prop.

Render text buttons that are links as:

  • <a> when attributes like href, target, etc., are needed.

content.description: Text buttons communicate low-emphasis actions that users can take.
do: Use it for optional actions on a page or a widget.
Use it to navigate to another page.
Use it to display a large list of optional actions.
dont: Don’t use it for primary or submit actions. Use a regular <Button/> instead.

accessibilityExamples.title: Inline links
accessibilityExamples.description:
Users with visual impairments may have trouble distinguishing links from text, if no additional visual indicators are given. Make inline text links stand out for all users:

  • Select a contrasting link color, such as standard text button next to dark text.
  • Use text button underline.
  • Or use a fitting prefixIcon or suffixIcon.

    • Also, use meaningful link text that conveys its function independently of the surrounding content. For example, say 'Learn More about Automations' instead of 'Learn More'.

      </Box>

</Page>;

content.description: Tooltips provide additional explanation on how a specific element functions. A user can trigger a tooltip by mouse hover, keyboard focus or touch.
do: Give additional information about interactive controls.
Describe or label non-interactive elements, such as icons or images.
Provide labels to <IconButton/>.
Use 'aria-describedby' prop to connect the tooltip’s content to its trigger element for assistive technologies.
dont: Don’t use it to explain disabled components, since keyboard and screen reader users will not be able to access it. Instead, use <Text/> or <InfoIcon/>.
Don’t use it to provide critical information. Instead, use <SectionHelper/> or <FloatingNotification/>.
Don’t use it to provide lengthy information. Instead, use <Text/> in the main layout.
Don’t include any interactive elements (e.g., <TextButton/>) in tooltip’s content, as keyboard and screen reader users will not be able to access it.

featureExamples.title: Structure
featureExamples.description:
To display a tooltip, two parts need to be defined:

  • A trigger element that calls a tooltip when hover or focus occurs (e.g., an <IconButton/>). The trigger element goes inside the <Tooltip/> wrapper as its child item.
  • The content, which is the text displayed inside of a tooltip.
featureExamples.example:
<Tooltip inline content="Tooltip content goes here.">
  <TextButton>Hover or focus to see tooltip</TextButton>
</Tooltip>

featureExamples.title: Size
featureExamples.description:
Control tooltip dimensions with the size prop:

  • For dense layouts (e.g., in a composer), use small.
  • The default size used in any other case is medium.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <Tooltip inline content="This is a small tooltip." size="small">
    <TextButton>Small tooltip</TextButton>
  </Tooltip>
  <Tooltip inline content="This is a medium (default) tooltip.">
    <TextButton>Medium tooltip</TextButton>
  </Tooltip>
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Max width
featureExamples.description:
Control tooltip width with maxWidth. When the maximum width is reached, text inside the tooltip will wrap onto multiple lines.

Default maxWidth is 204 px.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <Tooltip
    inline
    content="This is a tooltip with content wrapped using the default max width."
  >
    <TextButton>Default max width</TextButton>
  </Tooltip>
  <Tooltip
    inline
    content="This is a tooltip with content wrapped using 360px max width."
    maxWidth={360}
  >
    <TextButton>Max width = 360 px</TextButton>
  </Tooltip>
</StorybookComponents.Stack>

featureExamples.title: Placement
featureExamples.description:
Use the placement prop to select the position of a tooltip in relation to its trigger element:

  • top (default)
  • right
  • bottom
  • left

    • In each of these standard positions, the tooltip aligns itself to the center of the corresponding axis and appears outside the trigger element.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column" alignItems="center">
  <Tooltip inline content="Top (default)">
    <TextButton>Top (default)</TextButton>
  </Tooltip>
  <Box gap="24">
    <Tooltip inline content="Left" placement="left">
      <TextButton>Left</TextButton>
    </Tooltip>
    <Tooltip inline content="Right" placement="right">
      <TextButton>Right</TextButton>
    </Tooltip>
  </Box>
  <Tooltip inline content="Bottom" placement="bottom">
    <TextButton>Bottom</TextButton>
  </Tooltip>
</StorybookComponents.Stack>

featureExamples.title: Text alignment
featureExamples.description:
The textAlign prop controls how tooltip content is aligned:

  • start (default)
  • center
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <Tooltip inline content="Content is aligned to the left (default).">
    <TextButton>Start (default)</TextButton>
  </Tooltip>
  <Tooltip inline content="Content is aligned to the center." textAlign="center">
    <TextButton>Center</TextButton>
  </Tooltip>
</StorybookComponents.Stack>

featureExamples.title: Delay
featureExamples.description:
Delay the showing or hiding of a tooltip, for a specific amount of time, by using enterDelay and exitDelay.

Delay times are counted by milliseconds and both are 0 by default.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <Tooltip inline content="Tooltip was shown after 450 ms." enterDelay={450}>
    <TextButton>Enter delay</TextButton>
  </Tooltip>
  <Tooltip inline content="Tooltip will fade after 450 ms." exitDelay={450}>
    <TextButton>Exit delay</TextButton>
  </Tooltip>
</StorybookComponents.Stack>

featureExamples.title: Interactive
featureExamples.description: Decide whether tooltip can be hovered on not by using interactive prop.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <Tooltip
    inline
    content={
      <Box direction="vertical">
        <Text size="small" skin="light">
          This is an interactive tooltip.
        </Text>
        <TextButton size="small" skin="standard-light">
          Learn more
        </TextButton>
      </Box>
    }
  >
    <TextButton>Interactive</TextButton>
  </Tooltip>
  <Tooltip
    inline
    interactive={false}
    content="This is a non-interactive tooltip."
  >
    <TextButton>Non-Interactive</TextButton>
  </Tooltip>
</StorybookComponents.Stack>

featureExamples.title: On disabled trigger elements
featureExamples.description:
By default, disabled trigger elements (e.g., <Button disabled/>) do not show tooltips on mouse hover or keyboard focus.

To show a tooltip on mouse hover, set the disabled prop to false.

Note: such tooltip content will not be accessible to keyboard focus, so it's best not to use tooltip to give additional information on a disabled component. Instead, use <InfoIcon/>, <Text/> or other components near the disabled component.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <Tooltip inline content="Tooltip content will not be shown">
    <TextButton disabled>No tooltip (default)</TextButton>
  </Tooltip>
  <Tooltip
    inline
    content="Tooltip content is shown on mouse hover"
    disabled={false}
  >
    <TextButton disabled>Tooltip on mouse hover</TextButton>
  </Tooltip>
</StorybookComponents.Stack>

developerExamples.title: Built-in date validation
developerExamples.description:
The component's built-in validation feature covers these cases:

  • formatError - when a user types in a date that is invalid and impossible to parse.
  • outOfBoundsError - when a user types in a date that is out of the accepted range. This validation is triggered when the excludePastDates or filterDate props are enabled.

    • Get informed about a validation event by using the onValidate callback function. It provides these parameters: validationType, input value and format.

developerExamples.title: Custom date validations
developerExamples.description: To apply custom validations to the component, use onChange, value and status together with the statusMessage prop.

content.description: Date pickers allow users to select or enter a specific date. It’s a combination of the <Input/>, <Calendar/> and <Popover/> components.
do: Use it to select dates in the recent past or near future.
Make it easier to select dates far in the past or in the future with month and year selection in the calendar (e.g., when entering a birth date or expiration date).
dont: Don’t use it to select time. Use <TimeInput/> instead.

accessibilityExamples.title: Helper text
accessibilityExamples.description:
To help users enter the correct date format, use helper text below the date picker which describes the expected date format.

This will help prevent user errors.

commonUseCaseExamples.title: Together with time input
commonUseCaseExamples.description: Use the date picker together with <TimeInput/> for scheduling appointments, events and more.

featureExamples.title: Size
featureExamples.description:
Adjust the size using the size prop. It supports 3 sizes:

  • Use large when the date input needs emphasis.
  • For most common cases, use the default medium.
  • In more dense and compact layouts, use small.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <DatePicker placeholderText="Large" size="large" width="240px"/>
  <DatePicker placeholderText="Medium" size="medium" width="240px"/>
  <DatePicker placeholderText="Small" size="small" width="240px"/>
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Status
featureExamples.description:
Control the status using the status prop. There are 3 states:

  • error highlights invalid dates.
  • warning highlights dates that can't be validated or might impact the user negatively.
  • loading shows that the server is loading the selected value.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <DatePicker value={new Date()} status="error" width="240px" />
  <DatePicker value={new Date()} status="warning" width="240px" />
  <DatePicker value={new Date()} status="loading" width="240px" />
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Status message
featureExamples.description:
Add text that explains the status or what action the user should take with the statusMessage prop.

Showing the status message inline, directly below the date picker is preferred in all default cases.

  • To add an accessible inline message, wrap the component in a <FormField/> and add the statusMessage.
  • To add a status message in a tooltip that requires users to hover on the icon, use the statusMessage prop.

    • View more inline status message examples in <FormField/>.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column" gap="12px">
    <Text secondary>For all default cases:</Text>
    <FormField status="error" statusMessage="This is an error message.">
      <DatePicker placeholderText="See message below" width="240px" />
    </FormField>
  </StorybookComponents.Stack>
  <StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column" gap="12px">
    <Text secondary>For narrow layouts only:</Text>
    <DatePicker
      placeholderText="Hover on status icon"
      status="error"
      statusMessage="This is an error message."
      width="240px"
    />
  </StorybookComponents.Stack>
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Read-only and disabled
featureExamples.description:
Control the input interaction with these props:

  • Use readOnly to display dates that cannot be overwritten (but can still be copied).
  • Disable all input interactions with the disabled prop. Use it to highlight an unavailable selection.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <DatePicker value={new Date()} placeholderText="Select a date" readOnly width="240px"/>
  <DatePicker placeholderText="Select date" disabled width="240px"/>
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Clear button
featureExamples.description: Use the clearButton prop to add a button that clears the selected date easily.

featureExamples.title: Locale and date style
featureExamples.description:
Set appropriate formatting per country with locale and dateStyle props.

dateStyle supports 2 values:

  • In most cases, the default style should be short.
  • Give the month more emphasis with the medium prop.
  • Show day and month in more detail with the long prop.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <DatePicker value={new Date()} locale="en" dateStyle="short" width="240px"/>
  <DatePicker value={new Date()} locale="en" dateStyle="medium" width="240px"/>
  <DatePicker value={new Date()} locale="en" dateStyle="long" width="240px" />
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: First day of the week
featureExamples.description: Use firstDayOfWeek to adjust which day of the week is shown first in the calendar view. Overwrite the default value for Sunday (0) with a number representing any other day of the week (Monday = 1, Tuesday = 2, etc.).
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <DatePicker
    placeholderText="First day is Sunday"
    firstDayOfWeek={0}
    width="240px"
  />
  <DatePicker
    placeholderText="First day is Monday"
    firstDayOfWeek={1}
    width="240px"
  />
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Year and month selections
featureExamples.description: Make it easier for users to select dates far in the past or future with the showMonthDropdown and showYearDropdown. These dropdowns will show inside the calendar view.
featureExamples.example: <DatePicker value={new Date()} showMonthDropdown showYearDropdown width="240px"/>;

featureExamples.title: Excluding dates
featureExamples.description:
Control the date ranges that users can select with the following props:

  • Stop users from selecting dates in the past with excludePastDates.
  • Don't allow users to select a specific set or range of dates with filterDate .
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <DatePicker
    placeholderText="Select a date in the future"
    excludePastDates
    width="50%"
  />
  <DatePicker
    placeholderText="Select one of the available dates"
    filterDate={date => date < new Date()}
    width="50%"
  /> 
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Size
featureExamples.description:
Adjust the component size using the size prop.

  • large emphasize fields in onboarding flows.
  • medium is the default size used in most cases.
  • small should be used in dense layouts.

featureExamples.title: Border
featureExamples.description:
Style the component using the border prop which supports four styles:

  • For forms, use standard.
  • When the component is used to filter, use round.
  • For titles that can be edited on click, use bottomLine.
  • In the Content Manager’s spreadsheet, use none.

featureExamples.title: Status
featureExamples.description:
Use the status prop to control component status.

  • error highlights an invalid selection.
  • warning highlights a value that can’t be validated or impacts a user’s business.
  • loading shows that the value is loading.

    • Hide the status suffix and indicate the state with a border color by setting hideStatusSuffixto true.

featureExamples.title: Status message
featureExamples.description:
Add text that explains the status or what action the user should take with the statusMessage prop.

Showing the status message inline, directly below the dropdown is preferred in all default cases.

  • To add an accessible inline message, wrap the component in a <FormField/> and add the statusMessage.
  • To add a status message in a tooltip that requires users to hover on the icon, use the statusMessage prop. Control tooltip placement with tooltipPlacement prop.

    • View more inline status message examples in <FormField/>.

featureExamples.title: Disabled
featureExamples.description: Disable all input interactions with the disabled prop. Use it to highlight unavailable functions.

featureExamples.title: Affix
featureExamples.description: Add additional information to prefix and suffix props (e.g. text, icons, buttons) to support the dropdown value.

featureExamples.title: Clear button
featureExamples.description: Enable a button that clears the dropdown value by using the clearButton prop. Show it when the field value is optional or has to be cleared often.

featureExamples.title: Fixed header and footer
featureExamples.description: Add related actions to fixedFooter or fixedHeader areas. These headers and footers keep their position on scroll.

featureExamples.title: List item builders
featureExamples.description:
Use three props to build custom layouts:

  • listItemSectionBuilder groups items into sections by type.
  • listItemActionBuilder adds a text button for related list actions.
  • listItemSelectBuilder builds custom list designs.

featureExamples.title: List container dimensions
featureExamples.description:
Control the container size for the list of options with these props:

  • maxHeightPixels specifies the maximum height for longer lists.
  • dropdownWidth matches content width or specifies pixels. Set width to ‘auto’ or ‘max-content.’
  • minWidthPixels manually increases dropdown popover width.

    • By default, the dropdown matches the input field width.

featureExamples.title: Marked option
featureExamples.description: Once the dropdown is opened, use the markedOption to highlight the option.
featureExamples.example:
<Dropdown
  placeholder="Select an option"
  markedOption={1}
  options={[
    { id: 0, value: 'Option 1' },
    { id: 1, value: 'Option 2' },
    { id: 2, value: 'Option 3' },
  ]}
/>;

featureExamples.title: Native support
featureExamples.description: Switch to native support for mobile usage. Avoid using it for desktop applications.

featureExamples.title: Text overflow
featureExamples.description:
Control text overflow in the field with the textOverflow. Apply clip or ellipsis.

Dropdown list options wrap by default. To apply ellipsis, select the items to be displayed with the listItemSelectBuilder. This isn't recommended.

content.description: Pagination splits up large amounts of content into multiple pages.
do: Use it to let users navigate between content on multiple pages.

dont: Don’t use it to navigate between content on the same page. Use <Tabs/> instead.

developerExamples.title: Range validation
developerExamples.description:
The min and max properties enable built-in range validation, so no need to add onChange and value.

Users will still be able to enter invalid numbers, but will be notified that what they entered is invalid. Set the error message using invalidMessage.

Don't allow users to submit a form with an invalid input value. Use onInvalid to get an invalid event.

developerExamples.title: Integrating with react-hook-form
developerExamples.description: react-hook-form reduces the amount of code you need to write while removing unnecessary re-renders. The preview here demonstrates form validation in action while using the number input.

content.description: Number inputs allow users to enter and edit numeric values in a single line input field. The value can be inserted using the keyboard or incremented using the arrow controls.
do: Use it to enter custom numeric values, e.g., amount, price, quantity.
Use it to adjust values by a specific amount, e.g., the number of items in a shopping cart.
dont: Don’t use it to enter numerals that don't indicate quantity or measurements, e.g., phone numbers or postal codes. Use regular <Input/> instead.
Don’t use it to enter dates and times. Use <DatePicker/> or <TimeInput/> instead.

accessibilityExamples.title: Helper text
accessibilityExamples.description:
To help users enter the correct value, use helper text below the input which describes the constraints.

This will help prevent user errors.
accessibilityExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <FormField label="Label" statusMessage="Helper text">
    <NumberInput size="medium" />
  </FormField>
  <FormField
    label="Number of visitors"
    statusMessage="Enter numbers only, from 1 to 100"
  >
    <NumberInput size="medium" />
  </FormField>
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

commonUseCaseExamples.title: Settings panel
commonUseCaseExamples.description: Use number input with other components like <Slider/> in a <FieldSet/> wrapper to group them together and let users define the exact numerical value.

commonUseCaseExamples.title: Compound input
commonUseCaseExamples.description: Stack items next to each other with <Box/> when fields represent the same data, or when a change in one input affects one or more other fields.

commonUseCaseExamples.title: Disabled stepper
commonUseCaseExamples.description: Disable the arrows once the minimum or maximum value has been reached.

featureExamples.title: Size
featureExamples.description:
Adjust the size using the size prop. There are 3 supported sizes:

  • When the input needs to be emphasized, like in onboarding flows, use large.
  • In most cases, use the default medium.
  • For dense and narrow layouts where space is tight, use small.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <NumberInput size="large" placeholder="Large" />
  <NumberInput size="medium" placeholder="Medium" />
  <NumberInput size="small" placeholder="Small" />
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Border
featureExamples.description:
Style the field using the border prop. It supports 4 styles:

  • For most common cases, like forms, use standard.
  • To build inputs that can be used to filter data, use round.
  • Use bottomLine to create an editable, underlined title field.
  • When a component provides its own hover and focus styles, such as a table or spreadsheet cells, use none.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <NumberInput border="standard" placeholder="Standard" />
  <NumberInput border="round" placeholder="Round" />
  <NumberInput border="bottomLine" placeholder="Bottom line" />
  <NumberInput border="none" placeholder="None" />
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Status
featureExamples.description:
Control the status of the input using the status prop. It supports 3 states:

  • error demonstrates that a required input is missing something or the entry was invalid.
  • warning highlights an input value that might have a significant impact to a user.
  • loading shows when an input value is being uploaded to the server.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <NumberInput status="error" placeholder="Error" />
  <NumberInput status="warning" placeholder="Warning" />
  <NumberInput status="loading" placeholder="Loading" />
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Status message
featureExamples.description:
Add text that explains the status or what action the user should take with the statusMessage prop.

Showing the status message inline, directly below the input is preferred in all default cases.

  • To add an accessible inline message, wrap the component in a <FormField/> and add the statusMessage.
  • To add a status message in a tooltip that requires users to hover on the icon, use the statusMessage prop. Control tooltip placement with tooltipPlacement prop.

    • View more inline status message examples in <FormField/>.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column" gap="12px">
    <Text secondary>For all default cases:</Text>
    <FormField status="error" statusMessage="This is an error message.">
      <NumberInput placeholder="See message below" tooltipPlacement="top-end" />
    </FormField>
  </StorybookComponents.Stack>
  <StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column" gap="12px">
    <Text secondary>For narrow layouts only:</Text>
    <NumberInput
      placeholder="Hover on status icon"
      status="error"
      statusMessage="This is an error message."
      tooltipPlacement="top-end"
    />
  </StorybookComponents.Stack>
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Prefix and suffix
featureExamples.description: Add text, icons or a button at the beginning or end of the input field using prefix and suffix.
featureExamples.example:

  <NumberInput suffix={<Input.Affix>%</Input.Affix>} value="10" />
  <NumberInput
    prefix={

      </Input.IconAffix>
    }
    value="2"
    suffix={<Input.Affix>guests</Input.Affix>}
  />
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Read-only and disabled
featureExamples.description:
Inputs can also be made read-only or disabled entirely.

  • readOnly disables the field, so users can't enter new values. The current value can still be copied.
  • disabled removes all interactions and creates a disabled input state. Use it to highlight functions that are unavailable.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <NumberInput placeholder="Read-only" readOnly />
  <NumberInput placeholder="Disabled" disabled />
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Clear button
featureExamples.description: Enable a button that lets users easily clear the input value by using the clearButton prop. Use it when the input value is optional or has to be cleared often.

featureExamples.title: Increment by steps
featureExamples.description:
Use the step prop to specify what the increments are when clicking up or down on the arrows.

The arrows controls can be hidden with hideStepper. When the arrows are hidden, the field value can still be incremented by the set step when the field is changed using the arrow keys on the keyboard.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <NumberInput
    step={20}
    placeholder="Click on the arrows to change the value by 20 units at a time."
  />
  <NumberInput
    step={20}
    hideStepper
    placeholder="Click the up and down arrow keys to change the value by 20 when the arrows are hidden."
  />
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Min and max values
featureExamples.description:
If the user inputs something outside of the minimum or maximum, explain that it's invalid using the invalidMessage prop.

Get informed about invalid message events by using the onInvalid callback function.
featureExamples.example:
<NumberInput
  min={-5}
  max={5}
  invalidMessage="Enter a number between -5 and 5."
  placeholder="Try typing a number less than -5 or more than 5"
/>;
