content.description: Slider is an input field that enables our users to select a value within a given number range. It’s handy when a user needs an approximate but not a precise value.
do: Use it to adjust settings, such as opacity, brightness or volume.
Use it to specify an accepted range of values, such as price range.
Use it to control color opacity.
dont: Don’t use it to select a value within an extremely small range (e.g., 1-3). Use <RadioGroup/> or <NumberInput/> instead.

commonUseCaseExamples.title: Editable slider
commonUseCaseExamples.description: Let users enter an exact value with an editable text field.

commonUseCaseExamples.title: Color opacity
commonUseCaseExamples.description: Use slider with the gradientColor prop to control the opacity of a selected color.

commonUseCaseExamples.title: Composer
commonUseCaseExamples.description: Use sliders in a composer to let users adjust a variety of settings such as opacity, brightness, border radius, border weight, etc.

commonUseCaseExamples.title: Form
commonUseCaseExamples.description: Use a slider in a form to let users select a range of values, such as minimum and maximum values.

commonUseCaseExamples.title: Design panel
commonUseCaseExamples.description:
Use sliders to let users control color opacity and border width in a design panel.

  • Use a slider with the gradientColor prop to let users control the opacity of a selected color.
  • Let users enter an exact border width using an editable text field.

featureExamples.title: Range
featureExamples.description: Specify a range of a slider by defining `min` and `max` values.
featureExamples.example: <Slider min={1} max={20} value={3} />;

featureExamples.title: Values
featureExamples.description:
Specifies what `value` slider will represent:
 - `number` (default) - use it to select value within a given range.
 - `array` - use it to select a range of values within a given range.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <Slider min={0} max={50} value={10} />
  <Slider min={0} max={50} value={[10, 25]} />
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Start point
featureExamples.description:
Control the starting point of a slider with `startPoint` prop.
        A default starting point is a minimum value from a defined range.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <Slider startPoint={0} min={0} max={50} />
  <Slider startPoint={0} min={-25} max={25} />
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Marks
featureExamples.description:
Use marks to indicate allowed selections that slider thumb will snap to. Marks are enabled by default, but can be hidden using `displayMarks` prop.

Default marks display numeric values of start and end of a range.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <Slider min={0} max={50} displayMarks={true} />
  <Slider min={0} max={50} displayMarks={false} />
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Marks label alignment
featureExamples.description:
Control mark label alignment with the marksLabelAlignment prop, choose between:

  • center (default) - marks title will overflow outside slider bounds.
  • inside - marks will be aligned inside slider edges.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <Slider min={-100} max={100} marksLabelAlignment="center" />
  <Slider min={-100} max={100} marksLabelAlignment="inside" />
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Custom marks
featureExamples.description: Define custom marks for each accepted selection value via `marks` prop. It accepts numeric or string values.

featureExamples.title: Step
featureExamples.description:
Define a step to reduce the amount of accepted values within a range.
        Default step is 1 and might not work well for larger value ranges, such as 1-1000.
featureExamples.example: <Slider min={0} max={100} step={10} />;

featureExamples.title: Direction
featureExamples.description:
Sets the slider’s orientation:

horizontal (default) — renders along the x‑axis.

vertical — renders along the y‑axis, useful for tight or tall layouts.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <Slider min={0} max={50} direction="horizontal" />
  <Box height="150px"><Slider min={0} max={5} direction="vertical" /></Box>
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Pushable & crossing handles
featureExamples.description:
Control whether range slider handles should cross or push one another. By default handles are allowed to cross.
        If `pushable` prop is set, moving the handle on top of another one will move the whole selected range.

featureExamples.title: Opacity
featureExamples.description:
Use slider to control the opacity of a selected color with gradientColor prop.

Pass any color in color names, RGB or HEX formats.
featureExamples.example: <Slider gradientColor="#229954" displayMarks={false} />;

featureExamples.title: Disabled
featureExamples.description: Disable all slider interactions with `disabled` prop. Use it to highlight a temporary unavailable function.
featureExamples.example: <Slider min={1} max={10} disabled />;

content.description: Transition is a wrapper that allows animations of other components.
do: Use it to animate components that need a visual explanation of their origin or termination. For example tooltip appearance animation.
Use it for animated transitions between object states to provide clarity of change.
dont: Don't use it to animate interface elements for sake of effect.
Don't use it for idle animations, like loading spinner.

commonUseCaseExamples.title: Animating list items
commonUseCaseExamples.description: Use Transition component in cases when new elements appear or disappear from a screen, like in this case when dismissing list items.

featureExamples.title: Enter Animation
featureExamples.description:
Make component appear using these four animation types:

  • Fade In - use it for sudden appearances or state changes.
  • Move In - use it to emphasize direction from which object appears. It supports 4 possible directions.
  • Expand - use it for objects that appear in between the content. It supports 4 possible directions.
  • ScaleUp - use it to explain that object appears from a certain point. It supports 9 possible directions.

    • To see all possible direction options please check API.

featureExamples.title: Exit Animation
featureExamples.description:
Make components disappear using these four animation types:

  • Fade Out - use it for appearances or state changes.
  • Move Out - use it to emphasize the direction to which object disappears. It supports 4 possible directions.
  • Collapse - use it for objects that disappear in between the content. It supports 4 possible directions.
  • ScaleDown - use it to explain that an object disappears to a certain point. It supports 9 possible directions.

    • To see all possible direction options please check API.

featureExamples.title: Duration
featureExamples.description:
Use it to determine how long animation plays. Choose form 6 following properties:

  • Fast01 - 100ms. Use for small objects such as Buttons or Toggles.
  • Fast02 - 150ms. Use for larger than small objects such as Tooltips or Section Helpers.
  • Medium01 - 200ms. Use for medium size objects like dropdowns or accordions.
  • Medium02 - 300ms. Use for greater than medium size objects like side panel or small modals.
  • Slow01 - 450ms. Use for larger objects like big modals or large collapsible content.
  • Slow02 - 600ms. Use for very large objects like page transitions.

featureExamples.title: Easing
featureExamples.description:
Use it to determine the velocity of the object's motion:

  • Enter Easing - used for objects that appear on the screen during the enter animation.
  • Exit Easing - used for objects that disappear from the screen during the exit animation.
  • Standard Easing - used for objects that stay present on the screen during enter or exit animations. For example toggle switch.

featureExamples.title: Delay
featureExamples.description:
Use it to determine the time it takes for animation or next animation to start. There are three delay values:

  • Short - 100ms.
  • Medium - 150ms.
  • Long - 200ms.

content.description: Custom modal layouts contain content like forms, lists, or media within a <Modal/> overlay.
do: Use it to present a subtask, display more information or other custom content.
Use it after an intentional user action and only when it is completely necessary. Because they are intrusive, modals should be used sparingly.
dont: Don’t use to display essential information or primary tasks. Use <Card/> on the main page instead.
Don’t use to prevent users from taking a destructive action or to communicate short messages. Use <MessageModalLayout/> instead.
Don’t use to preview files such as images, videos or PDFs. Use <ModalPreviewLayout/> instead.
Don’t use in mobile environments. Use <ModalMobileLayout/> instead

accessibilityExamples.title: Using modals
accessibilityExamples.description:
Users with disabilities have difficulty interacting with modals, so use them sparingly, and only for specific purposes.

  • Use modals to confirm an action, or to perform subtasks that aren't the primary tasks on the page.
  • Don't use modals to save space on a page. Consider using expand/collapse functionality instead.
  • Avoid opening multiple modals one after the other as it can disorient the users. Consider using a separate flow.

accessibilityExamples.title: Heading structure
accessibilityExamples.description:
All modals must have a logical, descending heading structure that doesn't skip levels.

  • Use <h2> for the main modal heading.
  • Use <h3> for subsequent headings within the modal.
  • Don't skip heading levels.

};

Focus users’ attention on feature promotions with modals. Use them sparingly and only after users intentionally open the promotional content.

For example, use a custom modal layout with a <MarketingLayout/> inside.

featureExamples.title: Structure
featureExamples.description:
The custom modal layout can include the following:

  • title (required)
  • subtitle
  • content (required)
  • sideActions
  • footnote

    • To add supplementary actions, like a "Don't show this again" checkbox, use sideActions.

    To include additional information, add a footnote, e.g., “By sending an invite, you agree to the Wix Terms of Use.”
featureExamples.example:

  primaryButtonText="Save"
  secondaryButtonText="Cancel"
  onCloseButtonClick={() => {}}

  subtitle="Subtitle"
  footnote={
    <StorybookComponents.Placeholder>Footnote</StorybookComponents.Placeholder>
  }
  sideActions={
    <StorybookComponents.Placeholder>
      Side actions
    </StorybookComponents.Placeholder>
  }
  content={
    <StorybookComponents.Placeholder height="240px">
      Content
    </StorybookComponents.Placeholder>
  }
/>;

featureExamples.title: Height and width
featureExamples.description:
By default, modals grow with their content, but they'll never extend higher than the user’s viewport (with 48 px top and bottom padding).

Control a custom modal's height with these two properties:

  • height fixes height in pixels.
  • maxHeight sets a custom max height in pixels.

    • When modal content extends below the user's viewport, height or maxHeight, content scrolls vertically with a fixed header and footer.

    Control a custom modal's width with width property.

    Minimum width of a modal is 510px., maximum width is 1254px.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
  <CustomModalLayout
    primaryButtonText="Save"
    secondaryButtonText="Cancel"
    onCloseButtonClick={() => {}}
    secondaryButtonOnClick={() => {}}
    primaryButtonOnClick={() => {}}
    title="Auto height (default)"
    content={<Box height="180px" />}
  />

  <CustomModalLayout
    height="360px"
    primaryButtonText="Save"
    secondaryButtonText="Cancel"
    onCloseButtonClick={() => {}}
    secondaryButtonOnClick={() => {}}
    primaryButtonOnClick={() => {}}
    title="Height is fixed at 360 px"
    content={<Box height="360px" />}
  />
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Content padding

This property can be used to show components with built-in padding like <Page/> or <Table/>.

featureExamples.description:
Control the component style with theme prop:

  • standard is the default used in all common cases.
  • premium is used to promote Premium features.
  • destructive is for actions that have a destructive effect on user data, like delete. For short warning messages, use the <MessageModalLayout/> in a destructive theme instead.

featureExamples.description:
Control visibility of both the header and footer dividers with the showHeaderDivider and showFooterDivider props.

  • auto is the default that shows header divider only when content is scrolled and always shows the footer divider.
  • true always shows the dividers.
  • false always hides the dividers.

featureExamples.description:
Control button size with size prop:

  • large is best for calls to action that require more emphasis.
  • medium is for main page actions and common use cases.

  • tiny is used for dense layouts.

featureExamples.title: Skin
featureExamples.description:
Change the appearance of a button with a skin prop.

  • standard is for general primary actions.
  • light is for primary actions that are on dark backgrounds.
  • destructive is only for actions that have a destructive effect on user data, like delete.
  • premium is for actions that prompt users to upgrade their plans to premium subscription.
  • premium-light is best for upgrade actions that appear on dark backgrounds.
  • dark should be used with buttons on backgrounds with colors.
  • transparent is for general actions on backgrounds with vivid colors or images.
  • ai should be used with AI based features.

    • Each action can be primary or secondary. There should only be one primary action per page.

    Note: Secondary buttons should be used alongside primary buttons for less utilized actions, such as cancel or back.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column" gap="40px">
  <Box gap="20px">
    <Button>Standard Primary</Button>
    <Button priority="secondary">Standard Secondary</Button>
  </Box>
  <Box gap="20px" backgroundColor="#000" padding="6px">
    <Button skin="light">Light Primary</Button>
    <Button skin="light" priority="secondary">
      Light Secondary
    </Button>
  </Box>
  <Box gap="20px">
    <Button skin="destructive">Destructive Primary</Button>
    <Button skin="destructive" priority="secondary">
      Destructive Secondary
    </Button>
  </Box>
  <Box gap="20px">
    <Button skin="premium">Premium Primary</Button>
    <Button skin="premium" priority="secondary">
      Premium Secondary
    </Button>
  </Box>
  <Box gap="20px" backgroundColor="#000" padding="6px">
    <Button skin="premium-light">Premium Light Primary</Button>
    <Button skin="premium-light" priority="secondary">
      Premium Light Secondary
    </Button>
  </Box>
  <Box gap="20px">
    <Button skin="dark">Dark Primary</Button>
    <Button skin="dark" priority="secondary">
      Dark Secondary
    </Button>
  </Box>
  <Box gap="20px" backgroundColor="#3899EB" padding="6px">
    <Button skin="transparent">Transparent Primary</Button>
    <Button skin="transparent" priority="secondary">
      Transparent Secondary
    </Button>
  </Box>
  <Box gap="20px">
    <Button skin="ai">Ai Primary</Button>
    <Button skin="ai" priority="secondary">
      Ai Secondary
    </Button>
  </Box>
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Affix
featureExamples.description:
Add more context to actions with affix icons:

  • Emphasize the button action with a prefixIcon.
  • Indicate that an action will open a popover or navigate users to another page with a suffixIcon.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="line">
  <StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
    <StorybookComponents.Stack>
      <Button size="large" prefixIcon={<Icons.Add />}>
        Prefix
      </Button>
    </StorybookComponents.Stack>
    <StorybookComponents.Stack>
      <Button size="medium" prefixIcon={<Icons.Add />}>
        Prefix
      </Button>
    </StorybookComponents.Stack>
    <StorybookComponents.Stack>
      <Button size="small" prefixIcon={<Icons.AddSmall />}>
        Prefix
      </Button>
    </StorybookComponents.Stack>
    <StorybookComponents.Stack>
      <Button size="tiny" prefixIcon={<Icons.AddSmall />}>
        Prefix
      </Button>
    </StorybookComponents.Stack>
  </StorybookComponents.Stack>
  <StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column">
    <StorybookComponents.Stack>
      <Button size="large" suffixIcon={<Icons.ChevronDown />}>
        Suffix
      </Button>
    </StorybookComponents.Stack>
    <StorybookComponents.Stack>
      <Button size="medium" suffixIcon={<Icons.ChevronDown />}>
        Suffix

    </StorybookComponents.Stack>

        Suffix

    </StorybookComponents.Stack>
    <StorybookComponents.Stack>

</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Disabled
featureExamples.description: To disable a button, use the disabled prop which indicates a button can't be selected.
featureExamples.example: <Button disabled>Disabled</Button>

featureExamples.title: Text overflow
featureExamples.description:
Use the ellipsis prop for overflow text. The full text will be displayed in a <Tooltip/> when a user hovers over the button. Control the style of the tooltip using the tooltipProps.

Note: Try to avoid lengthy action labels. CTA text should be short and clear – one to two words, or max three for specific use cases.
featureExamples.example:
<StorybookComponents.Stack flexDirection="column" width="180px">
  <Button ellipsis>
    This label exceeds available space and is shown in a tooltip
  </Button>
</StorybookComponents.Stack>;

featureExamples.title: Full width
featureExamples.description: When working on mobile designs, use the fullWidth prop to fill the button to 100% of the parent container.
featureExamples.example: <Button fullWidth>Full width</Button>
